story:
Broadway Performing Arts Center 

Founded in 2008 by professional dancers and choreographers Tina Casula Gross and Cheyenne Gross, Broadway Performing Arts Center has quickly become a neighborhood mainstay with steadily rising enrollment rosters. 

Children are introduced to a variety of dance styles including classical ballet, tap, jazz and hip-hop.  Recognizing that the Washington Heights/Inwood community was under served compared with other parts of the city in performing arts venues for children, Miss Tina & Mr. Cheyenne were motivated to bring their vast experience and talents to the kids of Upper Manhattan.  Boasting an annual dance recital replete with top of the line costumes, Broadway Performing Arts Center is gaining momentum as the premier dance experience for the children of our neighborhood. Classes are taught at The Cornerstone Center; 178 Bennett Avenue    (1 block west of Broadway at 189th street) 

 
For more information, contact Tina Casula Gross at tina@broadwaypac.com or call 917.312.6263, www.broadwaypac.com 

We Need Your Help

We have grown so fast and with that growth there is a demand for improvements.  We began in 2008 with just a room. Two year ago we improved the studio by purchasing mirrors and a professional reversible marley dance floor.  Now that we have expanded we need to give our students attending class in our second room a set of mirrors too.  We also need to allow the students to grow by installing ballet barres. 

The Impact

 This fundraiser is so important to help the growth of the studio and the students.  It's so amazing to watch their faces in the mirror as they see themselves and the rest of their classmates.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help. Here are some ways you can:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Facebook, Twitter, Emails or just plain word of mouth.

And thank you from the bottom of our hearts and the tips of our toes!

story:
Last year I had the opportunity to be in a production of the new musical 'Orphan Train' - under the direction of Pat Birch.  (You can 'google' her...) It was so amazing to be a part of a production that was so well directed and is more than just 'fluffy' entertainment. 

A couple weeks ago, Pat called me and asked if I would be in the upcoming production of 'Orphan Train' to be put up at Grand Central Station in New York - as part of the 100 year anniversary celebration that is going on all year. I would LOVE to be a part of this - and feel it could be a huge boost to my acting career.

As all too many theater productions go, this project is under-funded, in that they can't afford to pay me - they would cover my 'room and board' ... and I would be away from my work as a contractor for 3.5 weeks ...

Unfortunately, I am just not in a position to walk away from my income for that length of time, and yet feel it is important for me to do this.  This brings me here - to you.

Many of you may have seen me on stage ... Many of you are great supporters of theater.  I am hoping you will read this, watch this and support me by, 'likeing' this, 'sharing' this, and perhaps even make a donation.  Thanks so much!

story:
What is ArtBra New Haven?

ArtBra New Haven is an art and fashion show event that provides a creative emotional outlet to the community of breast cancer patients, survivors and supporters.  It raises money to pay directly for treatment for under and uninsured breast cancer patients.

With your help this year’s event will be held at New Haven, Connecticut's historic Long Wharf Theatre on November 6th 2014.

What is an ArtBra?

It’s pretty simple. Art + Bra = ArtBra.  Artists take simple, or not so simple, bras and through their creativity and imagination transform them into fantastic works of art.  They range from serious to silly, from sublime to spectacular. And each and every one of them tells a particular story.


Adding a “T” to “PAIN”

I want to stop for a moment now and tell you how I discovered Art Bras.

ArtBras are not a new thing, they’ve been around for over 20  years.  I heard about it from a friend of mine while I was going through treatment.  I was bald and looked like Uncle Fester.   Due to my lack of resistance I could barely leave the house.  So I started making Art Bras and I couldn’t believe how much better it made me feel to focus on something positive.  But it was still just something I was doing for myself and by myself.

That’s when I got a call from my Aunt Edith, a noted regional fine artist. She was calling with news that she’d had a reccurence of her cancer.  One day while calling to offer her support she said the most amazing thing.  I asked her if she was in pain and she told me “Whenever I’m in pain I just add the letter T and turn ‘pain’ into paint”.

That’s when I realized I’ve got to get this idea out there.  To connect the artist community and the cancer community with the idea of creating and sharing our stories and experiences through ArtBras.

Why Hold An Event?

Because bringing people together is the best way to celebrate our struggle and survival. 

Because these fantastic ArtBras look even better up close and in person.

Because we need a place for everyone, including our health care providers, to meet each other in a nonclinical setting and enjoy themselves and each other.

Because there’s nothing quite like the emotional charge that goes through a room when a cancer survivor walks down the runway modeling an Art Bra.

Because through ticket sales, ArtBra auctions, and donations we’re able to raise vital money to help under and uninsured women afford their treatment. 

What happens at ArtBra New Haven?

There’s a live runway fashion show featuring survivors modeling ArtBras, a gallery show of ArtBras and fine art, as well as a live and a silent auction.

We also take time to honor someone from the community who made a significant contribution to the struggle against breast cancer.  This year’s honoree has not yet been announced but in the past we’ve honored everyone form politicians to geneticists.  Congresswomen Rosa DeLauro still proudly displays her Capitol Hill Art Bra in her office!

Why an Indiegogo Campaign?

So many artists, organizations and members of the community donate their time and energy to the event.  But in order to make it happen, and for the most possible amount of funds raised from the event to go to supporting under and uninsured patients, we need your support.

What Are The Rewards?

We’re very excited this year to be producing a fabulous full color souvenir program featuring ArtBra photos and stories of the amazing women participating in this year’s event.  The next best thing to attending ArtBra New Haven is to get one of these programs for yourself.

You can also get a great Pink Pearl Bracelet with an ArtBra New Haven charm, an ArtBra mug with specially created pink ArtBra Tea or even an ArtBra of your own.


We’re making it possible for you to sponsor a ticket for someone who otherwise could not afford it to attend ArtBra New Haven, or to have a personal ArtBra making party with your friends.

You can also become an ArtBra Sponsor or even attend the event as an ArtBra VIP.

If there’s a been an extraordinary medical professional or personal caregiver in your life you can honor them in our program and receive special rewards for you both.

Whatever level you choose the real reward will be knowing that you helped to involve and engage the diverse artistic community of Greater New Haven, to support the under & uninsured, and to fight for the eventual eradication of this disease.

Thank You

On behalf of everyone at ArtBra New Haven thank you for taking the time to look at our campaign.  We hope you’ll take a moment to look over the rewards on the right, get something great for yourself and help us make ArtBra New Haven happen.

story:
Help us spread the love (further)

A brief history

ps: We Are All Here was launched last summer alongside the annual Summer Love-In intensive in Toronto. The wildly successful 6 evening event was presented at Collective Space in Toronto's west end. Curated by The Love-In team, ps: We Are All Here, presents local and international artists in an intimate and casual setting that encourages discourse and engagement, taking in and taking on the questions that arise over contemporary performance. There is also beer, music and many sweaty, beautiful humans.

"Contemporary, yes. Well-curated. Dance for the theatrical folk. Dance for conceptual folk. Dance for dancers. Dance for participation. Dance for sensual types. It makes you dance. And great stories behind the works. " - Helen Yung, writing about the 2013 edition

ps We Are All Here (2013) Bee Pallomina

2013 Artists included: Amanda Acorn (Toronto), Lady Janitor aka Eroca Nicols (Toronto) and Francesca Pedulla (Italy), Andréa de Keijzer (Montreal), Heidi Strauss and Darryl Tracy (Toronto), Brandy Leary/Anandam Dance (Toronto), RootlessRoot (Greece), Bee Pallomina (Toronto), Vanessa Kimmons (Toronto), Helen Husak (Calgary), Zoja Smutny (Toronto/Berlin), Simon Renaud (Gatineau), Colleen Snell (Toronto), and Andrea Spaziani (Toronto). 

About the Love-In (briefly)

The Love-In is home to the silent, love revolution, taking place in Canadian dance making. Dedicated to the radical and rampant cultivation of tomorrow’s badass leaders and lovers, we promote democratic pedagogy, anti-competition and wild creative abandon through our programming and our presence in the Toronto dance community.  By connecting, supporting and welcoming artists locally and across the planet, the Love-In is making Toronto a destination for revolutionary indie dance activity. We are building better making; we are radicalizing movers; we are Animaux Sauvages. 

The Love-In has presented over 50 professional workshops with local, national and international artists, 4 Summer Love-In intensives, 20 teaching space workshops and built partnerships with training providers in Ontario and Quebec, building capacity for collaboration to continue to bring the most exciting artists into our community in Toronto. 

Summer Love-In 2013: Fighting Monkey workshop with RootlessRoot, photo by Andrea de Keijzer

Lovers: Amanda Acorn, Amelia Ehrhardt, Katya Kuznetsova, Kate Nankervis, Eroca Nicols, Madeleine Shen

Administrative lover: Emma Letki


ps: We Are All Here part deux, July 4, 5, 11, 12 at 8pm

"dear toronto, go see these shows. if you don't, it'll be like missing that clash concert you weren't even born yet to see, and feel remorse for not being there. you're alive to see these ones. don't live with the regret of missing them." - profession of love, Robert Abubo, July 2013

Pia Bouman's Scotiabank Theatre, 6 Noble St, Toronto (entrance by parking lot only...)

Visual artist/environment: Helen Yung

Artists that will be making it, breaking it, and putting it all back together again include:

Toronto locals- Meryem Alaoui, Michael Caldwell, Valerie Calam, D.A. Hoskins, Amelia Ehrhardt, Christie Stoeten

Candian nationals- Kelly Keenan and Adam Kinner (MTL), Sonya Stefan (MTL), Pamela Tzeng (CGY)

Internationalistas- Meg Foley (USA), Gregory Holt (USA), WITCHTITS/Alicia Grant (TO/Berlin)

Stay for the after partie July 5th and 12th: Dancefloor sounds provided by Sigourney Beaver and Manchyna. Party surprises to come....


Loving takes two, let's love each other

(what we need and what you get)

  • The money raised will go toward rounding out artist's and technical fees as well as venue costs. The Love-In is generously supported by project funding from the Toronto Arts Council, Ontario Arts Council and the Canada Council for the Arts. The majority of this funding goes towards operating costs and administration associated with our workshops and professional development activities. We have yet to receive funding specifically for the presentation of ps: We Are All Here. Help us build a legacy of a bad-ass series for dance and performance makers in Toronto! 
  • We have some great perks to give away including long distance love healing, private dances, VIP treatment at p.s, and the big one a dinner prepared by the Lovers for you and a friend.


The Impact

The Love-In has been heading a love revolution in Toronto since 2009 and we want you to be a part of it. The Love-In's programming supports the community through professional training activities, development opportunities and building a sense of community. ps: We Are All Here is our newest and most ambitious activity in addition to our professional workshops, meetings and advocacy efforts. Curated presentation opportunities for dance artists are sparse in Toronto and the Love-In is passionate about providing another venue for local artists to share their work alongside national and international artists. The Love-In hopes the series will grow to be larger and more wonderful each year. Help us do it!!!


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Help us spread the good word and make some noise about our campaign! 
  • Wear your Love-In T-shirt everywhere
  • Come to the shows in July :)
  • Share our campaign!!! Share, share, share!

story:
Short Summary

JESSICA KONDRATH | THE MOVEMENT is a modern dance/contemporary ballet company based in Long Beach, CA.  We are currently raising funds to support our upcoming Fall 2014 season with performances in Long Beach, Pasadena, Santa Barbara, and potentially Chicago!  With your help we can make this season a reality.  Since relocating from New York City in 2009, JKTM has performed in San Francisco, Chicago, Santa Barbara, San Diego, Pasadena, and New York City, however this will be our first full length concert since moving from NYC and we can't do it without you!  Your tax deductible donations, large and small, will go towards costume construction, musician fees, lighting design, space rental, touring expenses such as airfare, and most importantly dancer pay.  In putting this concert together, we have had the great fortune to work with Tamara McCarty as a costume designer for Fleeting and with Brian Wood, who has composed a gorgeous piece of music for us to dance to in I Still Haven't Learned How to Dream Wide Awake.  Your contributions will make it possible for him to join us live onstage.  

In addition to self producing our home season at ARC Pasadena, we have been invited to perform I Still Haven't Learned How to Dream Wide Awake in Santa Barbara at HIVE, a group show of amazing local dance artists.

We are hoping, with enough donations raised, to bring I Still Haven't Learned How to Dream Wide Awake to Chicago this winter.  

This season is an exciting one that involves large growths for the company.  I want to thank you for helping me bring our work to the stage!


What We Need & What You Get

There are so many various costs that go into one production, but some examples of how your donations will assist us are:

  • a donation of $15 will pay for one hour of rehearsal (the small donations matter so much!)
  • a donation of $50 will pay to costume I Still Haven't Learned How to Dream Wide Awake
  • a donation of $100 will pay a dancer's performance fee for one night
  • a donation of $200 will pay to costume Fleeting
  •  a donation of $500 will pay for our performance space
  • a donation of $1000 will get us to Chicago
It often feels as though the small donations will not make a difference, but if 200 people gave $10 each, it would cover our performance fees at ARC Pasadena.  Your tax deductible gifts add up and will be used to cover our season's expenses whether or not we reach our goal of $5000.    


    The Impact

    • Your gifts to JESSICA KONDRATH | THE MOVEMENT will forward our company's recognition in the Los Angeles area and bring awareness to the company outside of LA.  
    • You will be helping us to document our work so that we may apply to further performance opportunities across the US and abroad.  
    •  You will be helping employ not only LA based dance artists, but also a costume designer, musician, and lighting designer.
    • You will be helping us to continue to establish community ties with other dance artists here in California and across the country.  
    • And MOST IMPORTANTLY you will be helping to keep a small modern dance company afloat for the next year.
    We can't do it without you!


    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you cannot contribute at this time, you can help us by

    • Joining us for our performances at ARC Pasadena September 27th & 28th or in Santa Barbara November 2nd.  
    • Sharing our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, email, or word of mouth 
    • We are fiscally sponsored through Fractured Atlas throughout the year if you are able to contribute at another time, your help is always appreciated (and needed)!

      From all of us at JESSICA KONDRATH | THE MOVEMENT we THANK YOU!!!!

story:
First and foremost, the video above is a video of me and a peer acting. Feel free to take a look!

Hey everyone! To anyone reading this first I have to thank you greatly for taking any interest in my cause. My name is Pamela Munoz as you might know and I am currently a senior in high school, I live in the South Bronx, with my dad and my sister is away at college. I am very passionate about acting and have been doing it for about 4 years now. Freshman year my first close counter with this field was when my mentor/teacher/and forever close friend Ms. Rothwell cast me in a school play and I began doing puppet work and learning what memorizing lines were, and even getting my hands on improv. The world of theater since then fascinated me. There was something deep inside me that came out whenever I acted, and I never knew where it came from. It is like a calling to me and its my time to answer. Since then I've done musicals and plays, from You're A Good Man Charlie Brown to Much Ado About Nothing by Shakespeare. I've gone to many summer programs including the Summer Arts Institute 2011, Carnegie Mellon Pre College program to even studying at the Stella Adler program. I have been very blessed and fortunate along the way, that many have supported me in my journey.

As a senior in high school I have applied and auditioned to many schools. I am very fortunate to say that I will be going to Boston University with a Bachelor of Fine Arts after my audition was considered for the school. This was HUGE to me. It was the first step to making my dreams come true. However this same dream now puts not only me in debt, but also my father. He works day and night as a cab driver to barely even make the monthly rent. It would pain me to put any more financial burden on him than I already have and so this is why this campaign is so important. Because 5,000 dollars could make a difference in making my dream come true. Something that I am so certain and so in love with is this craft. With any contribution made, it is a contribution, and it is a vouch of faith in my success in this career. It would absolutely mean the world for me, and give me the support I need to continue on in such a risky career. 

In short, I will need 5,000 dollars to fill the gap in my financial aid that will go towards Boston University. Otherwise my dad will have to take this money out in loans, and he cannot afford that at all. This money will strictly go towards my cost of attendance for this university. Even if the goal is not reached, my family or friends or anyone will be able to fill the rest as much as I can, and I will do all in my power to fill up any gaps also. I will jump, scream and shout if this happens for me. And it is truly an opportunity that only comes once in a lifetime and I feel that I must reach out my hands and grasp it. Rather than make anyone else happy with a comfortable and practical job, I'm going to take the road less traveled by... And that will make all the difference in my life.

Also...

Anything you can donate, whether it be 5 or 10 dollars will make all the difference to me. And if you cannot donate, please please please feel free to share it among your friends and family and anyone who can help.

Thank you so so much, I am so incredibly grateful.

story:
"Las Placitas De Nuestros Pueblos" is a musical play that reflects the Salvadoran culture. It focuses on identifying diverse regions throughout the country with different types of folk music and dances. Throughout the play, our performers portray the lifestyle of Salvadoran peasants, their mannerisms and customs in order to help the audience understand the diversity of the Salvadoran heritage.


"Las Placitas De Nuestros Pueblos" es un obra musical que refleja la cultura Salvadoreña. Se centra en la identificación de diversas regiones del país con diferentes tipos de música y bailes folclóricos. A lo largo de la obra, nuestros artistas retratan el modo de vida de los campesinos Salvadoreños, sus gestos y costumbres con el fin de ayudar al público a comprender la diversidad del patrimonio Salvadoreño.

story:
Who We Are:

Amaranth Arts is a multi-faceted dance company under the artistic direction of Scott Putman. The company has been sharing its work with audiences both home and abroad since 2006 investigating what it means to be fully human while creating three dimensional visceral kinetic experiences. Fall 2014 finds the company returning to Richmond to share the incredible growth and development of new work in its packed concert, Falling Back to Grace, as well as returning to Denver School of the Arts (DSA) for our 9th annual residency. 

Amaranth Arts unveils the world premier of The One and Lonely, exquisitely executed by one of our most recent new additions, company dancer Johnnie Mercer. In addition, audiences will be treated to the Richmond premier of Shadows Fall Where Light Dares Shine, danced by Rachel Brady and Ryan Rouland Smith, and Creek Walkers Under a Waning Moon, channeled by Jill Brammer Ware and Karli Mestas. The community will also have the opportunity to immerse themselves in the re-staging of the acclaimed On the Shelf of Memory in the Temple of a Compressing Heartperformed by three original cast members, Damion Bond, Erin Dalton, and Paige Horton with a new member to the company, Christina Johnson. A long time collaborating company, Island Moving Company of Newport, RI joins us on stage, performing both Scott Putman’s choreography, Land of a Thousand Reflections and presenting work from their repertory with Richmond audiences for the first time.

Amaranth Arts will be supporting the vision of Artistic Associate, Jill Brammer Ware during our residency performance at Denver School of the Arts highlighting her freshly minted work To Mend With Gold. This production will fold in the performing talents of Artistic Associate, Robert Gosnell and Guest Dancer and Choreographer, Stephanie Martinez. The culminating performance with the DSA dance students will be choreographed by Robert Gosnell, Stephanie Martinez and Scott Putman. This residency has been a highlight of our season for many years and has established a second home for the company.

Cast of Characters

Artistic Director:

Scott Putman

Artistic Associate: 

Jill Brammer Ware

Robert Gosnell

Guest Choreographer: 

Stephanie Martinez

Dancers:

Rachel Brady: DSA Alumni, VCU Alumni

Damion Bond: VCU Alumni

Airin Dalton: VCU Alumni

Paige Horton: VCU Alumni

Christina Johnson: Current VCU Student

Ryan Rouland Smith: DSA Alumni, VCU Alumni

Johnnie Mercer: VCU Alumni

Karli Mestas: Current DSA, Alum VCU Student

What We Need

In order to bring wonderful work to the stage, it takes a great deal of energy, effort, and expense to realize that dream. Your support would greatly help offset our costs to ensure the sharing of our incredible mission and vision:

Falling Back to Grace

Dancers Performance Fee: $300 per dancer (8) $2,400

Theater Rental: $1500

Production Staff and Lighting Design: $1500

PR/Marketing: $1200

Costumes: $500

Set: $750

Travel: $1500

Lodging: $3000

Denver School of the Arts Residency

Guest Choreographer Fee: $3000

Travel and Per Diem: $4000

Car Rental: $600

Lodging: $2400

The Impact

Sharing four works choreographed by Scott Putman and performed by Amaranth Arts

Introducing Island Moving Company to Richmond Audiences by inviting them to perform a work choreographed by Amaranth Arts guest choreographer Stephanie Martinez and Artistic Director Scott Putman

Giving back a portion of our proceeds to Partnership for Non-profit excellence, Cadence Theater, and Richmond Triangle Players

Sharing our teaching and mentorship with the students at Denver School of the Arts

Creating three new works by acclaimed choreographers Scott Putman, Stephanie Martinez and Robert Gosnell.

Denver school of the Arts Residency is free to the school and helps to generate scholarship and program funds with money generated from the performances

    Other Ways to Support

    Share campaign with all of your friends on Facebook, Twitter….

    Come to performances

    Bring friends to performances

    Share your reviews of our work on social media

story:
The Dead Prince

Epic, goofy, comedic and romantic, The Dead Prince follows the story of a put-upon princess who is told by every magic mirror in the land that her true love has died and the two were destined never to meet; for he is dead and she alive. We join the play on the day she discovers it is possible to sneak across the void and steal him back; but does pulling someone from the brink do more damage than you think? A musical comedy full of corpses, bat attacks, magic mirrors, handsome thieves, horrible misunderstandings, lantern light, and quests...glorious quests! 

The Dead Prince reunites Strange Tree company members and associates with some new faces. Emily Schwartz is the author of past favorites The Three Faces of Dr. Crippen (2011 Jeff award, Best New Work), The Mysterious Elephant, Mr. Spacky...The Man Who Was Followed Continuously by Wolves and many more. Paul Holmquist makes his Strange Tree directorial debut. Company members Scott Cupper, Cory Aiello, Michael Downey, Jenifer Starewich, Kate Nawrocki, Stuart Ritter, and Elizabeth Bagby take the stage, along with associates Sarah Scanlon and Thomas Zeitner. Our friends Dan Behrendt, Amber Robinson, and Zachary Sigelko, all from last year's Funeral Wedding, are also in the cast. Ann Sonneville makes her Strange Tree debut as the princess Sara.

On the production side, we've teamed up again with some of our favorite collaborators, including Becca Jeffords, John E. Kelly, Phineas Jones, Tyler Core, Delia Baseman, Michael Huey, Joe Schermoly, and Becky Bishop. Kitty Campbell is creating as many props as a roving gang of musical bandits could possibly want. 

All this magic needs a special place to unfold, and we've got it. The enchanted forest will grow in the heart of downtown, at the DCASE Storefront Theater, at 66 E Randolph.

What We Need & What You Get

We've set a fundraising goal of $3,000 for this show. This will completely cover the expenses of creating an enchanted forest in the Loop: trees, ghosts, bats, bonfire, and gypsy caravan. Any excess funds will go toward our spring production.

When you donate, you get it all:

  • All the love of the Trees! Making onstage worlds is the thing we most love to do, so we tend to have rather warm feelings about the people who help us do that.
  • All the show tickets, merch, and public thanks you can handle! (See the sidebar for details.) 
  • All the tax-deductibility that comes from our 501(c)(3) status!
  • All the mysterious cachet and sexy intrigue of being a part of something entirely new! When you come to a preview of The Dead Prince, you'll be one of the first people in the world to get "Simple Love Song" stuck in your head. (Trust us, you'll want it there.)
  • All the extra joy that comes from helping kids watch theater! With magic, music, mystery, and tickets capped at $15, this will be one of our most family-friendly shows to date. Your donation helps us create an extra-awesome world for the audience members who just might be experiencing theater for the very first time.

*Please Note: To get your name in the program, your donation needs to be processed no later than November 5. We are no less grateful for later donations—we just can't acknowledge them in print. Thanks, champion!

**And: A few donation levels let you choose to receive your reward in the form of either tickets or merch. You must choose...but choose wisely.

***And Also: If you want to get tickets to opening or closing night (that's November 22 or December 22), act fast! Those nights sell out quickly, and much as we'd love to, we cannot tip other patrons from their seats so that you may see the show. Well, maybe...no. No, we cannot.

****Also And Also: Preview dates are November 17, 18, 20 and 21.

Other Ways You Can Help

Our productions are always a giant group effort. What you see on stage represents hundreds if not thousands of hours of work. Want to be a part of it?

  • We always need volunteers to help us paint sets, hang posters, distribute postcards, and staff our merch table. 
  • If you see the show, help us spread the word on Facebook and Twitter.

story:
Hello!  My name is Rick Wiley.
I am a 3rd generation native of Port Townsend, Washington and a 3rd generation Owner Operator of Port Townsend's historic Uptown Theatre.
My Grandfather, Ernie Thompson, established The Uptown in the Springtime of 1947.
For 66 years The Uptown Theatre has been Port Townsend's BIG motion picture venue, and has been witness to many changes in the industry including the advent of CinemaScope and  Multi-Channel Surround Sound.
Nothing however has compared to the most recent industry demand.
The retiring of 35mm Film and the introduction of Digital Cinema.
By the end of 2013, any Theatre not already Digital will most likely be closed and quite possibly for good.

Although we are sentimental about the end of 35mm Film, (the industry format for over 100 years), we are also excited about the future of the Uptown and the new Digital Cinema format.
DCP and other Digital Source material will not only look and sound better, it will be more consistent and will also open up opportunities for a whole world of alternative programming and Archived Movie Classics.
The new Digital Technology will also enable the Uptown to present on our CinemaScope  Screen (the biggest indoor screen on the entire Olympic Peninsula) The newest and biggest in 3D and High Frame Rate Motion Pictures.

In addition to our conversion to Digital Cinema we have an ambitious plan to renovate The Uptown Theatre.
We believe that these changes and improvements are both equally necessary for the Uptown to survive. And once completed, will make for a Spectacular and Grand Uptown Theatre that we can all enjoy for many decades to come.

Seeing this project coming for some time now we have done everything in our power to be ready financially, The  Digital Cinema Equipment is EXTREMELY costly so we have found it necessary, realizing the limitations of the business model, to get creative with a portion of the expense..
We would like to include YOU! Our Friends, Patrons, Fans of the Cinema and more specifically, Fans of the Classic and Historic single auditorium, Single Screen Movie Houses. like The Uptown.
Chronicled by the Washington State Department of Archeology and Historic Preservation as The Oldest Theatre Building in the State.

The actual cost of out project is in the neighborhood of $120,000. With almost 75% of that being The Digital Technology and Equipment alone.
If we can raise $40,000 of that, we will be able to continue with our plan. Get it done on schedule and save The Uptown Theatre from extinction.
Any funding beyond our goal will also go directly to our Digital Conversion / Renovation Project.
Quite frankly, I find it very awkward and a bit embarrassing to have to ask for donations to save a family business that has been operating and employing and playing by the rules for over 66 years, but the times, they are a changin.

With You on board we promise to make the Historic Uptown Theatre something it has never been before and to open a new chapter in the life of this unique and distinguished Iconic Motion Picture venue.

We have lots of creative Ideas to keep things interesting for our patrons at the Uptown and they start with some fun and generous rewards perks for our contributors!

Thank You so much for considering our project.
The clock is ticking, if you can't make a financial contribution you can still be of great assistance simply by spreading the word and networking to as many people as possible about our project.
Once again Thank You and wish us luck!

Rick Wiley
Wiley Theatres
Uptown Theatre / Wheel-In Motor Movie
Port Townsend, Wa.

story:
We are Wolf and Bear productions and for the second time we are producing our own student run show. Last year we started producing our own shows as a way to get behind the scenes of the theater world and make the art we wanted to make. The show we selected to produce last year was "Dog Sees God: Connfessions of a Teenage Blockhead" by Bert V Royal. This year we took on Neil LaBute's play "reasons to be Pretty" a play we feel can connect to people of all ages and not just an older audience. 


That's where you come in

With your help we can make this show bigger and better the Dog Sees God was last year. Your support will go toward costumes, lights, sound, fight choreography, and the rights to the show. We hope you can help us in funding our dreams

Thank you

Logan Riley Bruner and the Wolf and Bear team

story:
The Shelter Presents: Art
Among all creatures on this earth, art is a uniquely human activity. In THE SHELTER PRESENTS: ART, four playwrights track the journey of the artist and examine art’s role in the human experience. This exploration spans time and genres, and in true Shelter style, produces a seamless blend of comedy and drama. 

“THE SHELTER PRESENTS: ART explores the journey of the artist from the birth of art in mankind to the birth of art in the individual man. From hope to desolation, THE SHELTER PRESENTS: ART examines the need to create and how it affects the relationships we have with our fellow human beings," stated The Shelter Co-Artistic Director Meghan E. Jones.

The four short plays are:
  • Michael Sean McGuinness’ GLYPH – a cave comedy about the origin of the artist and his struggle to survive, directed by Catya McMullen. The cast of GLYPH will feature Alec A. Head, Chris Cardona, Andy Hassell, and Tania Verafied.
  • Meghan E. Jones’ MARK MAKES ART – a play that examines two struggling parents whose child is creating brilliant, yet emotionally unsettling drawings, directed by Paco Lozano. This two-hander will feature Beth Jastroch and Dave Lankford.
  • Michael Bernstein’s play ROBOT GIRL envisions a dystopian future, where a lone street artist calls out over airwaves searching for other signs of humanity in a lifeless, robot-automated world, directed by Beth Jastroch. The ROBOT GIRL cast will feature Olivia Killingswoth.
  • Ginger Kearn’s THIS IS A PLAY ABOUT ARTISTS launches two self-righteous artists at one another, creating an absurdly funny – and unexpected – romantic conundrum, directed by Nicole Rosner. THIS IS A PLAY ABOUT ARTISTS will feature Ian Bell, Ginger Kearns and Michael Kingsbaker.

The Shelter will also work with several local New York artists to create a large spectrum of art, spanning many disciplines. Art will be on display at the theatre, a different guest artist will create an original piece of art during each performance, and performance art designed by Melinda Smart will be integrated into the overall production.

THE SHELTER PRESENTS: ART runs April 19 through 29, with performances Wednesdays through Fridays at 8:00pm, Saturdays at 3:00pm and 8:00pm and Sundays at 3:00pm at the Flamboyan Theater (at the CSV Cultural Center, 107 Suffolk Street). Tickets are $12 during preview performances (April 19 and April 20) and $18 for the remainder of the run. Tickets can be purchased online at www.theshelternyc.org or at the door.


About The Shelter
The Shelter is a family of theatrical artists creating authentic theatre for the New York stage. All productions are written, directed, acted, and designed by its members and are developed through the company's weekly Shelter Sunday workshop series. The heartbeat of The Shelter, Shelter Sunday provides a safe harbor where New York's top emerging theatrical artists can collaboratively challenge themselves to explore their artistry and hone their respective crafts.  

"The Shelter is to be applauded for the work it’s doing — developing new theatre and building creative relationships at a time when small theatre companies are dropping like flies. Its approach to making theatre is both practical and optimistic." Regina Robbins, Theatre Is Easy
 
For more information about THE SHELTER PRESENTS: ART or The Shelter, please visit www.theshelternyc.org.

story:
The Story

I'm Skippy Cooper! I've had depression for my entire life, but only recently sought help and treatment. Too bad I didn't have health insurance, so my only choice was to go to a government funded mental health care facility that hires people that made me feel worse with every appointment visit. All of the trash I had to endure just to not want to kill myself naturally made for great satire and comedy, so I've decided to write and perform my very own one woman comedy show complete with reenactments of the situations and characters I encountered! We all know how ripe with comedy depression is, right?! RIGHT!


The Impact

There are millions upon millions of people suffering from all types of mental health disorders. Fun fact, there are also a shit ton of people with mental health disorders that don't have insurance. That means that they will either not seek treatment, or be forced to go through a bureaucratic mental health system that can be slow, demeaning, and unhelpful in treatment policies. I want my one woman show to let people know that they deserve the best treatment that is out there. You shouldn't want to kill yourself while waiting for your prescription, because the entire pharmacy is having lunch at the same time. Your doctor should want to answer your questions; not push them off with comments such as "You shouldn't even be thinking about that right now!" The show will be comedic, but will also (hopefully) let everyone know that just because you have a mental health issue, doesn't mean you deserve anything less than caring, compassionate, and helpful treatment.


Where's The Money Going?

Sure, we have some money in our pockets; unfortunately, it's not enough to cover everything!
Every penny that donors give will go toward production priorities. These include:

- Costume design -
wigs, costumes, make-up, etc

- Set design -
lumber, paint, furnishings, etc

- Venue rental - 
We're planning on having three performance days at two different locations...It costs money, y'all!

- Technical equipment purchases -
mics, projector, screen, memory cards, etc

Other Ways You Can Help

Love the idea, but can't donate? We understand! Just do everyone a solid and tweet it; facebook it; blog it; text it; yell it; shout it from mountain tops; please do everything you can to spread the word so we can hope for funding! Thank you for everything you give and do!

story:
Short Summary

Hello Everyone! My name is Skye LaFontaine and I am a young actor/director here in LA. My sister Liisi and have put up two productions together in the past and decided that our next venture would be a little more ambitious, and because we both love the music of Rent so much, we chose to put our own spin on this well know musical.  I have been studying acting in college for the past three and a half years, but have been in shows as well and creating my own since I was really young. This is my passion, what I want to do with my life, and I want to encourage other young artists to follow their passions and know that they can achieve any goal they set for themselves.  With this campaign, my sister and I have started a new production group called Notascar productions, after a quote of our father's; "Make a mark, not a scar." We want to be able to put on our own productions, the way we want to, and leave a beautiful mark on the artistic community.  With the cuts to the arts programs in schools around the country, we believe that young artists need to be encourage to go out and make their own mark.  My sister and I both attended an arts high school, and even that suffered cuts to some of its programs.  My belief is that children cannot thrive without the arts, and that is why this campaign is so important to me.  I want other artists to see the example we are trying to set here and go out and start their own campaigns and bring the arts back to life.  By contributing, you not only are showing your love and support for the arts, but also to the young artists in our company.  You are showing them that they can accomplish anything they put their minds to, and that what we are making here is truly something unique and special! Our sincerest thanks go out to everyone who donates and supports!!  

What We Need & What You Get

In the past, i have self-produced my shows.  I hired actors, had rehearsal in my basement, scraped money together for a very small theater, as well as doing everything behind the scenes.  My family and friends helped out, but this time we need backers like you all to allow us to expand and grow.  The money we raise is going towards: renting out a theater for a week of tech plus four performance dates, paying a stage manager and a lighting director, acquiring the tools necessary to build sets, rent stage microphones, and pay our musicians and actors.  Our perks are detailed below, but you could get anything from a signed custom made shirt and bracelet to a performance by the cast members at any event you choose! We hope to reach our goal, but if we dont, the funds will still go into production costs, we will scale back a little to accomadate for the money we do raise. 

The Impact

Young artists often feel like they have no say and very few options in the creative process. This project is putting power back in our hands and allowing us to create the opportunities we so despratly yearn for. Notascar is a company dedicated to educating young artists about the impact their work can have on the world. Art makes the world beautiful; it puts music and color into our everyday lives. By donating, you are contributing to the growth of art in this community and around the world. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't make a contribution to our campaign, you can still help by getting the word out!  By telling one other person about our project, you are raising awareness and bringing our cause to light.  Remember that the arts are important, support the arts at your local elementary, middle and high schools. Share this campaign using the indigogo share tools, and come see the show yourself, and see what young artists can do.

story:
The Subtle Body invited to China

Gold No Trade is proud to announce that The Subtle Body has been selected for the Shanghai Dramatic Arts Center's ACT International Theater Festival in November 2013. This is one of the most prominent theater festivals in Shanghai.

The project represents a new level of collaboration between Chinese and American artists: half our actors are from the United States and half are from China. While artistic exchange between the U.S. and China is growing, projects performed by mixed casts are rarely if ever seen.

To make this project possible we need your help.

The good news: We were honored to receive a nationally awarded Global Connections Grant from the Theatre Communications Group (TCG) to support part of this project, but, alas, it will not cover all our expenses.

The better news: We have received a matching grant of $3,500 from Sunrise Medical Group. While they do not practice Chinese medicine, their grant means every dollar you donate will be worth twice as much!

We have until September 2, Labor Day, to make our labor of love and imagination a reality.

We also have some very nice thank you gifts for your donations!

 

The Play

...A dyspeptic British doctor on an all-noodle diet,
...a Chinese doctor practicing pulse diagnosis,
...a British wife discovering multiple marriages, and
...a Chinese translator at the heart of it all.

In this bi-lingual comedy, John Floyer and his wife Charlotte travel to China to research the practice of pulse diagnosis in traditional Chinese medicine. While endeavoring to discover the scientific basis for this technique, Charlotte falls in love with the couple’s already married translator, Wang Ming. It's an 18th century love rectangle, where everyone must confront a foreign interpretation of the human heart.

The play is in English and Mandarin, with surtitles.

Written by Megan Campisi
Produced by Kevin Lapin / Gold No Trade
Directed by Michael Leibenluft
Performed by Patrick Barrett, Ya Han Chang, Megan Hill & Yuekun Wu
Set and Light design by Danica Pantic
Sound design by Mark Van Hare
Costumes by Carrie Wladis
Translations by Grant Zhong
Dramaturgy by Grant Zhong and Peregrine Heard

Gold No Trade would also like to thank Meng Zhang who generously helped arrange interviews with a traditional Chinese medicine practitioner in Shanghai.

The Subtle Body was made possible through generous support from NYC Department of Cultural Affairs and New York State Council on the Arts, Brooklyn Arts Council, Dixon Place, Mud/Bone Collective, and The Nacl Theatre Deep Space Performance Residency Program.

More at www.goldnotrade.com

Our Company

The Gold No Trade theater company is based in Brooklyn, New York. Founded by two performers, Megan Campisi and Kevin Lapin who met at the Lecoq school in Paris, Gold No Trade creates rich new works using simple means. We strip theater down to its most essential, combining language, narrative and striking visual imagery to ignite both passion and intellect.

Gold No Trade is one of the best young companies out there. Absolutely original work;inventive story telling with inventive staging.
–Max Schaefer, Artistic Director, SummerStar Theatre

Read more press on our website at www.goldnotrade.com

Where Your Support Goes

All funds raised go directly to supporting the play:
• Per diems: $35/day for the two-week tour
• Hotel: $85/night for the two-week tour
• Stipends for designers: $250 stipends for set, costume, sound, and lighting designers
• Freight costs for sending our set to China: $750
• Plane tickets for the American actors: $1000 each

Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Join us on facebook
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools or just send an email and tell your friends

And that's all there is to it.

Thank you in advance for your generous support!

--Megan Campisi & Kevin Lapin, co-founders Gold No Trade

story:
Production History

                          INSPIRED ARTS MINISTRY PRESENTS:
                                          'The devil is a Liar'


            

This year's production displays the loss, hurt and frustrations we endure
because we allow the enemy to whisper lies into our ears. It reveals some
of the traps, plots and schemes of the enemy, and how to overcome them.
Believing a lie is what caused the downfall of humanity. The enemy
strategy is  to completely destroy the lives of those who love God.

Inspired Arts Ministry is an outreach organization driven to spread the Gospel of Jesus Christ through the performing arts.  This will be the 5th theater production and the third run of this show! 

The first run of the play attracted many people from all walks of life.  Due to financial limitations the show could only be seen by those who were told by word-of-mouth with very little TV and radio promotion.  Your support will allow the show to be produced on a larger scale and marketed to the masses.

PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD!!  The beauty of the internet is that we can reach many people with a simple "share".  Check out all of the awesome perks and tell everyone you know about the show!


Thank you for your continued support. 


P.S. Visit us at our website: www.inspiredartsministry.com

Facebook: Inspired Arts Ministry

story:
Short Summary

The Byrd Theatre is a beloved Richmond institution and the "go to" destination for $2 second-run movies.  Teenagers, college students, families and the Greater Richmond community patronize the theatre and the surrounding businesses in Carytown.

The Byrd Theatre Foundation relies 100% on fundraising to fulfill our mission. The Foundation needs to replace the old air-cooled chiller, a critical component of the air conditioning system, to Keep the Byrd Humming!

And with a $250,000 challenge grant from The Cabell Foundation, each donation gets us closer to our goal - if we raise $250,000, The Cabell Foundation will give us an additional $250,000!

Background

The Byrd Theatre opened on Christmas Eve, 1928. It straddled the silent film and the talkie eras, and has one of the only working original installation Wurlitzer theatre organs left in the country. Even now, each Saturday night, Bob Gulledge, our theatre organist, plays the Mighty Wurlitzer before the movies.

The Byrd Theatre is on both the Virginia and the National Register of Historic Places. But the Byrd, while a glorious and completely intact example of a Renaissance Revival motion picture palace, is more than just a historic building. It continues to operate as a single-screen movie palace, open 365 days a year. It provides the entire Greater Richmond community with affordable entertainment. It hosts numerous film festivals and non-profit fundraising events. And it serves as the anchor of Carytown, Richmond's very own "Mile of Style," a walkable shopping and dining district dense with locally-owned businesses.

The Byrd Theatre Foundation is a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit entity, dedicated to restoring and preserving the Byrd Theatre as a grand movie palace. We are administered by a very small working Board, and we have no permanent paid staff. We are all volunteers. We have worked extremely hard over the last few years, and have been fortunate to have some significant fundraising successes, such as

  • Meeting the Mary Morton Parsons' $250,000 matching challenge in 2012;
  • Raising funds to replace the boiler (November 2012); and 
  • Purchasing and installing a new digital server (October 2012). 

People assume funds from theatre operations go toward funding the Byrd Theatre Foundation and restoration efforts. This is not correct. Movie operations are a break-even or even money-losing operation.  $2 movie tickets and concessions make enough money to keep the doors open, but no money for capital improvements or a comprehensive restoration.

The Byrd Theatre Foundation's ultimate goal is to raise $5M to completely restore the Byrd Theatre, ensuring that it will be around for generations more to enjoy. But this specific Indiegogo campaign is to raise $100,000 to fix our air conditioning. We are nervous and excited. We have no idea if this will work. But we're hoping, like Sally Fields, that "You really, really like [us]!"

What We Need & What You Get

We need $100,000 to replace a critical component of the Byrd Theatre's air conditioning system, the air-cooled chiller.  The air-cooled chiller was installed in 1966, initially expected to last only 20 years.  Well, it's been working away, cooling the Byrd Theatre, for 47 total years, but it finally died in May 2013.  Wouldn't you know it?  The chiller conked out RIGHT when it gets so hot here in Richmond you absolutely have to have air conditioning.

If we raise the $100,000, this is where the money will go:

  • To purchase a new air-cooled chiller;
  • To design and build a new structural steel support to bear the weight of the new piece of equipment;
  • To install the cooling tower on the roof; and
  • To reimburse the Byrd Theatre Foundation for some of the expense of the temporary chiller, which is costing over $6,000 per month.

And we have some super-cool incentives - at least we think so! - for donors to our Indiegogo campaign.  They include:

  • Limited edition Byrd Theatre "swag," including bumper stickers, T-shirts, and other cool stuff;
  • Free movie tickets for a day, a week, even for life!;
  • The opportunity to sign the chiller before it is installed (“Leave Your Mark”);
  • Tickets to see Cameron Carpenter, the “Bad Boy of the Organ,” play the Mighty Wurlitzer organ during a One Night Only event on October 4, 2013.  If you give enough, you can even meet him at the VIP reception!;
  • Our public show of appreciation with web site and screen recognition; and
  • A private movie screening for 800 of your closest friends!

The Impact

There is another great reason to consider contributing to the Byrd Theatre Foundation's Indiegogo campaign. We recently received another $250,000 challenge grant, this time from The Cabell Foundation. So if we can raise $250,000, the generous folks at the Cabell Foundation are going to give us another $250,000! And believe, me, we have many, many, MANY more capital needs, beyond just the replacement of the chiller. We estimate that our entire restoration campaign will cost approximately $5M. That $5M would allow us to:

  • Pay off the mortgage on the building;
  • Hire the appropriate professionals to advise on and manage the restoration;
  • Upgrade the electrical system;
  • Renovate the bathrooms;
  • Improve handicapped accessibility;
  • Replace the carpet;
  • Repair and restore the Wurlitzer organ;
  • Restore the ornamental plaster and the decorative paintings; and
  • Replace the seats - that means more legroom!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute money, you can still help by sharing this with your friends, family, followers, subscribers and connections! Post it, tweet it, email the link, and leverage your circle’s social power. Any or all will help us Keep the Byrd Humming! And check back regularly, to monitor our progress.

The Byrd Theatre Foundation is always looking for committed volunteers as well.  If you have an interest in contributing your time to one of our Foundation committees, please send your contact information to preserve@thebtf.org.  Let us know what your particular interests might be, and we'll find a way to put you to work.

Thanks for checking out the Byrd Theatre Foundation's campaign here on Indiegogo, and thanks for helping us Keep the Byrd Humming!

Extreme Vision Dance: Zimbabwe

Six young men from the inner city of Harare, Zimbabwe need your help to make their dream of dancing in America come true. Their talent and hard work have gotten them this far; now all they need are the funds to get them to Las Vegas.

Extreme Vision Dance Group has qualified to represent the entire nation of Zimbabwe at this year's Hip Hop International 2013 Competition in Las Vegas, Nevada. This is an opportunity far beyond anything they could have ever hoped for while growing up in the ghetto of Chitungwiza. With no formal education, they see dance as their only way out of this reality. 

Their mentor, choreographer and friend wrote to me explaining that, "Not only do they have no formal education, but they have faced being thrown out onto the street, being orphaned, or living with a single parent who struggles to keep food on the table. They all face the challenge of being unsupported by their families and being continually told that they will never achieve anything or become something and that their lives are worth nothing. Before finding dance, they each had little to no self esteem and yet they are so talented. Going to the US will be an absolute life changing experience; truly their only way out". 

With your support they will be able to attend the Hip Hop International 2013 Competition in August. Here they will have the opportunity not only to compete while representing Zimbabwe, but they will also have the chance to meet industry professionals and like-minded dancers who are just as passionate about their craft. This could mean endless open doors to a future in dance and choreography. This is a future that would never be available to them in their current situation.

With very few avenues available to fund raise in Zimbabwe, we are turning to you, the fantastic global community on the world wide web, to help get them where the deserve to be: competing in Las Vegas.  

What They Need 

Our goal is to raise $30,000 to fund the travel and accomadation needs of the entire group and their managers. This will include flights, hotel and meals for 8 people. 

If we do not reach our goal, all the funds that are raised will still go towards EXV's trip to the Hip Hop International 2013 Competition in August. Every little bit helps and gets them that much closer to a dream come true!

The Impact

With new connections and networks established from their involvement in the Hip Hop International 2013 Competition, these young men will be eqipped with the skills and motivation to return to Zimbabwe and will continue to change their community through dance. They will be able to inspire the next generation of kids to hope for things beyond the day to day struggle of living on the streets. 

They are truly dancing to save lives. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Share their story through social media!

*Facebook 

*Twitter

*Instagram

*Pinterest

How ever you are able to share, get their message out there to help reach our goal! Make as much noise as you can!

Check out all of Indiegogo's tools available to help spread the word. 

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Marjolayne Auger is from Montreal, Canada. She graduated from Conservatoire Lassalle in communications and theatre. She pursued professional theatre studies and then decided to focus on dance. Her BA is in es Arts from UQAM, majoring in dance. Meanwhile she was studying she started to teach argentine tango and to perform for argentine tango orchestras which whom she toured. She adapted as well a version of Romeo and Juliet for the tango orchestra, Flores de Nacar. She studied flamenco in Granada, Spain and Butoh in London, Montreal and New York. Also a certified Hatha Yoga teacher and Reiki healer, she is practicing in the City.

She had the chance to tour in Mexico in the multidisciplinary project Los Angeles de la calle and danced for Danza Corpus in Cuba. She was introduced to Indian dances like Kathak and Baratha Natyam dancing for Manijeh Ali and Aparna Sindhoor. In 2006, she produces her own dance show, Saudade, where she proposed a fusion between tango and argentine folklore movements and contemporary dance.

In New York, she has performed work by Jose Limòn, Sue Bernard, Doris Humphrey, Charles Weidman and Geraldine Cardiel at the Limon Institute’s. She performed for the choreographers for Laura Shapiro, Diego Funes and Yuki Hasegawa. She choreographed for the children theatre show Rikki Tikki Tavi, by Miles Square theatre. She joined the Purring Tiger'sproductions “Water in the desert” and "Mizaru", in residency at BMCC Tribecca.
Her work in New York“Que le vent l’emporte” was presented at the New York Fringe festival 2010. Her solo, “Seed” was shown at Greenspace and she will be showing her new group piece “Contempotango” at Blooms Festival in April, at the same venue. She has been invited to Performatica festival 2012, in Mexico, to teach and perform.She has won the Price for Outstanding Overall Production of one act for SCENE/UNSEEN.

Esquisse will be presented in premiere at the Dumbo Festival, Brooklyn, New York at the end of September. (September 26-29th 2013) Esquisse is the new research project of Juniper theatre dance company.It wil be further developp and presented in Switzerland in the Summer 2014. 

Esquisse is a performance observing the spectrum of human relationships. Throught different tableaux these relationships will be exposed throught different lenses. This work will be very much influenced by the improvisation technique called the Viewpoints. 

 It is better described as physical theatre. Using movements to express the characters's stories, exposing their beauty and poetry throught their attempt to embrace the world. 

The performances will be divided in 3 parts.

1st Act : The Talk

2nd Act : The Dream

3rd Act : The Surprise

The works of Juniper theatre dance company is poetic, engaged, theatrical.

The pictures are taken and generously provided by Kenneth Schwartzman.

The pledge will help to pay the dancers, to pay their costumes and the studio rental fees.Unfortunatly, Dumbo Festival is not able to provide salaries neither stipends this year.

story:
Play Description

Two characters waiting on the train platform, but never get on any regardless how many have passed. Not until another two (who are actors on stage) take off from the train do they finally realize what they are waiting for isn’t the train but actually Pozzo. Inspired by Waiting for Godot, this play will examine the ridicule of the quotidian life, of the artistic life, and raise an unanswerable question: what are we anticipating?
 
Upcoming Train/Stopped Clock/Untitled Waiting is a manifesto of the ritual of waiting, presented by four characters representing the general public and artists. The ritual, addressed upon life/death and reality/illusion, will be practiced by metatheatre and paronomasia within the conversation among the animate beings (characters) and the inanimate beings (mannequins), and further by the embodiment of the sufferings from the ritual itself to accent the timelessness and the ridicule of the action itself.
 

Dennis Yueh-Yeh Li (Director/Playwright/Producer)

Dennis Yueh-Yeh Li earned his MA in Performance Studies at NYU Tisch. He is a performing artist having created productions addressed upon sexuality, cultures, philosophies and political concepts as a director, performer, and playwright in New York and Taipei with an aim to give rise to contemplation on time and space, and create a better life. He is, as well, a writer composing poetry, prose, and short stories dealing with his deliriums in both Mandarin and English. Currently Dennis is the member of The Living Theatre and The Performance Troupe of The Forum Project. His directing credits including his original plays: In Search of Shakespeare, She/Her, and The Trial, and modern plays: Nikita (Piney Fork Press Theatre), Fear of Clowns (Thespian Productions), The Echoes (Adam Roebuck/The AlphaNYC), Marat/Sade, and Six Character In Search of An Author. Other credits include Here We Are (The Living Theatre), Spring Pictures of the Floating World (Peculiar Works Project), What’s In A Name (Theatre Askew), Same River (Strike Anywhere Performance Ensemble), and Kiss Me, so I am Queer (a performance art piece, Chashama).www.dennisyuehyehli.wix.com/dennisyuehyehli

Claire Shang-Ling Kuei (Actor/Producer)

Claire Shang-Ling Kuei graduated from the Educational Theatre Program in NYU Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development in May 2013. She is an actor, theatre artist, poet, and creative writer. She has appeared in Dante’s Inferno (The Brick Theatre, Brooklyn, NY), Macbeth (Pless Hall, New York, NY), The Crucible (Provincetown Playhouse, New York, NY), The Time of the Wolves (Third North Mini Theatre, New York, NY), Eaten Voices (Cabrini Repertory Theatre, New York, NY), Frida (Pless Black Box Theatre, New York, NY). The focuses of her creation as an artist revolves around the topics of femininity, love, death, fear, and human beings.

Mika Yin-Chih Lee (Producer/Stage Manager)

Mika Lee graduated with an M.A degree in NYU drama therapy program in 2012. She continues to apply drama and theatre in school, community and hospital setting. She has been involved in experimental theatre work in Taiwan since 2005. Her past theatre-related experience including actress in Pain (2005), The Galaxy Grew Out Of His Body (2012); director in Walter And Doris (2005); stage manager in Reincarnation (2010); costume design in The Gang (2008), Neglect (2010). As a drama therapist, she believes every piece of art is a research to the ultimate question while every single performance is an act to healing.

Important Notice

Unfortunately, sopport us does not help deducting your tax. But we will be extremely grateful if you are still willing to help us.

Social Meida Links

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/TheatreAfterPozzo?fref=ts

Official Website: http://theatreafterpozzo.wix.com/index

Box Office: http://www.smarttix.com/show.aspx?EID=&showCode=UPC0&BundleCode=&PackageCode=&GUID=46cb108c-883d-49f2-910f-ffbcf1419cec

Twitter: https://twitter.com/AfterPozzo

Tumblr: http://theatreafterpozzo.tumblr.com/

Videos

Director's talk: http://youtu.be/Ppyz_KGsliM
Time Square Fundraising Event: http://youtu.be/P3Vy8HGu_2U

story:
That's right! Your Donation is TAX DEDUCTIBLE!!!

Our Project:

We at Zootopia Theatre Company are absolutely thrilled to be presenting Adam Szymkowicz's THE WHY OVERHEAD, an office comedy about nine-to-fivers left to their own devices when their boss stops coming to work. 

While the boss is away, the workers will play. Karen skips out with her dog and questions the meaning of life.  Donald plots his revenge after being canned. Sid and Alan fight over Jessica, while Annie and Nigel wage an all-out war. Tensions mount as the time clock ticks on, and who knows if Sam will meet his true love or if anyone will figure out the #@?!ing filing system?!

THE WHY OVERHEAD will play September 6-23 at the Access Theater,
380 Broadway (at White St.), 4th Fl, New York, NY.

"Mr. Szymkowicz writes quirky plays about contemporary topics like online dating and gender roles, but there always seems to be something--a knife, a rope, a dead body--in an unexpected place." - The New York Times

"Adam Szymkowicz is a gifted young playwright with an imagination on overdrive..." - Baltimore City Paper

"Zootopia Theatre Company...shows a real affinity for dark-edged, character-driven
comedies that leave the audience thinking as well as laughing." - Backstage

You are the Dream Makers!

It can be very expensive for an independent group of artists to produce original work, even for only a few weeks. That is why we need your support! We are trying to raise $4000 on Indiegogo to help with our costs, but in truth, that only represents a portion of our expenses.  Ensure the success of THE WHY OVERHEAD by helping us meet our funding goal and possibly beyond! Every little bit truly does help and can make all the difference!

Your Participation Makes Possible:

  • Theater & Rehearsal Space: Because we need boards on which to perform!
  • Sets! Lights! Costumes! Props! All the elements that make theater magic!
  • Publicity and Marketing: So people will know when and where to come see us!
  • Artist Fees: We like to pay our artists a little something for their time and talent, though no one is getting rich doing indie theater.  It's a labour of love!

What You Get Out of the Deal:

  • We have a number of cool perks for various levels of support!
  • Did we mention your donation is tax deductible? You can opt to receive rewards for a partial deduction or opt out for a full deduction.
  • Like the Medici Family of old, you can consider yourself a benevolent and generous patron of a young and passionate group of artists.  You're the Dream Makers! We couldn't do it without your support!

Spread the Good News!

Even if you aren't able to contribute to our campaign, you can still support us by sharing our campaign on Twitter and Facebook. E-mail your friends and family! Shout it from the rooftops! We will be!

 

Get Your Tickets!

Tickets are on sale now HERE!

And witness the fruits of our labor and your generosity firsthand at the Access Theater Sept. 6-23! 

Also, check out our website zootopiatheatre.org!

 

THANKS FOR VISITING AND SEE YOU AT THE THEATER!!!

- Matthew J. Nichols & Britney Burgess, Co-Artistic Directors

 

About Zootopia:

We are storytellers.

Zootopia Theatre Company seeks out and produces new stories by original voices that have something unique to say about the way we live in the world. We love stories that contain humor, heart, and a strong narrative focus. Zootopia also provides a professional and supportive environment for emerging artists to collaborate and pursue ongoing relationships while honing their craft. We invite audiences into our zoo to engage them with stories that speak to their humanity and open them up to new ideas and perspectives.

story:
Keeping The Pace

Maybe you have seen Stockton in the news...the first major city in the U.S. to go bankrupt and a city rampant with crime and gang activity?

Well, I grew up in Stockton, and I know that there are also many wonderful characteritistics about the city, including a wonderful history of fostering the fine arts.

My name is Kelly Pace, creator of PACE Dance Company based in Stockton. From small, community dance studios, many dancers and artists of renown have come out of Stockton, and countless others have benefited from having their lives enriched by participating in the arts. 

However, due to the current economic state of Stockton, funding is faltering for the arts in the city and many potential artists are not receiving training. I opened PACE to be a place of dance for the love of it, not for the monetary value. To bring joy and art to those who could not afford it. Because of this, a studio can struggle. That is where we are. I would like to get the studio on solid ground and also support a few underprivileged students throughout the season.

About Pace Dance Studio

PACE Dance Company was established in 2010. We are located at 7273 Murray Dr., Suite 14, Stockton, CA 95210. PACE Dance Company covers all bases in dance types, body types, and age groups. We are ethnically diverse and all are welcome. PACE Dance Studio is also a bully-free environment.

Currently, there are seven instructors, including myself, that operate out of PACE. Each season, there are approximately 50-80 students that take classes at various times of the year. We perform two concerts per year (in December and June) and also perform in the community at large when opportunities present themselves.

What Can You Do?

  • If you are in town, you can join classes or attend concerts. Participation in the arts will help keep Stockton alive and vibrant. You are also welcome to donate to the cause.
  • If you are out of town, you can help support Pace Dance Company through your donations. It's simple. Money makes a difference. We will be so grateful for your contribution and send you one of the perks offered on the right hand side of this page.
  • If you are not able to contribute, we still need your help! Please share our campaign with your friends. Help us spread the word.

That is where we are. I would like to get the studio on solid ground and also support a few underprivileged students throughout the season.


About Pace Dance Studio


PACE Dance Company was established in 2010. We are located at 7273 Murray Dr., Suite 14, Stockton, CA  95210. PACE Dance Company covers all bases in dance types, body types, and age groups. We are ethnically diverse and all are welcome. PACE Dance Studio is also a bully-free environment.
Currently, there are seven instructors, including myself, that operate out of PACE. Each season, there are approximately 50-80 students that take classes at various times of the year.  We perform two concerts per year (in December and June) and also perform in the community at large when opportunities present themselves.



What Can You Do?




If you are in town, you can join classes or attend concerts. Participation in the arts will help keep Stockton alive and vibrant. You are also welcome to donate to the cause.

If you are out of town, you can help support Pace Dance Company through your donations. It's simple. Money makes a difference. We will be so grateful for your contribution and send you one of the perks offered on the right hand side of this page.
If you are not able to contribute, we still need your help! Please share our campaign with your friends. Help us spread the word.

story:
In a Nut-Shell

Having brought the classic holiday ballet to the stage for the past several years, ADI's Nutcracker has become a much anticipated production that sells out weeks in advance. However, ticket sales and participation fees only cover 50% of the many costs associated with bringing this seasonal ballet to life.

We need your support to help make this year's production the best yet! Make a one-time, tax-deductible donation to make the story of Clara and her Nutcracker Prince more magical than ever before. In return, you'll get some unique benefits and perks!

What We Need & What You Get

This campaign will support all production expenses ranging from costumes, set design, and lighting equipment to everything else that happens behind-the-scenes, including the production crew and music rights. Your donation will also support our annual outreach productions of The Nutcracker performed free of charge for Walter Reed Medical Center patients and families living at The Children's Inn at NIH.

For as little as $25, you'll be eligible for awesome rewards including your name in the program, early seating, and reserved seats and parking spots... check on the right for details!

The Impact

Although The Nutcracker seems to be anywhere and everywhere during the holiday season, ADI students and audience members would agree that there is something special about our production. The beautiful yet intimate setting makes for a cherished memory for both students and audiences. Furthermore, ADI has made it a tradition to spread the joy of The Nutcracker to deserving children at Walter Reed and Children's Inn at NIH. Bridget, the Family Program Coordinator at The Inn wrote:

Thank you each so much for continuing the tradition of doing a special performance for the children and families... It can be so difficult for them being away from home this time of year and facing the challenges of their illness-- your kind support in no small way bring much hope and provides a treasured memory for them all.

Every dollar will help us to continue brightening the holidays for not only ADI families, but for those in our community who need it the most!

Post-performance picture with some adorable kids at The Children's Inn at NIH. (Photo courtesy of The Children's Inn)

Spread the Word!

If you've already donated (thank you!) or are unable to do so right now, there are still other ways you can pitch in. Click on any of the sharing options at the top of the page and help spread the word to your friends and family!


Questions? Email cathy@americandance.org

story:
Please check out our update videos by clicking here!
 
Thank you visiting our Indiegogo Campaign!

After six wonderful years, At Hand Theatre Company will be producing its final show, the world premiere of Joshua Conkel's hysterical new play, I Wanna Destroy You. We need your help in raising the $8,000 to complete our budget for this production, and since At Hand is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, all donations are tax-deductible!  
 
Please read about the show below and take a look at the rewards we're offering to donors. Thank you in advance for your support!


ABOUT I WANNA DESTROY YOU 
The Beckett Theatre at Theatre Row  |  May 17 - June 1
Get your tickets here!
Written by Joshua Conkel
Directed by Dan Horrigan
Produced by Matthew DiCarlo and Justin Scribner
Starring Geneva Carr, Jamie Jackson, Anthony Johnston, Preston Martin, Kieran Mulcare, and Kathy Searle
 
 
"But you're not Cinderella. You're one of the woodland creatures who helps her get dressed."

It's June 24th 2011 and as Marriage Equality is being passed in New York State, one gay man is having the worst day of his life. Beau is the personal assistant to the famous (and famously demanding) romance novelist Cecile Collins who is about to get married. When his longtime boyfriend dumps him on his 30th birthday and an old frenemy reappears, Beau is forced to reevaluate his so called life. I Wanna Destroy You is an unlikely romantic comedy that tears the trope of the gay sidekick to shreds.
 
Set Design – David L. Arsenault
Costume Design – Nicole Wee
Lighting Design – Josh Bradford and Daisy Long
Original Music and Sound Design – Anthony Mattana
Stage Manager – Angela F. Kiessel
Casting – Judy Bowman Casting
Press – Ron Lasko, Spin Cycle

At Hand produced two staged readings of I Wanna Destroy You under the direction of Artistic Director Dan Horrigan in 2012, as part of At Hand's Development Series. Previously the show was developed at Ensemble Studio Theatre, The Southampton Writers’ Conference, SPACE at Ryder Farm, and received a reading at Playwrights Horizons through Old Vic/New Voices.  


ABOUT AT HAND THEATRE COMPANY
At Hand Theatre Company is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit company, founded in 2007, whose mission is to develop and produce new plays using sustainable means. At Hand's Development Series has cultivated 20 new works through table readings, staged readings, and workshops. At Hand has also produced Broadway Recycled, an annual Earth Day concert, showcasing songs that were cut from popular musicals.
 
Past productions include the world premieres of As Wide As I Can See and Lila Cante by Mark Snyder, Letters to the End of the World by Anton Dudley, Dan Horrigan's one-man shows My AiDS and The Big A, Brian Dykstra’s Silence!, Andrea Lepcio’s One Nation Under, Jono Hustis’ Cake and Plays... But Without the Cake, and Richard Abrons & Margarett Perry’s The Body Politic, as well as the NY Premiere of Trickster at the Gate by John Patrick Bray.
 
Check out athandtheatre.com for more!
 
Artistic Director:  Dan Horrigan
Executive Director:  Justin Scribner
Managing Director:  Matthew DiCarlo
Executive Assistant:  Angela F. Kiessel
Development Assistant:  Shelley Miles
Associate Producers :  Clay Francis, Laura Wright Leenaars, Sophie Quist
Board of Directors:  Matthew DiCarlo,  Dan Horrigan,  Julia Jolly,  Justin Scribner
Videographer & Editor: Francesca Russell
