story:
Hi! We're The Hoop Unit!

We were conceived by Valentina's brain in 2008 and have been delighting audiences with outside-the-box dance fusion ever since. Valentina is a second-generation belly dancer who was raised in the Los Angeles underground art scene by her mother, Leela, a successful theatrical belly dance icon. She has since become an International Sensation of the Vaudevillian style.

The Hoop Unit combines belly dance, hooping, burlesque, aerial arts and fire dancing into one fused form of expression and entertainment. We have been recognized by Hooping.org as a nominee in the "Performance Group of the Year" Hoopies Awards for 4 years running!

We have been accepted to compete in the "Best Group Category" at the Burlesque Hall of Fame in Vegas, the first weekend of June! This is a huge honor and a true milestone. We have been applying to perform at this event for 3 years! It's finally happening! We need just a little bit of financial help to get us there.

We are excited to be representing Southern California and specifically San Diego's Burlesque community at this international festival. We are also looking forward to bringing Hoop Dance to the Burlesque world! Hooping has changed our lives and we can't wait to rock out with our hoops in front of hundreds of burlesque lovers and performers. We hope someone in that audience will be inspired to pick up a hoop, maybe join the circus :) It could change a few more lives!

Funding Break Down:

$400 for lodging

$200 for travel

$900 for 4 admissions to the BHoF Weekend shows

$400 for costumes

$200 to offset % taken by Indie GoGo and cost to get you your perks!

= $2,300

We have been working our booties off rehearsing and rhinestoning like crazy! We have also been working hard to get ourselves financially able to complete this exciting project. Lots of our sweat, tears, money and energy will be put into this. We are asking for only a little bit of help to get us there. 

Impact:

We hope to gain inspiration from attending the shows at BHoF and we also want to support the Burlesque Hall of Fame organization. Our ticket money to these shows will help keep this non-profit organization thriving. The BHoF's mission is to "inspire, educate and entertain the public, fostering an appreciation for and understanding of the unique history and heritage of vintage American Burlesque–including but not limited to the art, artifacts and personal histories of the art’s biggest names and brightest stars." We believe in that and want to support it!

We will bring back all of the inspiration that we receive from attending the shows and meeting the stars, icons and legends. Valentina is teaching Burlesque classes regularly in San Diego. You can count on her gaining massive inspiration from this experience and sharing it with everyone back home!

We will be constantly updating our Facebook page: http://facebook.com/TheHoopUnit as we go through the weekend journey. We will also be filming it to create a vlog of our experience. We want to keep you in the loop! Subscribe to our YouTube: http://youtube.com/UnityTheGypsyQueen so you know when our BHoF video is up! Also, our blog: http://DanceUniversalLanguage.blogspot.com will have synopsis of our experience. 

Can't contribute? No problem! Please help us spread the word by using IndieGoGo's easy share tools! Maybe someone you know will be able to help! We are eternally grateful for your help, whether it be financial, sharing the project with your network or simply supporting us! Thank you!
story_txt:
Hi! We're The Hoop Unit!
We were conceived by Valentina's brain in 2008 and have been delighting audiences with outside-the-box dance fusion ever since. Valentina is a second-generation belly dancer who was raised in the Los Angeles underground art scene by her mother, Leela, a successful theatrical belly dance icon. She has since become an International Sensation of the Vaudevillian style.

The Hoop Unit combines belly dance, hooping, burlesque, aerial arts and fire dancing into one fused form of expression and entertainment. We have been recognized by Hooping.org as a nominee in the "Performance Group of the Year" Hoopies Awards for 4 years running!
We have been accepted to compete in the "Best Group Category" at the Burlesque Hall of Fame in Vegas, the first weekend of June! This is a huge honor and a true milestone. We have been applying to perform at this event for 3 years! It's finally happening! We need just a little bit of financial help to get us there.
We are excited to be representing Southern California and specifically San Diego's Burlesque community at this international festival. We are also looking forward to bringing Hoop Dance to the Burlesque world! Hooping has changed our lives and we can't wait to rock out with our hoops in front of hundreds of burlesque lovers and performers. We hope someone in that audience will be inspired to pick up a hoop, maybe join the circus :) It could change a few more lives!
Funding Break Down:
$400 for lodging
$200 for travel
$900 for 4 admissions to the BHoF Weekend shows
$400 for costumes
$200 to offset % taken by Indie GoGo and cost to get you your perks!
= $2,300
We have been working our booties off rehearsing and rhinestoning like crazy! We have also been working hard to get ourselves financially able to complete this exciting project. Lots of our sweat, tears, money and energy will be put into this. We are asking for only a little bit of help to get us there. 
Impact:
We hope to gain inspiration from attending the shows at BHoF and we also want to support the Burlesque Hall of Fame organization. Our ticket money to these shows will help keep this non-profit organization thriving. The BHoF's mission is to "inspire, educate and entertain the public, fostering an appreciation for and understanding of the unique history and heritage of vintage American Burlesque–including but not limited to the art, artifacts and personal histories of the art’s biggest names and brightest stars." We believe in that and want to support it!
We will bring back all of the inspiration that we receive from attending the shows and meeting the stars, icons and legends. Valentina is teaching Burlesque classes regularly in San Diego. You can count on her gaining massive inspiration from this experience and sharing it with everyone back home!
We will be constantly updating our Facebook page: http://facebook.com/TheHoopUnit as we go through the weekend journey. We will also be filming it to create a vlog of our experience. We want to keep you in the loop! Subscribe to our YouTube: http://youtube.com/UnityTheGypsyQueen so you know when our BHoF video is up! Also, our blog: http://DanceUniversalLanguage.blogspot.com will have synopsis of our experience. 
Can't contribute? No problem! Please help us spread the word by using IndieGoGo's easy share tools! Maybe someone you know will be able to help! We are eternally grateful for your help, whether it be financial, sharing the project with your network or simply supporting us! Thank you!

story:
FRAGGLED PRODUCTIONS - URINETOWN (The Musical)

  • Fraggled Productions is a company of recent college graduates who are striving to make their voices heard through relevant and inspiring theater productions in Los Angeles.
  • The company had past success with Reefer Madness the Musical last year and is coming together again to knock LAs socks off! See our pictures from a dress rehearsal of Reefer Madness!
  • Our next venture is URINETOWN the musical! In order to get anything up and running we first need your help with the royalty fees to secure our contract for the show!
  • You will help us get on our feet for our first Los Angeles production!
  • We are a passionate and dedicated group who create exciting pieces together using our combined perspectives, opinions, aesthetics, and talents to communicate a play's important message to the world. AND WE NEED YOUR HELP.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need the $3000 royalty fee that goes to MTI for the rights to URINETOWN the musical. This is our first push to the public for help funding our show. We just need the rights at this moment, and we're asking for your help!
  • Our contract with MTI expires JUNE 14th. We cannot book the theater space or start rehearsing until we've gotten the music librettos and scripts!
  • And we have perks for your generous folks that donate! For each amount you donate there will be prizes ranging from:
    • Any contribution - a shoutout in the program
    • $25 - poster of the show
    • $50 - poster signed by the cast
    • $100 - signed cast photo & poster
    • $250 - nods in our promo videos (name dropping at it's finest. Don't you want to be on the internets?)
    • $500 - a pair of tickets to the show & a nod in the video
  • If we do not reach our entire goal, any money that we can raise goes directly to MTI. And the rest we will have to scrounge up by doing unspeakable acts on the streets of Los Angeles.

Your Contribution Will Make a Huge Difference in this Show Even Happening -

In this economy the first thing to suffer are the arts. There's no money or time anymore. But there is a human interest and need for the arts, especially live theater.

There is nothing like watching another person, right in front of you, experiencing emotions that we all share. Participating in the life events of a character the audience has come to love is the reason we still go to the theater.

The young people of this world have unique perspectives to share, and they should be able to get that chance, no matter what the economy looks like.

Let us share that with you and the world.

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out! Make some noise about this to everyone you know!

Put it on your Facebook and Twitter! Be a part of making this a reality!

story:
The Play

The Dunne family struggles with how to handle a house haunted by memories and a parent struggling to hold onto them. Family bonds remain even in the darkest of deeds.

A dramatic magical story about family, home and the end of life.

What you need money??? For what???

Oh so many things.starving artists are no joke. In order to get ahead many playwrights produce their own work with big hopes and dreams and big... bills...so here we go...

Rehearsal space, festival fees, programs, transportation, props, printing, marketing, lighting, sound, acting, stage management

And maybe most important... The Planet Connections Theatre Festivity is about raising money and awareness for charity. The Home will be benefiting the Alzheimer's Association and a portion of all money raised will go directly to support the work that they do with local chapters throughout the country.

Learn more about the Alzheimer's Association here:
http://www.alz.org/index.asp

The Players

Gabrielle Fox-Playwright
Anthony Valbiro-Director
Charles Baran-Artie
Petra Denison-Melanie
Margie Ferris-Margaret
Misti Tindiglia-Mom

The Crew

Charlotte Exton-Stage Manager
Lise Prown-Graphics
Diana Rusu-Video
Claudia Toth-Board Operator
Anthony Vincent Valbiro-Sound Designer

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Repost, retweet, tell your friends, tell the press, shout from the rooftops!
  • Come to the show!

Venue: Upstairs Theater, Paradise Factory, 64 E 4th Street, NY, NY

Schedule: 
Thursday, May 22 at 4:00pm
Saturday, May 24 at 7:00pm
Tuesday, May 27t at 9:00pm
Thursday, May 29 at 9:00pm
Saturday, May 31 at 6:30pm
Sunday, June 1 at 11:30am

https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pr/933567

story:
What We're Doing

Pipeline Theatre Company opens its 4th season with the world premiere of Colby Day's Giant Killer Slugs, part of the Theater for the New City's Dream Up! Festival. 

Giant Killer Slugs is a creature feature written for the stage, complete with a small town sheriff trying to leave his troubles behind, an unscrupulous mayor in cahoots with the crooked BusinessCorp, a pack of city slicker kids who know the truth no one wants to believe, and of course, killer slugs that keep getting bigger!

 

Who We Are

PIPELINE THEATRE COMPANY is a downtown Manhattan-based non-profit theater company, comprised of 21 emerging actors, directors, writers and designers. Pipeline makes theater of the imagination and hopes to produce stories that stick somewhere in your heart, your brain, or your guts.  Productions include: Timberlake Wertenbaker's The Love of the Nightingale, Tim Chawaga's Sleepless City (World Premiere), Psycho Beach Party, Alex Mills' Shakespeare the Dead (World Premiere, 2010 Dream Up Fest at Theater for the New City), Bekah Brunstetter's Fat Kids on Fire (directed by Tony nominee Peter Frechette), The Caucasian Chalk Circle (Winner! 2011 NYIT Awards for Original Music, Cormac Bluestone - Composer, and Nominated for 2011 NYIT Award for Lighting Design), Colby Day's Felix & The Diligence (World Premiere) and most recently, Timberlake Wertenbaker's The Ash Girl.

Our Brave New Works, whisper & SHOUT, and Hung Up series, produced in tandem with our mainstages, develop and support adventurous original material and deepen connections with our ever expanding network of artists.

 

The Impact

Pipeline prides itself on our collectivity and the empowerment of our peers by offering the opportunity for full-scale, fully funded, fully organized and realized Off-Off Broadway productions.

Pipeline makes theater of the imagination. We thrive on adventure and believe no story is worth telling without a little risk. With Giant Killer Slugs you can help us take one of our most imaginative and adventurous strides yet as we attempt the impossible and stage a movie.

 

What We Need

In-line with our mission of delivering imaginative adventures, we have a big and boisterous production envisioned. This is one of our most ambitious productions to date and in order to make it happen, we need $8,000 by August, $2,500 of that will come from this campaign. 

Your contribution will go to support floor to ceiling film projections, an original rockabilly score, and 20-foot slug puppets! 

Need another incentive? We recently filed our 501(c)3 paperwork and now all of your donations are tax-deductible (minus the value of your chosen perk)!

 

Any amount, big or small is greatly appreciated and incredibly helpful! 

 

Thank you for helping to make this wonderful show a reality!                 

-The Giant Killer Slugs Team 

www.pipelinetheatre.org

 

**To claim your ticketing perk or special snack, e-mail aschrier@pipelinetheatre.org for verification and availability. **Must be chosen as a perk through IndieGoGo

story:
Why do some nations forbid women and homosexuals to go to war?

How does war lift sexual taboos?

Does media proximate us to or further distance us from the enactment of violence?


Breaking and Entering is an immersive performance work blending theatre and installation art being developed by Masters students and alumni of California Institute of the Arts. Our goal is to explore the relationship between war, sexuality and pornography, media, and that way we have of playing out conflict in our minds like Sunday’s cartoon strips.

Artist Arjuna Neuman will present an installation - in response to an original text conceived by Kestrel Burley - which will culminate in a weekend of performances devised from the same text. An ensemble of performers will incorporate Neuman’s environmental elements as “characters” in a series of vignettes, transforming the installation from a purgatorial space with the threat of action - into a theatrical space - a place of action.

Breaking and Entering will take place at Human Resources in downtown Los Angeles, 22-27 May, and also as part of the California Institute of the Arts New Works Festival, 11 May.


“I make theatre because I assume that our world needs willing mouths to risk having our teeth kicked in and our tongues cut off - willing to swallow every experience in order to paint a picture with our spit, and willing to go hungry trying. It is the ripe opportunity for collaboration, experimentation, and expansion in Los Angeles that has made me fall in love with this community. The city’s sidewalks bulge and crack with the eruptions of old tree roots and soil, and its veneer is showing dire need of an overhaul. I have never felt the movement of roots anywhere as strongly as right here, underneath a bedazzling veil of vanity - our human fear of mortality - and my skin feels tender to where I have to (literally) act so as not to burst myself. I want to crack this city wide open.”                                                 

Kestrel Burley

Director  

                                                                                                                

“As a visual artist the opportunity to cross disciplines doesn't arise as much as is believed. Working with a theatre troupe as well as a production team has not only opened me up to a discipline that has collaboration at its core, but it has also been inspiring for my own personal work. As an installation artist concerned with space and environment, it seems natural, but also challenging, to apply my craft within a different context and history. I am learning a new way to talk and think about theatre, as well as my own practice, that is radically different from my training as a visual artist. I think these moments of opening up and learning from a different point of view are essential, and exactly what makes interdisciplinarity important.” 


Arjuna Neuman

Installation Artist

 

As an independently produced but professional-quality work, we need your support in order to make a true impact on the Los Angeles community. $1,700 of support is needed. The show must go on whether we meet our fundraising goal or not, but every donation will bring us closer to realizing the full potential of this project. If we exceed our goal, those funds will help us continue the next stage of development and take Breaking and Entering to a wider audience. And each donation of $5 or more gets you perks - from original music and artwork to music lessons and DJ services!

After you donate, please share our page with your art-loving and conscious-living friends through the indiegogo share tools. And please rest assured, if you do not wish to be contacted again, let us know and we will honor all such requests!

story:
My Story

Howdy, y'all. My name is Evangeline and I am an actress, musician, writer and producer. I am creating a new project entitled Chrysalis which explores the intersection of grief and growing up using storytelling, song, movement, and chocolate cake. 


The content of the show is personal to me, and it has taken me several years to develop. In 2004, my brother was killed in an accident. This coincided with the end of my freshman year in college. This show has been rolling around in my subconscious ever since then, and I am overjoyed to finally feel ready to take this tragedy and transform it into something beautiful that is, at times, funny. 


I hope that this show will allow my audience an opportunity to reflect on their own unique experiences of loss in a way that transcends mere sadness.

The Impact

The money I receive from this campaign will enable me to produce Chrysalis this August in the San Francisco Bay Area, and then to tour the show to two theater festivals; New Orleans Fringe Festival and Frigid New York. I believe that addressing loss is incredibly important in the context of a culture where our grieving rituals are sorely limited, and that is precisely what my show will do. The idea of "grieving" is often only acknowledged in the immediate loss of a person, by cards and flowers and a short ceremony. Any other public acknowledgement of loss makes people feel uncomfortable. 


Chrysalis is special because, through the abstract performance languages of movement, song, storytelling, and clowning, it creates the space for a public acknowledgement of the long-term impacts of loss in a way that is otherwise rare.

What We Need & What You Get

Through careful consideration of production and touring costs, my co-pilot Ben Prusiner and I have arrived at a fundraising goal of $3,000. This money will pay for:

1) The props and set

2) Festival entrance and administration costs

3) Rehearsal Space for the development of the show

4) Travel costs to for the various tour locations.


Any donation will be tax-deductible because I am fiscally sponsored through Fractured Atlas, a non-profit organization. There is a list of perks for various donation levels and ultimately your support for this show will help me realize my vision.


Other Ways You Can Help

1) Donate! Even a small amount will help me to reach my goal.

2) Tell your friends! If anyone you know may be interested in supporting this project, please pass this page along to them. 

3) I am also seeking technical theater support for the Bay Area run of the show. If you would like to aid in ticket taking, lighting design, or board-op for the Bay Area run, lemme know!

4) This campaign is also on facebook: facebook.com/solochrysalis

story:
Aftermath

 

It's not the storm itself—wind and rain lashing shore,

uprooting trees, toppling poles and dousing lights,

flooding cellars and roads, capsizing boats—

but the aftermath—the bright calm, the pair

of drowned cats crumpled against the picket fence,

the parlor of Izzy's shack open for inspection,

the walls fallen flat on all sides, your own

roof filling the front yard, covering your car,

and your own twin daughters dazed by Nature's

petulance—that makes you reconsider

your life and weigh your possessions and the cost

of putting down stakes too near the coast

as the globe warms, and storms grow worse.

- George Held



Almost Home


A tribute to flood victims worldwide

Featuring an international cast of actors from

Australia, Germany, Macedonia, and the United States




In 2008, when Hurricane Ike hit Galveston, Ward Studio Company Director, Wendy Ward turned to her intern and said, “Let’s build a show that will benefit the people of Galveston,” and a few weeks later, the show was born.  Audiences remarked on the good humor, depth and sensitivity of the show which captivated audiences.


"It amazes me that within a few weeks of Hurricane Ike, a committed director named Wendy Ward, a small ensemble of actors-in-training and a handful of theatre technicians, could put together this incredibly powerful multi-media work that is authentic and of the highest artistic quality.... there are moments in Almost Home that seem to pop out of nowhere and channel the voices of the people and history of Galveston and demand: 'Look at us. Listen. In this tragedy, we are one. We are you.'


I only wish that this show could be taken to Texas where it would both act as a voice for those dispossessed... It would be both enlightening and a profound catharsis, an act of healing."

 

TOM JOHNSON, of the Texas Faculty Association    

 

In January of this year, Ms. Ward was working in Melbourne, Australia when perilous floods left most of the state of Queensland and its population in ruin. Since then, floods have continued to devastate other communities around the world, making this an appropriate time for us to rebuild Almost Home and tour it to flood ravaged areas.

 

The show opens this Thanksgiving in Philadelphia, PA (USA) where all proceeds will benefit the American Red Cross and St. Mary’s Chapel, whose sanctuary we have converted into a theatre for our season.

 

But we have even more exciting plans in store for this unique production.  You can help Almost Home travel to Australia in time to mark the one-year anniversary of Hurricane Yasi and the Australian floods. Your contribution will help us get there.




wardstudiocompany.com


Company Members

Cazz Bainbridge, Christopher Chung, Sophie Cole, Leah Costello,

Petra Glieson, Scott O'Halloran, Mel Orpen, Xavier O'Shannessy,

Kliment Poposki, Eben Rojter, Ryan Rickenbach,

Linda Schapley, Gianmarco Soresi, Lena Taege


Company Director
Wendy Ward
story_txt:
Aftermath
 
It's not the
storm itself—wind and rain lashing shore,
uprooting
trees, toppling poles and dousing lights,
flooding
cellars and roads, capsizing boats—
but the
aftermath—the bright calm, the pair
of drowned
cats crumpled against the picket fence,
the parlor of
Izzy's shack open for inspection,
the walls
fallen flat on all sides, your own
roof filling
the front yard, covering your car,
and your own
twin daughters dazed by Nature's
petulance—that
makes you reconsider
your life and
weigh your possessions and the cost
of putting
down stakes too near the coast
as the globe
warms, and storms grow worse.
- George Held


Almost
Home

A tribute

story:
YOU DID IT! WE DID IT!

THANK YOU to ALL WHO HELPED US REACH OUR GOAL!

Our time together in Boulder was truly rich.  Over the course of our week long residency, we brainstormed like crazy, took mountains of notes, worked late into the early morning hours to get at the heart of what we are, what we're doing, and how we're going to continue. 

In addition, we engaged with 25 middle and high school students from Watershed School's art and photography classes.  In these workshops, Gabriela talked about the photographer's relationship to movement as they work. Students used stage directions and elements of dance to create simple improvisational structures, comparing how visual artists and dancers think about space, movement and composition.  It was super dynamic.  

In this video, made after our residency by Gabriela and Denisse, you'll see a glimpse of our time together.  Thank you, again, for helping us get started!

in english and español:




NEXT STEPS:

  • establishing fiscal sponsorship and a cohesive fundraising plan
  • creating our blog
  • planning 2015 residencies

STAY TUNED!

Chicken Bank Collective

Tejiendo comunidades entre fronteras a través del arte del movimiento.

Weaving communities across borders through the art of movement.



our campaign


Chicken Bank Collective, a group of artists who have worked together enough to know we want to work together for a good long time.

Who We Are and What We're Up To: 

Zap McConnell (North Carolina, USA), Gabriela Bosquenegro (Cholula, Puebla, Mexico), Denisse Cardenas Landeros (Mexico City, Mexico), Paola Suculima De La Concha Zindel (Cholula, Puebla, Mexico), Cinthia Pérez Navarro (Cholula, Puebla, Mexico), Julie Rothschild (Boulder, Colorado, USA) and
Amanda Martin (Athens, Georgia, USA).

We are Chicken Bank Collective, 7 Women, Dancers, Choreographers, Visual Artists and a Filmmaker, coming together from different states and countries to make films, perform dances, and engage in community service and public art.  The Chicken Bank is literally and figuratively where we collect our resources, be it money, time or sewing skills.  Once it's in the bank, it belongs to the collective. 



At this moment, we are in the start up phase of creating this international dance and art collective.  We will soon have fiscal sponsorship and then non-profit status, meaning all donations will be tax deductible. 

In the meantime, we have our first gathering coming up in Boulder, Colorado. 

During our inaugural meeting, we are going to get down and dirty and into the nitty gritty of what it is going to take to make this collective a sustainable reality. 

  • How do we do this?  Scheduling, funding, planning, generating audience and reaching out to our communities.   All things we have done independently, and now seek to do so collectively. 
  • What do we then bring to each others' communities and how does our collective voice reach beyond the confines of our borders? 
  • Giving back to our communities, making art that we feel has an impact on how we treat each other, ourselves and our environments is essential to us.  

While the world of arts funding isn't looking so plentiful, and hasn't in quite some time, we are more certain than ever that we must continue to make art, to perform, to teach, to get kids involved in the arts and to encourage creative expression.  We are gathering in order to support each others' visions, to hold each other up, to be honest, to make work that we believe in.  Your financial support will help us collaborate in person and work collectively to inspire others through
dance, art and film.

In Boulder, we have a great opportunity to participate in the public art project "Around the Bend."  Zap and Julie were just awarded a grant by the City of Boulder to create a public art installation that aims to give people a new look at how they move between point A and point B, and what they encounter in the midst.  We are inviting residents of Boulder County to join us as we explore this question.
Here's more on the project: AROUND THE BEND. 
 

Our vision for our future: we want to meet and work together 2-3 times a year.  We will all take turns hosting and directing projects in our home towns in Colorado, Georgia, North Carolina and in Mexico, as well as in additional locations around the world where we can reach into our combined network of amazing artists to
bring our ideas to fruition.  


What We Need and How You Can Help

For those of you who have supported us as individual artists in the past, we invite you to help us take these early steps and stay afloat during this start up phase.  $3000 will get us rolling.  To be able to continue to work together in person is a significant financial challenge, but one we believe is worth the effort.

Your support in any amount helps us take this leap of faith.

Whatever it is that you can do to help us get going, a small donation, a BIG donation, a shout out to your art loving friends or a simple word of support, we extend our appreciation.  And we hope that Chicken Bank Collective can come to
your community in the very near future.

With Gratitude,

        Amanda Martin  

   Gabriela Bosquenegro  

                                  Cinthia Pérez Navarro 

   Denisse Cardenas Landeros 

                                                   Zap McConnell  

  Paola Suculima De La Concha Zindel

                            Julie Rothschild  

There is always a chance that we won't reach our goal of $3000.  If that happens, we will act frugally, as we are already well versed at, and stretch each dollar to it's fullest extent.  And if more than our goal comes in, it goes into the Chicken Bank!

story:
Short Summary

Hi, My name is Joy Naik and I am the President of an organization that is forming into a non-profit called A Time To Dance.  What started off as just a show to say thank you to the Military Community for the sacrifices that they make everyday is now becoming an organization who not only wants to tour stateside and to bases overseas but would also provide dance scholarships.  A mother of three and a Military Spouse of nine years I have already gone through six moves with two of them being overseas. 



 When living in Rota, Spain and teaching dance as a MWR Community Classes Instructor I saw a couple of things. I saw military children who had such a huge talent and passion for dance but their career as a dancer was even more uncertain than the norm because they had to constantly be moved around just to keep their families together and there was no guarantee that they would have a good dance teacher let alone a studio were they could nurture their talents. I saw spouses who wanted to dance but figured that with the kids and traveling that they had to give it up but if they could be given the proper chance they would get right back on that stage.  I saw people in the military who even though had committed to serving and protecting the United States of America wanting to still practice their skills in the art form of ballet and jazz. I had students fresh out of boot camp, sent overseas as their first duty station and when they could've been out with everyone else they were with me practicing for hours in the studio. Or they made sacrifices to come to class during their lunch break just so they wouldn't miss a chance to keep growing in dance.


(He's now a PS2!!)


Dancing has been my passion in life for the last 21 years and now it is such an honor to be able to blend it with the Military Community.  Contributing to this campaign is going to help us bring our inspiring shows, workshops as well as scholarships to a community who has at least one family member who is willing to make the Ultimate Sacrifice for our nation.

What We Need & What You Get

Ever since our premiere las year things have been moving fast.  We are now producing two more shows.  The Holiday Extravaganza for December and the Redeemed Dance Project during the month of April.  Being that we are all freelance artists from various studios the money that we receive will go towards the following:

$6,100 Artist Compensation (this is just the amount for one show; we have over 36 dancers for the one in September)

$4,800 Practice Space (this amount will get us through December)

$4,500 Costumes (to keep in our repertoire for all three shows)

$2,000 Dance Floor (we need a proper portable dance floor)

$450 Video/Audio Editing (this goes to one person and it's more than I am able to pay each of the dancers)

$400 Lighting/Sound Technician (this is on the cheap side and would love to be able to pay them more!)

If we don't reach our goal the money that we do bring in will go towards the floor and costumes.

(Here are our some of our teens performing last year at the Norfolk Navy Exchange. We are so thankful to Academie de Ballet in Chesapeake for allowing us to use their floor and costumes) 

Please read about all of the uniques Perks that we have for everyone willing to support our mission!

The Impact

A Time To Dance the show premiered on September 11th, 2013. The day was chosen because to be able to give back to the Military community on a day like that would just be such an honor.  To be able to say thank you with our gifts and talents on such a day would be a dream come true.

(Intro)

The name comes from two other areas that I love.  My faith and the good ol' oldies. You can either take it straight from Ecc. 3 or from "The Byrds" singing it but really it is because on a day that we were supposed to be torn down as a nation, left in ruins, meant to be scared and to be broken, I wanted to take it and remind us that we are stronger than that. We are so strong that we can take the emotions from that day, our emotions as a military child, our emotions as a military spouse and our emotions of being a part of the American Armed Forces and use it as our time to dance. Which is a time to show ourselves and the world that we can dance and keep moving through whatever life may throw at us.  That our spirit cannot be broken.  It was with that passion and that mindset that I went forth and put together the show from the time it came into my mind to the time it was finished in 2 1/2 months.  And it is with the same that I am continuing it and hoping to make it bigger.  But I am not alone in this because if I was then our group wouldn't have grown this year and according to the feedback from the theatre the audience is expected to quadruple in size which is why we are adding in more shows!

(Our finale "Wavin' Flag", everyone that you see volunteered to be a part of a show that has never been done before because they believed in it's mission.  Not one person said let me think about it, they all wanted to know when practice started.)


    Risks & Challenges

    Our first show was a little bit easier in some ways.  Since it was in September we had a space to practice since most dance studios were only providing class in the morning/early afternoon time frame.  When Fall comes around and school starts it is going to be hard to find a place to practice. Also, not knowing that it was going to be more than just a one time show we were graciously given costumes and a dance floor to borrow. Doing more shows means that we need our own costumes and floor.  Having to borrow is not an option for us this year and to rent space is something that without your help is not in our budget.  We really need your help.

    (ATTD younger dancers rolling out the floor in New Bedford, Mass!)

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you aren't able to financially support our campaign we would love it if you could help us spread the word about who we are! You can find us on Facebook as A Time To Dance USA or go to atimetodanceusa.com to learn more. On Twitter we are @atime2dance_usa.  Also please use the Indiegogo share tools as well if you know of anyone who might be interested!

      (SrA Bryant B.True Anderson, USAF)

      Thank you so much for your support!!

story:
Bois franc et langues fourchues : Nous sommes un collectif de jeunes artistes de théâtre de Québec et nous produisons la pièce Dans le bois de David Mamet.

Au théâtre Premier Acte à Québec, du 16 septembre au 4 octobre, le grand public sera convié à un spectacle intime, en arène, pour partager l’histoire d’amour d’un jeune couple au seuil du précipice, avec toute la passion et la fougue qui les transportent.

Nous, Danielle Le Saux-Farmer, André Robillard, Karine Mecteau-Bouchard, Jean-Denis Beaudoin et Alexandra Gendron, membres de Bois franc et langues fourchues, brûlons d’impatience de partager ce premier travail collectif. Un texte plein de poésie et de mystère du grand David Mamet.

Le concept 

La pièce a été écrite en 1977 pour un couple homme-femme, et nous prenons le pari de la jouer cette fois avec Nick et Antoine, un couple homosexuel. Ce choix reflète notre désir d’inscrire une histoire de couple homosexuel dans l’imaginaire collectif du public de théâtre, sans partir d’un texte qui portait cette thématique en elle à l’origine. Nous sommes aussi intéressés par la notion d’acceptation d'une identité sexuelle, et la manière dont ça peut influencer nos relations.

Nous nous interrogeons activement à travers ce projet aux questions de « normalité » au sein d’un couple, de genre comme construction sociale et d’identité sexuelle.

Les droits d'auteur

Les droits d’auteur représentent notre plus grande dépense. Le budget a été conçu en fonction des droits de 2000$, et nous avons fixé notre objectif de financement pour payer ces droits. Les autres revenus de la production nous permettrons de réaliser une scénographie simple et épurée, adaptée au théâtre en arène, ainsi que les costumes, et l’ensemble de la publicité.  

Le public 

Dans le bois est un projet de théâtre qui va rejoindre un public de tous les âges, et en particulier, on l'espère, les jeunes. En racontant l’histoire de Nick et Antoine, on veut augmenter, à notre manière, la visibilité de la diversité sexuelle au théâtre. 

De plus, le grand texte de Mamet mérite d’être entendu ici, car il explore avec poésie la complexité des relations humaines, et le fragile équilibre entre nos attentes en amour et celles des autres. 


Équipe de création

Traduction: Rosemarie Bélisle

Mise en scène :   Danielle Le Saux-Farmer

Interprétation :   André Robillard et Jean-Denis Beaudoin

Scénographie :   Karine Mecteau-Bouchard 

Éclairage :   Alexandra Gendron

Environnement sonore :   Simon Hains

poésie et de mystère du grand David Mamet.
Le concept La
pièce a été écrite en 1977 pour un couple homme-femme, et nous prenons le pari
de la jouer cette fois avec Nick et Antoine, un couple homosexuel. Ce choix
reflète notre désir d’inscrire une histoire de couple homosexuel dans
l’imaginaire collectif du public de théâtre, sans partir d’un texte qui portait
cette thématique en elle à l’origine. Nous sommes aussi intéressés par la notion
d’acceptation d'une identité sexuelle, et la manière dont ça peut influencer nos relations.
Nous
nous interrogeons activement à travers ce projet aux questions de « normalité » au sein d’un couple, de genre comme construction sociale et
d’identité sexuelle.
Les droits d'auteur
Les
droits d’auteur représentent notre plus grande dépense. Le budget a été conçu
en fonction des droits de 2000$, et nous avons fixé notre objectif de financement pour payer ces droits. Les autres revenus de la production nous
permettrons de réaliser une scénographie simple et épurée, adaptée au théâtre
en arène, ainsi que les costumes, et l’ensemble de la publicité.  
Le public 
Dans le bois est
un projet de théâtre qui va rejoindre un public de tous les âges, et en particulier, on l'espère, les jeunes. En racontant l’histoire de Nick et Antoine, on veut augmenter,
à notre manière, la visibilité de la diversité sexuelle au théâtre.  
De
plus, le grand texte de Mamet mérite d’être entendu ici, car il explore avec
poésie la complexité des relations humaines, et le fragile équilibre entre nos
attentes en amour et celles des autres. 
Équipe de création 

Traduction: Rosemarie BélisleMise en scène :   Danielle Le Saux-Farmer
Interprétation :   André Robillard et
Jean-Denis Beaudoin
Scénographie :   Karine Mecteau-Bouchard  
Éclairage :   Alexandra Gendron
Environnement
sonore :   Simon Hains

story:
Who We Are: The Silk Stocking Sirens

The Silk Stocking Sirens consist of five beautiful ladies: Dahlia Vee, Rachel Riot, Adele Vice, Nikki St Sin, and Euphoria Harlot. From various backgrounds and stage experiences, we have come together to create empowering, fun, and thought provoking burlesque shows in Raleigh, North Carolina.

As a new troupe in a city where there are many, we need your help to 

  • help us expand the love of burlesque beyond the regular burlesque hotspots and ease into the mainstream community
  • help us market our art! Besides performing, we teach empowering burlesque and pinup classes where women can express and empower themselves through dance, movement, and creative makeup and character play
  • increase our production value. We are a small group of only five! We don't have a large production budget, yet it takes money to develop props, costuming, and choreography. 


Our Mission

To bring the classic art of burlesque to new audiences and empower women through the celebration of female sensuality.

We believe beauty has no size, age, or gender requirements. We strive to find the beauty in each person who comes to our shows and to help them realize their own beauty through burlesque and pin-up workshops.

    As a small cast, our performers dedicate a full time work load to rehearsals on top of their regular jobs and school.  After we take care of our performers and expenses-- there's not much left over for show expansion and promotion.

    Through your support we will be able to take the steps to bring the show to the next level of AWESOME!

     Funds will be used for a variety of purposes but most importantly our goals are: 

     1. Bring amazing burlesque performers from outside the Triangle, right here-- to you!

    2. Create and build reusable set pieces that can be used for all future shows to further envelop the audience in the stories we try to tell.  

    3. Work with our fantastic group choreographer for improved dance and agility  AND generally continue to increase the overall production value of future shows.


    We know not everyone can help-- hey, no big deal! If you can't help monetarily, we can always use help with marketing, stage kittening, and being our mailing list hottie!

story:
Hi Everyone!

Thank you so much for taking the time to check out our campaign and show your support.

THE PLAY

Rum and Cookies is an original play written by Matt Mancuso which he will be the lead in alongside Pamela Portnoy. It will be directed by Hunter C. Smith. It is the story of two best friends coming together for what they think will be a really great night of drinking and reminiscing, but they eventually learn that there is more between them than they were willing to acknowledge.

THE MISSION

For many years, the three of us have been studying acting and learning different skills to use both onstage and offstage. We have been working hard both individually and together as a group to further our knowledge of the world of theater and film. Now, we want share our hard work, talent, and creativity with you! The money raised in this campaign will be used to launch this new play and to get our unique voices heard by the world, that's you! We believe that art is something everyone should not only get to witness but also be a part of, and with your help we can all make this work of art come to life. We hope to give all of you, an experience you will never forget.  

WHAT WE NEED

We put a deposit down on a wonderful space that itself cost $4,500. We are looking to raise that amount, plus an extra $1,500 more to help promote the project, build a set that rivals a Broadway show, and provide every attendee with a completely immersive experience the second they walk through the door.

This project has been two years in the making and we are passionate about this play. Pam and Matt have already given two readings of Rum and Cookies, and have received wonderful responses from the viewers. Not to mention that the second that Hunter read the script, he decided he wanted to be apart of it and help bring it to life. 

FUN AND PERKS

We cannot thank you enough for your contribution and support, which is why we have set up many different thank you gifts for whatever amount you give. From a shout out through social media, to a signed photograph of the cast, to a dinner with the cast and director, we have many ways of saying thank you. Any amount of money you can donate to this project will be appreciated! This production will be the inaugural production of a new non-for-profit theatre company, so those of you who are generous enough to donate $1,000 will also reach patron status with the company and get all the perks that come with that.

Just so everyone knows, this is just the first production we plan on producing. We have many more ideas that we want to bring to life! We love theatre and we believe that its purpose is not only to entertain, but to potentially enlighten, and get people to think. We know this will be a successful project, and we cannot wait to share it with you! 

THANK YOU for your time and for your generosity, we will see you at the show!

story:
Dear Friends,

We are off to the Minnesota Fringe Festival to present Duetted, July 31-August 9, 2014!  

Monica and Dan are set to celebrate 10 years of dancing and choreographing together by looking back while charging ahead.  Duetted will showcase new works, some greatest hits from our repertory, and choreography by other artists that have been creatively and professionally influential.  For our fourth adventure to the MN Fringe, long time friend, mentor, and collaborator, Debra Loewen (Milwaukee, WI), stages a new work based on duets we have danced for Wild Space Dance Company during our 12 years with the company.  Suniti Dernovsek (Portland, OR) resets a work from her acclaimed evening length work, This Is How We Disappear, and in collaboration with their first friend at the 2006 Minnesota Fringe, Monica and Dan make a long-distance collaboration with Mike Mathieu (Seattle, WA) of the Cody Rivers Show.  Finally, the duo perform Susan Marshall’s (NYC) Crimson & Clover, the gorgeous and audibly captivating duet from the 2006 evening-length concert Cloudless.

We need your help!

As independent artists we need your financial backing to go towards:

  • Travel Expense - to NYC and Minnesota
  • Commission and Licensing Fees for the choreography & music
  • General Expenses such as rental of rehearsal space, marketing, and production fees.

Any amount you can contribute is greatly appreciated and those of $20 or more receive gifts in return. 

A little about us -

The performing pair, Rodero and Schuchart, are both pretty laid back, have a great sense of humor, and only argue about choreography.  Their first independent concert was in the summer of 2004, which makes it easy to remember when they had their first fight.  After a few years in sunny California to earn MFA degrees in Experimental Choreography (i.e. how to fight for real) the pair has returned to the Midwest to celebrate ten years of making innovative, physical, and humorous work together.

Whether you are able to make a contribution today or not, please help spread the word and join us for the event!

PS - To all those in WI, it is in the works to present this in Milwaukee in the fall too!


Link to the MN Fringe site: http://www.fringefestival.org/2014/show/?id=2663

Monica Rodero & Dan Schuchart present: Duetted at the Minnesota Fringe Festival. Southern Theater, 1420 Washington Ave. South in Minneapolis, MN.

Show times are:   Thursday, July 31 – 7:00pm  

                                   Sunday, Aug. 3 - 2:30pm

                                   Monday, Aug. 4 – 7:00pm

                                   Thursday, Aug. 7 – 10:00pm

                                   Saturday, Aug. 9 - 5:30pm

“They make (dances) not only funny, but also touching and engaging to the eye…a couple with a sophisticated sense of form.”  

-Tom Strini, Milwaukee Journal Sentinel


Just for your viewing pleasure, we found this while digging through our archives to get ready for the show.  Our 2009 MN Fringe trailer...Enjoy!

story:
My name is David Sisco, and I'm a voice teacher at Marymount Manhattan College. I founded The Directory of Contemporary Musical Theatre Writers in January 2012 because I was frustrated by the lack of contemporary work being published. Having been witness to a lot of great musical theatre songs through my involvement in the BMI Musical Theatre workshop, I got the idea to develop a resource that would bring teachers, students and writers together in a new way.

During the spring I began creating a mammoth directory and interactive database that currently holds over 150 writers and 360 songs (all searchable by voice and song type). Each page of the Directory features a writer or writing team's head shot, bio, contact information and five of their best songs with links to listen/view the songs and information on how to purchase them directly from the writers. All the songs were vetted by musical theatre and voice professionals, making the Directory a very unique resource for those looking for fresh new repertoire (95% of which is self-published).

Knowing the project was too big to handle alone, I asked my friend Lorene Phillips - with whom I previously co-founded Caprice Opera Theatre - to join me. I was thrilled when she said yes!

This summer, Lorene and I presented the Directory as a poster paper at the 2012 NATS (National Association of Teachers of Singing) Conference in Orlando, where it was met with a great deal of interest. Since then, our blog associated with the project - which covers a wide range of topics about the musical theatre industry - has gotten over 22,000 hits in over six countries! It's clear this is a much-needed resource.

We’ve just launched an online version of the Directory at www.contemporarymusicaltheatre.com with added writers and songs. Our web designer Josh Levine did a phenomenal job creating the infrastructure that holds all of this information and allows writers to update their own pages in the Directory. There is no other resource out on the market like this.  The breadth and depth of information in this Directory makes it very unique and highly attractive to teachers, students and musical theatre professionals alike.

To be clear, the songs listed in the Directory are not be available for purchase on our website - we send interested consumers directly to the writers to buy sheet music. Better yet, we’re not taking a cent from the writer’s sales, which is the traditional sheet music publishing model. Instead we have created a new model in which our revenue will come from our subscribers and advertisers.

We need your help! Lorene and I have solely funded the project thus far because we believe in it. We recently asked each writer or writing team to contribute $25, which only covered the build of their individual writer pages. It did not cover any other costs associated with launching the website or marketing it.

We are also planning a huge launch concert on Monday, January 21, 2013 at Second Stage Theatre. The evening will benefit The Dramatist Guild Fund, which helps financially support writers in need. The expenses associated with putting this performance together are considerable. The more money we raise for our website build, the more members we have, the more money we can use for marketing our website around the country and globe.  We expect to have enough proceeds from our concert to make a generous donation to our benefactor.

In addition to the website and launch concert, we just found out we've been accepted to present the Directory at the International Congress of Voice Teachers in Brisbane, Australia July 10-14!  This is a huge opportunity for us in terms of exposure and networking.  Your donations will help us market the Directory at the conference and keep finding new ways of developing the website.

Will you help us? This is an opportunity to be a part of the theatre community in a way never before possible. You will literally be supporting hundreds of musical theatre writers as they seek to get their songs out into the world. Anything you can offer in support of this project is greatly appreciated!  Whether by donating the cost of your daily latte or making a sizeable contribution, we are counting on your generosity to get our idea out into the world in a big way.


We’ve come this far and now we need your help !!  Thanks in advance for your generosity.

story:
Miss Burlesque Bunny and Blue Belle Burlesque

"Tease 'n' Tassels" is the premier event for Blue Belle Burlesque and includes Heat 1 of the Miss Burlesque Bunny competition. In its inaugural year, this awards program aims to encourage and mentor the next generation of burlesque performers, and help launch their stage careers from ingenue to impresario.

Each heat of the competition is held during the quarterly Blue Belle Burlesque revue showcase event, Tease 'n' Tassels. The idea of this is to bring seasoned entertainers together with new performers, to provide an opportunity to network, learn - and perform for a large audience.

It will be judged by a panel of burlesque teachers and principal dancers from the local burlesque community. Entrants for the competition must have been performing burlesque for less than two years, and hold no other major titles.

Building a strong profile for the event now will help to attract interest for the next two heats and sponsors for the Miss Burlesque Bunny grand final event in 2013. I hope to award the winner gift vouchers, classes, costumes etc from local business and send them to the Burlesque Hall of Fame in Vegas. 

Blue Belle Burlesque is part burlesque, part vaudeville and 100% fabulous. Located in Edmonton, Alberta and directed by Australian performer Jade Janvier, it features a mischievous line up of ladies in a show that will capture fetish, fusion, classic burlesque and the circus arts.
 
With feature performances from well known local talent including Lylia Chorosive of Chorosive Dark Fusion, and Kiki Quinn of River City Revue Burlesque, as well as soloists Cherry Poppins, Samantha Rose, Casha Clay and Miss Rainbow, the audience will enjoy a diverse show from a troupe that has performed collectively coast to coast in Canada, and across the Pacific in Australia and New Zealand.

What We Need & What You Get

As you are not in Canada so probably can't make it to the event to show your support, a contribution will help cover venue costs, staging and lighting/sound tech costs, sashes/prizes for the extrants, promotion and advertising.

I've already invested the funds for start up expenses, performer's pay, and MC.

Perks:

Shimmie: $10 Blue Belle Burlesque will thank you online (website and facebook)

Tassel twirl: $30 You will be sent a limited release photo with all the performers from the premier night, and thanks online

Bump & Grind: $100 You will be sent a limited release photo with all the performers from the premier night, magnetic frame, event poster and thanks online

The Impact

Your help from the other side of the world will help me to get burlesque booming in a city where its still very much fringe theatre, and more importantly launch a few blushing burlyQ bunnies into the spotlight. I hope to build a strong foundation here, and then take the Miss Burlesque Bunny competition global.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help!

  • Help get the word out and let others know about the campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools for facebook and twitter!

Thanks and shimmies from afar!

story: This video tells the story of the visionary New Stage Theatre Company founded by Ildiko Nemeth. For our 10th year celebration we are presenting Jollification|Mortification at the Club at La MaMa on East 4th Street from April 5th through April 21st. We ask you to support The New Stage Theatre Company by making a contribution today.
story_txt: This video tells the story of the visionary New Stage Theatre Company founded by Ildiko Nemeth. For our 10th year celebration we are presenting Jollification|Mortification at the Club at La MaMa on East 4th Street from April 5th through April 21st. We ask you to support The New Stage Theatre Company by making a contribution today.

story:
I've come a-begging. 
 
I am trying to produce this play I wrote to be performed in April and need your help to achieve the budget.  I do not have non-profit organization status so I am unable to obtain grant money, but I have my own money that I am using (and working to get more), and in need of great chunks of the stuff.
I have to rent the theater, rent rehearsal space, hold auditions (and rent space to hold those auditions), pay the actors, the director, the lighting technician, house manager, stage manager, and do all of the publicity.  The budget is hefty (the theater rental alone for the three week run is close to $10,000).
 
I need the practical help of my friends, acquaintances and strangers for this project (so please spread the word). 
 
If you are unable to provide anything it is understandable, especially in these difficult, lean and scraping times, but please come and see it all the same because a piece of theater, like life, is made to be shared with people.
 
I think the play will only enhance the spirit of our lives; I hope you will find it so,
 
Tristan Grigsby
 
*Please know that every piece of media (posters, flyers, postcards, etc.) will be laced with these words: "Theater for the New City Presents" and "Funded in part by the DCA and NYSCA," however nobody is presenting the play other than me nor will anyone or any organization be funding this play, other than me, my friends, and acquaintances, but I could not use the theater without placing these words on the various media materials.

story:
Now, on the 6th production, Definition Theatre Company is back and bigger than ever. As we continue to strive for telling stories about how we live now and whats to come, we are excited about continuing to define our future. We can’t do it without YOU. Your support will go directly towards funding our productions and operations: materials, costumes, lights, props, programs and, stipends for the creative teams are just a small example of how your gifts help bring these stories to life and allow us to share our passion with the Chicagoland community.

Donate today, and your support will go TWICE as far. Definition supporter and friend, playwright Tarell Alvin McCraney, will match donations made to DTC in the month of March. Since Definition’s inception, with his play, The Brother’s Size, we are thrilled to continue our relationship with the inspiring and accomplished playwright. Donate Now!


What's Next?

Upcoming Production—Definition Theatre Company’s presents A DOLL’S HOUSE adapted and directed by Michael Halberstam. Playing at The Chopin Theatre (1543 West Division Street, Chicago, IL 60642) April 3 - May 3, 2015.

Nora and Torvald have all the trappings of a perfect suburban life: a beautiful home, two children, and enough money to finance their comfortable lifestyle. But when a terrible secret from Nora’s past threatens to ruin all they’ve built, she is left with two options: deceive the man she loves, or face the truth and risk losing everything.

The cast of A Doll’s House  includes Yaw Agyeman (Dr. Rank), Miriam Lee (Nora), Krystal Mosley (Mrs. Linde), Tyrone Phillips (Torvald), Chris Sheard (Krogstad), Mercedes White (Anne-Marie). 

The designers are Moon Jung Kim (Set Designer), Kristy Hall (Costume Designer), Claire Chrzan (Lighting Designer), Matt Test (Sound Designer), Clyde Compton (Properties Designer). The Stage Manager is Ari Y. Wartell.


A Doll's House: About the Director

Michael Halberstam comments, “I am excited to be directing for Definition for very specific reasons.  This theatre company was founded at my alma mater, The University of Illinois, in partial response to a dialogue about non-traditional casting during a master class I taught a couple of years ago.  I felt that this collaboration gave me the opportunity to both mentor an emergent company engaged in this very conversation while allowing me to learn more about the process in an organic and integral way.”  He continues, “I have always found that the great off-loop theatre scene is often at its most creative when it has lean resources. As I prepare to expand my toolbox in Glencoe with our new theatre center, it seems like a fine idea to re-engage with core values that drive us to do what we do—namely great words and great actors.  I am wildly excited about doing this play with this company at this moment in time and I cannot wait to be in the room."


Our Mission

Definition Theatre Company is a Chicago ensemble-based theatre founded by six graduates of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Featuring a multi-ethnic core companionship of actors, Definition strives to artistically reflect the myriad of modern America to inspire and engage the communities it represents through  contemporary and classical theatrical works. Our mission is to tell language-driven, relationship-oriented, thought-provoking socially relevant stories.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word about the DEFINING Our Future Campaign!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Visit our website and join our mailing list!

story:
Disparat Theater 

We are Disparat Theater, an emerging theatre company, whose work has been described as 

"Genuinely fresh, new and exciting" (James Seagar, Les Enfants Terribles)

and

"Literate, warm and surprising" (Leon Rubin).

We translate the magic of stories into a visual language, giving each audience member the chance to imagine their own. 

We were founded at Uri Roodner’s Contemporary Theatre course at East 15 Acting school in 2014 and have already been shortlisted for the Les Enfants Terribles Award 2015 and performed the show at the Lyric Hammersmith, Greenwich Theatre and New Diorama Theatre. 

Our next step is the Edinburgh Fringe festival, where we have secured a spot at the Big Belly space at Cowgate, Underbelly. It is a great opportunity to showcase the play to reviewers and potential programmers, as well as share this wonderful story with an Edinburgh audience. 

 

CREATIVE TEAM

Written by 

Avital Lvova & George Vere 

Directed by 

George Vere 

Designer 

Connor Mott

Multimedia Manager

Przemek Grzeda

 

CAST

Robyn Grant

Holly Kilpatrick 

Avital Lvova

Federico Moro

George Vere

Richard Weston

MUSIC

Ian Fleming

              

                              What We Need

In order for Edinburgh to happen we need to raise £2800. We made £1000 from workshops and fundraisers. So that brings us down to £1800. Without this money we wont be able to take the show to the Fringe.

We need money for;

Venue hire  &  Brochures  -  £1700
- Deposit for Big Belly space 
- A place in the Ed Fringe Brochure 
- A place in the Joint Venue Brochure 
Travel - £300
- Getting a cast of seven to Edinburgh and back
Van hire  - £300
- To safely transport our wonderful set, costumes, props and instruments 
Marketing  - £400
- To promote the show with flyers and posters 
Insurance  - £100
- To keep us safe 

                          

                        The Show

                       

                                 11.20am, Big Belly (Underbelly Cowgate)

                                           6th - 30th of August (not 17th & 24th) 
 Once upon a time there was a girl who lived in a room filled with unfinished books. She read and imagined the worlds of the stories around her. One day a new book appeared. She wanted to read it, but the voice in her head told her not to. And shouldn't you listen to those who know better?
Using the enigma of unfinished stories we have created a wonderful play for the whole family about literacy and growing up, which invites us to question our existence. 

                      

                      Other Ways You Can Help

 If you are not in the position to contribute but really liked what you've seen and read you can always share the link with your friends, get the word out about us or simply come and see us at the Underbelly.

story: Since SOL does not charge admission, ICARUS is raising money to be able to cover the numerous costs of putting on a professional quality show. In order to showcase our pieces on a beautiful stage, with a variety of costumes, and extensive lighting, we need your help! Any donations would be incredibly helpful and graciously accepted to help make our show as great as possible. We can't thank everyone enough for all of the love and support they have shown our team!

story:
Mission Statement

It is the goal of Fuzion Contemporary Dance Company to teach young people to achieve a life-long love of dance and creative freedom by stressing excellence in both education and performance.  The organization encourages self-confidence, self discipline, responsibility and unity among diversity.

By stressing attention to detail, skill and technique, and exploring a wide variety of dance styles, the students learn time management, discipline, and experience a level of performance excellence and performance opportunities not available through their public/private school dance programs.

Primary Activity

Fuzion Contemporary Dance Company began its educational activities in May 2005.  Weekly class sessions and dance rehearsals provide instruction by qualified dance educators.

These classes and rehearsals are designed to teach attention to detail through repetition of skill and technique, time management and provide the learning of many varied dance styles, to include ballet, jazz, lyrical, contemporary ballet, modern, hip hop, and tap.

Fuzion Contemporary Dance Company students participate in 4 - 12.5 hours of classroom instruction and rehearse 5 - 10 hours per week.  Seventy percent (70%) of Fuzion Contemporary Dance Company's purpose is met through this educational setting.  FCDC maintains a low teacher-to-student ratio allowing for the additional achievement of not only high artistic standards, but also the development of self-control, responsibility, citizenship, creative expression and the ability to work with others.  Fuzion Contemporary Dance Company also contracts with professional choreographers to provide students exposure to the creative process of dance.

Secondary Activity

Performances at Fuzion Contemporary Dance Company concerts and community events showcase the skills of company members and introduce the community to Fuzion's mission and goals.  FCDC performances encompass an additional thirty percent (30%) of the purpose, vision and mission.  The intent of these performances is to provide a forum for students to enhance and fine-tune their dance skills and technique, and to develop an appreciation for the performing arts.  Fuzion Contemporary Dance Company uses these event performances to reach the community, expanding the opportunity to raise community awareness of the dance arts.  

FCDC believes that giving back and paying forward are important aspects of living in a community.

Fuzion has supported local non-profit organizations by performing at benefits such as Dancers Against Cancer and Upstage Arts.  FCDC donates tickets to their bi-annual shows to Big Brothers Big Sisters and the Bay Area Turning Point.  Company members serve as positive role models by supporting the "Drug Free Program", performing at local elementary schools, and community events including, The Oak Tree Festival, Ballunar Festival, and Houston's Children's Fest.  They celebrated League City's "50th Gala" and the Barnevelder's "Dance Gathering" with outstanding performances.  FCDC supports the "Community in School" Program each year with canned food drives and they donate a portion of every ticket to their concerts to the Bay Area Turning Point.  Fuzion also provides scholarships to students who are at risk by offering dance classes and performance opportunities.  FCDC believes that helping children gain exposure and access to these activities will go a long way in affecting positive change in their lives.

What We Need 

Budget

1)  Theater -                                                     $1380.00

2)  Tickets paper/Ink  -                                    $24.99 + $79.96

3)  Posters -                                                    $24.50

4)  Programs -                                                 $181.00

5)  Rehearsal Space -                                    $900/month x 4 = $3600

6)  Costumes -                                                $570.00

7)  Sets -                                                         $4800.00

8)  Backdrops -                                               $2000.00

9)  Props -                                                       $390.00

10) Rehearsal Director/Artistic Director -       $10.00/hour x 10 hours/week         

                                                                        =$100.00 x4=$400x4 = $1600.00

11) Rehearsal Assistant -                              $5.00/hour x 5 hours/week = $25.00 x 4=                                                                          $100.00 x 4 = $400.00

12)  Professional Company                           $100/per performance x 6 dancers = 

                                                                       $600.00

13)  Guest Artists -                                        $250/performance x 2 artists = $500.00

14)  Flowers for the leads -                            $300.00

15)  Lunch for cast on show day -                 $150.00

16)  Cast Party -                                            $300.00


$16, 900.45

-$3200.00 FCDC monthly fundraising

Total - $13, 700.45

  • The Impact

Fuzion Contemporary Dance Company is striving to bring a contemporary version of the holiday classic "The Nutcracker" to their community.  Fuzion's "The Fuzed Nutcracker" has a fresh spin on the story and uses the surrounding area of Clear Lake and Webster Texas and original cast members as inspiration.  FCDC is 2.1 miles from NASA's Johnson Space Center so they tied the space program into their story by sending the lead role to outer space in Act II.  The lead and supporting roles of Clara, Drosselmeyer, Fritz and more are renamed after the FCDC alumni that originated the roles.  In keeping with Fuzion's initial mission statement, "The Fuzed Nutcracker" uses a variety of styles of dance such as ballet, contemporary ballet, jazz, lyrical, modern, and hip hop to bring to life FCDC's version of a holiday classic with a new twist!

Fuzion has presented their Fuzed Nutcracker annually for 6 years.  The Artistic Director feels having an annual production is important to the growth of a dancer. The dancers feel a sense of accomplishment when they step into the roles of past dancers that they admire.  The Fuzed Nutcracker allows younger dancers to learn how hard work, determination, and passion pays off when they move up through the levels of walk on roles, corps roles, soloist roles, and finally lead roles. Each year Fuzion produces two shows, usually they are The Fuzed Nutcracker and Funk, Soul, Dance.  The past two years however, Fuzion has not produced the Fuzed Nutcracker due to lack of funding.  Fuzion's artistic director feels the time is right to present the 7th annual production of the Fuzed Nutcracker.


If we don't get funded:  The show must go on but...

1)  Rehearsal space will be cut so we'll have less time to rehearse and produce a quality show.

2)  No sets.  Sets help provide atmosphere for the show and helps the audience experience the story.

3)  No backdrops.  Backdrops will make our show polished and professional.

4)  Rehearsal Director/Artistic Director will not get paid.

5)  Professional division dancers of FCDC will not get paid to perform.

6)  No guest artists.  We will have to cut some of the dances in the show because we won't be able to hire a male lead (Apollo) or a 3rd partner for our cha-cha in the party scene. 

7)  Rehearsal Assistant will not get paid.

8)  No flowers for the leads in the show.

9)  Dancers and crew will pay for their own lunch on show day.

10) No cast party.

11) No new costumes.  Dancers will perfom in old costumes that are worn out and don't fit properly.

12)  Cost for paper and ink and printing of tickets, posters, and programs will come out of the Artistic Directors pocket.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate... please, please, please help us spread the word!

$16, 900.45
-$3200.00 FCDC monthly fundraising
Total - $13, 700.45

The Impact

Fuzion Contemporary Dance Company is striving to bring a contemporary version of the holiday classic "The Nutcracker" to their community.  Fuzion's "The Fuzed Nutcracker" has a fresh spin on the story and uses the surrounding area of Clear Lake and Webster Texas and original cast members as inspiration.  FCDC is 2.1 miles from NASA's Johnson Space Center so they tied the space program into their story by sending the lead role to outer space in Act II.  The lead and supporting roles of Clara, Drosselmeyer, Fritz and more are renamed after the FCDC alumni that originated the roles.  In keeping with Fuzion's initial mission statement, "The Fuzed Nutcracker" uses a variety of styles of dance such as ballet, contemporary ballet, jazz, lyrical, modern, and hip hop to bring to life FCDC's version of a holiday classic with a new twist!
Fuzion has presented their Fuzed Nutcracker annually for 6 years.  The Artistic Director feels having an annual production is important to the growth of a dancer. The dancers feel a sense of accomplishment when they step into the roles of past dancers that they admire.  The Fuzed Nutcracker allows younger dancers to learn how hard work, determination, and passion pays off when they move up through the levels of walk on roles, corps roles, soloist roles, and finally lead roles. Each year Fuzion produces two shows, usually they are The Fuzed Nutcracker and Funk, Soul, Dance.  The past two years however, Fuzion has not produced the Fuzed Nutcracker due to lack of funding.  Fuzion's artistic director feels the time is right to present the 7th annual production of the Fuzed Nutcracker.If we don't get funded:  The show must go on but...1)  Rehearsal space will be cut so we'll have less time to rehearse and produce a quality show.2)  No sets.  Sets help provide atmosphere for the show and helps the audience experience the story.3)  No backdrops.  Backdrops will make our show polished and professional.4)  Rehearsal Director/Artistic Director will not get paid.5)  Professional division dancers of FCDC will not get paid to perform.6)  No guest artists.  We will have to cut some of the dances in the show because we won't be able to hire a male lead (Apollo) or a 3rd partner for our cha-cha in the party scene. 7)  Rehearsal Assistant will not get paid.8)  No flowers for the leads in the show.9)  Dancers and crew will pay for their own lunch on show day.10) No cast party.11) No new costumes.  Dancers will perfom in old costumes that are worn out and don't fit properly.12)  Cost for paper and ink and printing of tickets, posters, and programs will come out of the Artistic Directors pocket.Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't donate... please, please, please help us spread the word!

story:
Hi, I'm Hadley.

I've been creating dance work in New York for the past decade. As an artist, one of my main desires is to create work that pays homage to the powerful women who populate my daily life. For the past two years I've been working with some of these women; who have overwhelmed me with their dedication and generosity. Tanogram, a new dance piece, is the result of many hours of working together - working through personal and political pain, working at witnessing one another, working for each other.

These Women Need to Get Paid

I've been amazed by my collaborators generosity. Kirsten Schnitker, for example, came into the studio with me to start this process almost two years ago. Two years guys! It may not seem like a long time for a big project to develop, but it is when you're dedicating hours every week and also working a full time job. Elanor Bock joined this process not long after, and this past spring Emily Bock joined us from Chicago, sometimes flying back and forth from a summer teaching job. DID I MENTION THESE WOMEN SHOULD REALLY GET PAID? All of us have received intangible benefits from the practices that became apart of this process, but at the end of the day we need to be paid in order to sustain this work.

Creating and sustaining creative practices and meaningful community in this world is hard. By giving to this campaign you are directly supporting artists who are engaged in this work.

 

This Work//It's Rewards (and "Rewards")

This work has helped me to rebuild and refocus my attention as a maker. For my collaborators I can only hope to offer a space to think, reflect, offer alternative visions of themselves to the world, and to see one another. Most importantly, to know their own value in this process, in this world. Any rewards we've reaped will be reflected in the rewards you will receive for your donation. If you're familiar with my work, you know that the writing/drawing/sewing/zine making is as important as the dancing. By donating to this campaign you will receive some of this dance-making by product, for lack of a better term:

When you give $10+ you'll receive a personalized score postcard thanking you.

When you give $25+ you'll receive a personalized score postcard, and a score zine with illustrations and writing related to this work.

When you give $50+ you receive a postcard, zine and a pocket calendar featuring lunar phases throughout 2019.

When you give $100+ you will receive a postcard, zine, pocket calendar and a custom tarot embroidery piece hand sewn by myself.

 

Thank You!

Thank you for taking the time to visit our campaign. Please consider contributing, and if you cannot please share this with someone who might be able to contribute. Our next performance is at Secret Project Robot in Bushwick Tuesday October 16th, come and see the work we're doing!
