story:
What is this project?

We are a group of 7 Northwestern students banding together to put on this show. Jordan Knitzer conceived this idea to produce "The Zoo Story" as an independent project, and ever since November, this team has put in an incredible amount of work to make this show as incredible as it can be. 

 

What are we asking for?

As an independent project, this seven person team is responsible for all fundraising for the show. The most substantial cost is the space rental for performances, but other costs include scenery rental, rights and props. We would appreciate greatly any contribution you are able to make to support this production. It is shaping up to be a fantastic show and these few technical elements will truly add the finishing polish to the amazing work the actors and directors have been doing. We simply need to raise the money to pay for them.

story:
Who We Are

Eclipses Group Theater New York is a nonprofit theater company that serves as a cultural bridge between the United States and Greece. Using an exploratory, multidisciplinary approach, Eclipses presents Greek and non-Greek classical and modern plays in collaboration with artists of various ethnicities and cultures, developing an intercultural artistic dialogue. Eclipses has performed at Cherry Lane Theater, La MaMa, NYU, the St-Ambroise Montreal Fringe Festival, the LaGuardia Performing Arts Center, the National Hellenic Museum of Chicago, the Hellenic Cultural Center in New York, the Greek Cultural Center in New York and elsewhere. Recent work has featured works by Aeschylus, Anton Chekhov, Euripides, Dario Fo and the contemporary Greek playwrights Dimitris Dimitriadis, Akis Dimou, Penny Fylaktaki, Yannis Mavristakis and Michalis Reppas/Thanasis Papathanasiou, among others.

 

Hercules: In Search of a Hero

In Alcestis, Hercules goes to the underworld and restores Alcestis to her family. In Hercules, he comes back from the underworld, is thrown into a god-induced frenzy and kills his own family. On the other hand, Alcestis sacrifices herself to save her family, yet she is rarely counted among the heroes of Greek mythology. That moniker is usually reserved for male warriors—men of action, adventure and death.

We see echoes of the heroic legacy of ancient Greece in modern, Western society—a society that all too often exalts aggression and the vanquishing of enemies, whether in sports, entertainment, business or politics. In Hercules: In Search of a Hero, we use as a launching point the two diametrically opposite actions by the prototypical Greek hero Hercules, contrasted with Alcestis' own heroic act, to explore what heroism is and could be in a modern context. Our play poses a number of questions: What counts as heroism in our time? Is an act heroic if it involves violence? What is the place of women in the modern mythology of heroism? Do we need to create new mythologies?

Conceived and directed by Ioanna Katsarou, the production features a new English translation of excerpts from Euripides' Alcestis and Hercules by Demetri Bonaros and original music by Costas Baltazanis.

 

When and Where

We will perform Hercules: In Search of a Hero from January 24 to February 10, 2019 at the Abrons Arts Center: 466 Grand Street (at Pitt Street) in Manhattan's Lower East Side . Click here for more information and here for tickets.

 

Your Support

    Did you know that, other than building a space shuttle or ordering a Venti salted caramel mocha frappuccino at Starbucks, producing theater in New York City is the most expensive human activity? Even an off-off-broadway production has a budget that matches the GDP of Lichtenstein. (These things may or may not be true.) In our case, expenses include, among others: theater rental, rehearsal space, artist fees, publicity, marketing, design materials, transportation, storage and a partridge in a pear tree.

    Luckily, Hercules: In Search of a Hero has no shortage of heroes: YOU! (Even reading this far is a heroic act.) Your contribution will help us cover the rental cost of the Experimental Theater at the Abrons Arts Center, one of the most important organizations in Manhattan's Indy theater scene. You may support Hercules in a variety of ways:

    • by making a contribution to this campaign, which is tax deductible to the extent allowed by law;
    • by purchasing show tickets here;
    • by telling your friends, family, acquaintances, your green grocer, your periodontist and that annoying uncle about the show and this campaign; and
    • by using the Indiegogo share tools to promote the show and this campaign to your circle of friends.

    Finally, we would be remiss if we didn't express our gratitude for the institutional and government support we have received in the development of Hercules:

    * This project will be performed at the Abrons Art Center as part of the @Abrons program.

    * This project was made possible (in part) by the Queens Council on the Arts with public funds from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council; and  

    * This project was made possible with funds from the Decentralization Program, a regrant program of the New York State Council on the Arts with the support of Governor Andrew Cuomo and the New York State Legislature and administered by the Queens Council on the Arts.

    * This project has been proudly supported by a grant from Investors Foundation. www.investorsbankfoundation.org

    * This work was partially developed and performed through a generous space grant from LaGuardia Performing Arts Center (LPAC).

    * Under the Auspices and strong support of the Consulate General of Greece in New York.

     

    ... and of course, this project is made possible by all of you! So, a wholehearted "thank you" to you all for contributing to this campaign and supporting us over the years!

     

    Our Herculean labor is well underway! Join us on this great journey In Search of a Hero! #NewProduction #AncientGreekDrama #EGTNY

In Brief...

Nothing To Declare Productions was founded in 2018 by Rosie Fleeshman and Alex Slater. Our debut production 'Narcissist In The Mirror'  is playing for the full month at this year's Edinburgh Fringe in The Pleasance Courtyard following a sellout and award winning run at various theatres across the country. 

Over the past year and a half we've funnelled every penny from every performance along with a host of other ridiculous events, quizzes and poetry nights into getting the show to Edinburgh. We've managed to raise nearly every penny through our endeavours (a lot of which we know we stand to not get back) and need your help clearing the final hurdle. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We're not really sure how, but somehow by running Harry Potter quizzes, Friends quizzes, hosting poetry events, performing at poetry events and with the ticket sales from the show thus far, we've managed to raise almost every ounce of our budget, that said we're still doing it on a bit of a shoe string. We don't yearn for caviar or Kristal, we don't wish to ride to Edinburgh in a horse drawn carriage, we simply wish to be able to fix things if they break and  travel back home once the show is done. 

We purposely set a small target as we didn't want to have to set up a crowd funder at all, but as it stands we're a couple of weeks away and we're still a little way from covering all of our basic costs, including van hire, travel costs and marketing.

In exchange for your support, large or small, you receive a huge thank you from ourselves for the world to see along with the knowledge that you're assisting a newly formed company find its feet. Depending on your pledge you can also receive a unique token of our appreciation, created by us for you as a way of saying thank you a little differently. 

The Impact

We really want to spend the rest of our lives making things. We reckon it's as selfish as it is selfless. We like making things. We also like making people think, making people laugh, entertaining and enlightening, sparking dialogue. Hopefully with the things we make we can make peoples lives a little better for an hour or a little more at a time. Hopefully after this show we will be able to self sustain our creative endeavours 100% of the way. For now it's only 95%, but we hope that with your help this year we will be able to make the transition before next year comes around.

Risks & Challenges

The vast majority of theatre companies do not go to The Edinburgh Fringe with the goal of making money, maybe with the exception of Jimmy Carr, Shit Faced Shakespeare and a select few others. We're quite aware that there's a good chance we may lose money, we'll be happy to break even, ecstatic to make any. This isn't why we're going. Our first production has done better than we could have ever expected and for us taking it to The Fringe was never a question of 'if', rather 'how'. It's an invaluable experience for a new company to make connections, spread awareness of their brand and their product and a chance to make mistakes, learn, grow and develop as individuals and as a collective. We aim to come back from The Fringe stronger, smarter, tighter, wiser, better connected and invariably - exhausted. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Lots of people do not have exposable income in any shape or form. We understand this completely. If you cannot spare us £1 or £100 now or ever then there are other ways you can help us. Follow any of our social media handles!

Our Instagram and Twitter handles are @ntdproductions

Our Facebook page is facebook.com/narcissistinthemirror

Every follow spreads our reach, every like and share helps us spread awareness of our company, it's totally free and almost everyone has an account on one of the three platforms.

story:
THE PLAY

Jonno is a beloved Canadian radio host, recently published novelist, and self-proclaimed feminist. Jonno also violently abuses his sexual partners.  As the details of his aggressions threaten to become public knowledge Jonno desperately tries to rationalize his abusive behaviour to himself and to the people around him. Meanwhile, the women he has attacked struggle to find the ‘correct’ response to their assault. Angry, visceral, and disturbingly funny, the play takes an honest look at the violence perpetuated against women, and forces a light onto the men who engage in it.

JONNO was written by playwright Alix Sobler as a direct response to a sexual assault scandal that sent shockwaves through the Canadian entertainment industry back in 2014. In 2016, the play was produced by Echo Theatre at the Winnipeg Fringe Festival, and received rave reviews from critics and audience members alike. In January 2018, JONNO will receive its Toronto debut at the Next Stage Theatre Festival.

THIS PRODUCTION

Although initially written in response to a particular set of events, JONNO is fuelled by a more general conversation on victim-blaming, consent, and feminism-- and over the past few months, the need for that conversation has never been more apparent. Society is becoming increasingly concerned with the question of how to advocate for survivors and how to condemn their assaulters. Through our production of JONNO, we hope to create a space in which to foster this discussion.

THE FUNDING

Rabbit in a Hat Productions is a small company with limited funds. We rely primarily on ticket sales and private donations to support the work we create. The money raised by this campaign will help us cover many of our expenses, including rehearsal space rental, purchasing production materials, and marketing and promotional materials.

Because of the difficult nature of the subject material that we are tackling in this production, we feel that it is necessary to create a safe space after our performances for our audiences to unwind, process their experience, and discuss the contents of the show with the cast and crew. Organizing these debriefing sessions comes at additional cost to us, but we feel that they are invaluable. Your donations will help us offer an environment that is as safe and as welcoming as possible.

Finally, a large portion of your donation will go straight to the artists involved in this production. All of our actors and designers are professional artists who make a living off of the work that they create. The more money we raise here, the more we are able to give back to them.

YOUR SUPPORT

Support from donors like you is integral to creating indie theatre in Toronto. Independent theater helps give voice to those who aren't always heard, and raises questions that aren't often asked. By donating to this campaign, you are helping us tell a story that we feel desperately needs to be told, and driving a vital conversation about sex, abuse, and power forward. And-- above all else-- your donations will ensure that the artists involved are getting properly compensated for their work.

To thank you for your donation, the team at Rabbit in a Hat Productions is offering some pretty great perks. These include:

  • Name recognition online and in our program
  • Free tickets to our production
  • A signed copy of our poster
  • A copy of the script, signed by the playwright
  • Post-show drinks with the cast and crew

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you can't donate to our campaign-- or can, and would like to do more!-- you can support us by buying a ticket to the show! Tickets and Next Stage festival passes will be available for purchase online as of November 27th. Early Bird savings of 15% can be accessed until December 5, 2017.

You can also help out Rabbit in a Hat Productions by following us on Facebook and Twitter, and by spreading the word about the show and this campaign.

WHO WE ARE

Rabbit in a Hat Productions was founded in Montreal in 2001 with a mandate to produce new Canadian Independent Theatre. Using multidisciplinary techniques and mediums,
the company is devoted to bringing intelligent, vibrant, and original to the stage. JONNO will be our fifth Toronto production, and our second show at the Next Stage Theatre Festival. Learn more on our website.

story:
What's this project all about?

"Renascence" is a New York Magazine Critics' Pick musical about "the original riot grrrl", Edna St. Vincent Millay, which is currently in its final two weeks of performances Off-Broadway. It features a score by Carmel Dean (musical director of the Broadway shows American Idiot, If/Then, Hands on a Hardbody), a book by Tony Award nominee Dick Scanlan (Thoroughly Modern Millie, Everyday Rapture) and orchestrations by Tony Award winner Michael Starobin (Assassins, Sunday in the Park with George, Next To Normal).

I, Carmel Dean (the composer!), have launched this fundraising campaign with the desire to preserve not only this score, which marks my compositional debut, but also the world-class performances of the six actors (Mikaela Bennett, Hannah Corneau, Jason Gotay, Danny Harris Kornfeld, Katie Thompson & Donald Webber Jr.) and eight musicians who have brought this music to life so gloriously here in New York City over the last six weeks. Having a cast album will also make it easier to license "Renascence" to schools, colleges and regional theatre companies, ensuring that the show can be performed AND seen by audiences worldwide for the indefinite future. 

Many of you who have seen the show have asked if there is a recording to take home because you loved the music so much and wanted listen to it again - well, here's your chance! And for those of you who weren't able to come to the show, here's your chance to own and experience what critics described as "seismic", "remarkably seductive" and "musical nirvana"! As you can see from the video containing selections from the show, the score contains staggeringly rich & lush orchestrations by Michael Starobin and incredible performances by the cast. This is your opportunity to fund - and subsequently own! - a recording of this whole show, including the title piece, which is a 20 minute sung-through epic musical journey - and I promise it's unlike anything you've ever heard before!

It is my dream for this score to reach as wide an audience as possible, and your donations can make this happen. Please consider contributing to this campaign so that the music of "Renascence" can be immortalized, and that the show can live on for the next generation of musical theatre audiences.

With immense gratitude,

Carmel Dean
story_txt: What's this project all about?"Renascence" is a New York Magazine Critics' Pick musical about "the original riot grrrl", Edna St. Vincent Millay, which is currently in its final two weeks of performances Off-Broadway. It features a score by Carmel Dean (musical director of the Broadway shows American Idiot, If/Then, Hands on a Hardbody), a book by Tony Award nominee Dick Scanlan (Thoroughly Modern Millie, Everyday Rapture) and orchestrations by Tony Award winner Michael Starobin (Assassins, Sunday in the Park with George, Next To Normal).I, Carmel Dean (the composer!), have launched this fundraising campaign with the desire to preserve not only this score, which marks my compositional debut, but also the world-class performances of the six actors (Mikaela Bennett, Hannah Corneau, Jason Gotay, Danny Harris Kornfeld, Katie Thompson & Donald Webber Jr.) and eight musicians who have brought this music to life so gloriously here in New York City over the last six weeks. Having a cast album will also make it easier to license "Renascence" to schools, colleges and regional theatre companies, ensuring that the show can be performed AND seen by audiences worldwide for the indefinite future. Many of you who have seen the show have asked if there is a recording to take home because you loved the music so much and wanted listen to it again - well, here's your chance! And for those of you who weren't able to come to the show, here's your chance to own and experience what critics described as "seismic", "remarkably seductive" and "musical nirvana"! As you can see from the video containing selections from the show, the score contains staggeringly rich & lush orchestrations by Michael Starobin and incredible performances by the cast. This is your opportunity to fund - and subsequently own! - a recording of this whole show, including the title piece, which is a 20 minute sung-through epic musical journey - and I promise it's unlike anything you've ever heard before!It is my dream for this score to reach as wide an audience as possible, and your donations can make this happen. Please consider contributing to this campaign so that the music of "Renascence" can be immortalized, and that the show can live on for the next generation of musical theatre audiences.With immense gratitude,Carmel Dean

story:
Short Summary

We love this community and we want to celebrate it. We think the best way to do that is to invite new stories to commingle with the fantastic theater community that already exists in Boise. Campfire Theatre Festival will take place September 15th-17th, 2017 at Boise Contemporary Theater. There will be staged readings, guest artists, workshops and other events to engage with these incredible artists. We hope to create an "around the campfire" feeling to share these stories from across the nation and from right at home in Idaho.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $3000 to make this festival be the best it can possibly be. Your donation will go to getting the word out, taking care of artists, and increasing our production value. We want these plays to get the attention they need and deserve in order to produce some riveting work. 

You can get anything from a sticker to a behind-the-scenes meet and greet. But more importantly, you will be giving to this community and be helping grow the arts scene in Boise.

The Impact

We believe the world needs more empathy. It's too easy to disregard other people because they feel different. Our festival is trying to produce work that creates understanding for others, and hopefully, our festival attendees will take that compassion and spread it to all corners of their lives. 

Challenges

One of the challenges is how do we actually diversify the perspectives we represent? To achieve those goals we've reached out to playwrights across the country, but we feel we can take this a step further. We would like to bring actors, directors and other artists in from across the country to participate. That will cost us a lot in housing and flights. We don't want to do this festival with the bare minimum requirements and any money you give will help achieve something that truly diversifies our festival. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contribute financially, but there are other ways you can help. Specifically, we need a plethora of volunteers to help run the festival. If you would like to volunteer you can email our technical director at caitlin@campfiretheatrefestival.com

story:
“This is not at all what I asked for when I came into this world. This is not at all what people here asked for when they came into this world. This is not what they’re asking for now”. 

The New Theatre Presents My Name is Rachel Corrie, directed by Megan Carney and edited by Katharine Viner and Alan Rickman. The show, starring Shannon Ferber, was previously staged at UCD Dramsoc and at the Irish Student Drama Awards where Shannon was nominated for Best Actress. Everyone involved in the show met in UCD Dramsoc and this is our first professional show, staging in The New Theatre in July 2017. 

Your contribution can help bring this show to the stage, bringing the urgent and timely voice of Rachel Corrie to The New Theatre. 

Who Are We?

We are a group of theatre-makers who met in UCD Dramsoc.

We are:

Megan Carney DIRECTOR AND SET DESIGNER

Shannon Ferber ACTOR

Ailish Toal PRODUCER

Matt Jones LIGHTING DESIGNER

Seán Mac Dhonnagáin SET DESIGNER

Seán O’Neill VISUAL DESIGN ARTIST

 

Why This Show Is Important

We are all extremely passionate about this piece, and constantly inspired by Rachel Corrie and her desire for change. Many years on, her thoughts and diary entries resonate with many current issues in the world today.

Rachel Corrie was an American activist who was a member of the Pro-Palestinian group International Solidarity Movement (ISM) and was killed trying to block an Israeli bulldozer in Gaza in 2003.

Since the creation of the state of Israel, there have been a number of accusations of human rights violations carried out against Palestinians both in Israel and in the Occupied Palestinian Territories. According to Amnesty International, Israeli forces have unlawfully killed Palestinian civilians, including children, and the authorities have continued to promote illegal settlements in the West Bank. Israeli forces have blockaded the Gaza Strip and demolished homes of Palestinians in the West Bank, forcibly evicting residents and restricting Palestinian’s freedom of movement. Israeli forces have used excessive force against Palestinian demonstrators, and so far, Rachel Corrie’s family’s attempts to gain justice for their daughter have been unsuccessful. However, it is important to note that the conflict is two-sided.

“If any of us had our lives and welfare completely strangled and lived with children in a shrinking place where we knew that soldiers and tanks and bulldozers could come for us at any moment, with no means of economic survival and our houses demolished; if they came and destroyed all the greenhouses that we’d been cultivating for the last however long do you not think, in a similar situation, most people would defend themselves as best they could?”

What We Need & What You Get

The team are generously working on a profit-share basis, but there are still a number of costs associated with staging this show in The New Theatre. Your generous contribution will go towards the rights for the show, the use of tech in the theatre, marketing, and insurance for our team in the theatre.

Even a small contribution of €5 will go a long way in helping us achieve our goal, and bringing Rachel Corrie’s story to The New Theatre.

We would like to extend a massive THANK YOU in advance for reading about our campaign. Check out the list of perks you can earn from contributing – your support means so much to us. If you find you can’t contribute at this time, but would still like to help out, please share the campaign with friends and family.

Other Ways You Can Help

You may not be able to contribute at this time, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help! There are several ways you can help the campaign:

  • Share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Snapchat, or any other social media form. Encourage your friends and family to contribute and help us spread the word.
  • Email this campaign to your friends and family
  • Get in touch with anyone you know who would be interested in supporting a project like this – there are so many ways they can support us, not just through contributing.
  • Attend our next fundraiser – we will be hosting a funky fundraiser in the next few weeks so keep an eye on our Facebook for details of this. Come along and bring your friends!
  • Come see the show! The show will be on in The New Theatre from 3rd of July, and we’d love to see you there!

Share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Snapchat, or any other social media form. Encourage your friends and family to contribute and help us spread the word.

Email this campaign to your friends and family

Get in touch with anyone you know who would be interested in supporting a project like this – there are so many ways they can support us, not just through contributing.

Attend our next fundraiser – we will be hosting a funky fundraiser in the next few weeks so keep an eye on our Facebook for details of this. Come along and bring your friends!

Come see the show! The show will be on in The New Theatre from 3rd of July, and we’d love to see you there!

story:
Say Her Name: The Lives That Should Have Been 

"I think our daughters would be ecstatic to know that their memories are being memorialized. The play almost solidifies their existence, their humanity. You don’t get this raw information delivered through the media." -Rhanda Dormeus, mother of Korryn Gaines, killed by Baltimore police in 2016
 

About the Project

In 2014 the African American Policy Forum (AAPF) launched the #SayHerName campaign to amplify and politicize the names and stories of Black women, girls and femmes lost to state violence. The campaign continues to be an essential part of a now global movement. 

The story of Say Her Name: The Lives That Should Have Been begins in May 2015, when mothers of Black women slain by police were convened for the first time in New York City for AAPF's #SayHerName Vigil in Union Square, launching a five-year journey of community building, political organizing, and relentless demands for justice. The play, written by Kimberlé Crenshaw, G’Ra Asim, and Julia Sharpe-Levine in 2019, is based on five years of interviews with this group of women, now called the #SayHerName Mothers Network.

The plot entangles the stories of six women victims of police violence and their mothers to weave a tapestry of intergenerational loss, grief, resistance and rebirth. 

Your invaluable support will help AAPF to advance intersectional consciousness across the country and around the world.

What We Need & What You Get

“This is not the narrative that anyone else can tell except for the family and for the mothers. You get to relate to the person instead of the news story and get to know them on a different level. The lives that should have been, we'll never get to see, but it's good to see the dream and how we can imagine it.” -Maria Moore, sister of Kayla Moore, killed by Berkeley police in 2013

Through a donation to this fund you are supporting a multitude of components it takes to create an artistic endeavor. From payment for actors and designers to materials to manifest the immersive learning environment, your contribution will breathe life into this project and its mission in limitless ways. 

And for those unable to make a financial contribution during these unpredictable times, we hope you’ll join us in spreading the word and joining our mailing list for more information about the organization and the show. We are so grateful for everyone’s support.

The Impact

“Now, people will have a chance to see our daughters in a different light, and see how their lives were just taken at the drop of a pin. We want justice, and now the audience knows that these are things that we can't do on our own, that we need their help. I want to keep these women’s names alive. I want us to continuously say their names.” Fran Garrett, mother of Michelle Cusseaux, killed by Phoenix police in 2014

Via a full-scale, immersive, multimedia production, audiences will get the glancing opportunity to feel a new world at their fingertips, and may perhaps nudge us all closer to its realization by watching.

The frames used to challenge anti-Blackness and police brutality rarely encompass the names and stories of Black women killed by police. #SayHerName sheds light on Black women’s experiences of police violence in an effort to support a vision of racial justice that centers all Black lives equally. This play aims to share the stories and lives of these women in a dynamic and full theatrical experience.

After the show’s first run in New York, it will subsequently tour cities and campuses around the country, including HBCUs. 

 

A Message from Kimberlé Crenshaw

“I'm excited to finally deliver to a mass audience a fully-realized artistic rendering of the issues I've devoted my life to. Throughout my career I've used more traditional methods of activation, and the time is ripe for a fresh approach.  Art allows us to imagine new possibilities, futures and worlds, keeps us going when we are feeling hopeless and burnt out, and brings vital ideas and conversations to new audiences in new ways. Please join us as we leverage that artistic power in pursuit of intersectional justice.”

story:
***Support our NEW campaign for FERGUSON's NYC World Premiere!***

 

=====================================================
=====================================================

 

LA Weekly said FERGUSON "made for a riveting spectacle and comes as a reminder both of the adversarial dramatic power that is inherent in any courtroom testimony and how even the dry language of a legal transcript can come alive when placed in the hands of skilled actors." ... "an incendiary evening of theater."
 

=====================================================
=====================================================
 

Friends, 

What a 24 hours it has been! Thank you so much. Yesterday I received the shocking news, reported in the Los Angeles Times, that five members of the FERGUSON cast were walking out because of my "conservative" politics and their desire to rewrite the script. I won't rewrite the truth.

But then you stepped up and sent donations and offers of support. Last night we hit our $93K target, but even more important we've had offers of help from actors across the country. One actor offered to fly himself in from Chicago--at his expense--so he could perform in this important work.

I'm going to be honest. The cast leaving is a crisis. It's tough and stressful, and I had a two hour meeting with the remaining cast members last night--as others were threatening to leave. I don't know how many more walkouts there will be, but I'll let you know as soon as I hear.

But rest assured: the FERGUSON Play will have its world premiere in Los Angeles on Sunday night.

Obviously these last minute walkouts have been incredibly disruptive, so I need your help again to ensure the show goes on. I need $8,000 more to meet the extra costs. It's not easy to rework an entire show at the last minute. 

Please buy a ticket or make a donation. With your help the play will be performed on Sunday night and the world is going to know the truth about Ferguson.

Thank you,

Phelim
 

=====================================================
=====================================================
 

Hi,

Thanks for having a look at the FERGUSON play. I think this is one of the most important projects I've ever done. I have an opportunity to bring to the stage the truth about what happened in Ferguson, Missouri the morning police officer Darren Wilson shot dead Michael Brown. The truth is full of shocks and surprises, but it is unbelievably compelling. Below I have answered some of your questions. Please let me know all your other questions through the Indiegogo comments section.

Thank you,

Phelim

The purpose of FERGUSON is to reveal the truth about what really happened on August 9, 2014 in Ferguson, MO and to look at why and how the Grand Jury came to the decision they did. FERGUSON is a staged version of the Grand Jury testimony exactly as they heard it. But this time the audience gets to be the Grand Jury. The performances in Los Angeles will be dramatized staged readings with interactive voting. Every night the audience will  decide who's telling the truth, decide who's lying, and decide if they would indict Darren Wilson for the shooting of Michael Brown. How will you vote?

FERGUSON

A guest production at the Odyssey Theatre 
2055 S Sepulveda Blvd, Los Angeles, CA 90025

 

Sunday, April 26 at 7 p.m. (World Premiere)
Monday, April 27 at 8 p.m. (Second Night)
Tuesday, April 28 at 8 p.m. (Third Night)
Wednesday, April 29 at 8 p.m. (Final Night)

 

 

A lot of people lied about what they saw that day. They lied to support both sides. They lied to the media, they lied online, and they lied to investigators. Many admitted this to the Grand Jury, but the media never corrected the record. 

Most people don't know what the Grand Jury heard and most people don't know that a lot of what alleged witnesses told the media was later withdrawn or proven impossible by evidence uncovered in the Grand Jury room.

 

 

 

FERGUSON shows there were lies on all sides of the story. It will show how prosecutors AND the jury asked tough questions of all sides and revealed layer by layer the truth of what happened that morning.

I am a journalist. I'm only interested in what really happened. This is a story that deserves to be told. And FERGUSON shows the audience something the media won't: The Truth. You get to decide what you would do with that information.

 

 

 

"Verbatim drama, at its best, is aesthetically indistinguishable from high art. " - Michael Billington, Chief Drama Critic for The Guardian. Britain's longest serving drama critic.

 

 

The format of FERGUSON is based on the Verbatim Theatre movement centered around the Tricycle Theatre in London UK. They pioneered the idea of writing plays based on the exact testimony from public inquiries or court cases.

There have been a number of high profile Verbatim Dramas, particularly BLOODY SUNDAY: Scenes from the Saville Tribunal and GUANTANAMO: "Honor bound to defend freedom."

 

     

     

     

     

     

    I believe lies imprison people, but the truth sets them free.

    FERGUSON doesn't present an agenda. It presents the exact testimony and asks you to decide for yourself. No spin. No media filter. Just the evidence and you. In an era of 24 punditry disguised as news, FERGUSON brings the truth.

     

    Your contribution helps us bring this story to the stage and to the world.

     

     

    We are a GUEST PRODUCTION at the Odyssey Theatre and are renting their theatre in Los Angeles, but the show won't go on without your help. When you make a contribution and claim a perk, you're helping guarantee that this story gets told. 

    Right now we're planning to have four performances in LA, April 26-29, 2015. But eventually, we want to bring the show to more cities and we even want to have performances in Ferguson itself. Even if you're not local to Los Angeles, you can be a HUGE part of bringing this show to communities everywhere.

    The performances will be:

    Sunday, April 26 at 7 p.m. (World Premiere)
    Monday, April 27 at 8 p.m. (Second Night)
    Tuesday, April 28 at 8 p.m. (Third Night)
    Wednesday, April 29 at 8 p.m. (Final Night)

    A recording of one of the performances will be on YouTube for FREE if we reach our funding goal. 

       

       

      Every single dollar brings us closer to our goal, but so does every word. Please share this campaign with your close friends and family. Tell them how important it is to you personally that this story be told.

      Tell people to visit FergusonThePlay.com. 

      Thank you!

FERGUSON
A guest production at the Odyssey Theatre 2055 S Sepulveda Blvd, Los Angeles, CA 90025
 
Sunday, April 26 at 7 p.m. (World Premiere)Monday, April 27 at 8 p.m. (Second Night)Tuesday, April 28 at 8 p.m. (Third Night)Wednesday, April 29 at 8 p.m. (Final Night)
 

 
A lot of people lied about what they saw that day. They lied to support both sides. They lied to the media, they lied online, and they lied to investigators. Many admitted this to the Grand Jury, but the media never corrected the record. 
Most people don't know what the Grand Jury heard and most people don't know that a lot of what alleged witnesses told the media was later withdrawn or proven impossible by evidence uncovered in the Grand Jury room.
 
 

 
FERGUSON shows there were lies on all sides of the story. It will show how prosecutors AND the jury asked tough questions of all sides and revealed layer by layer the truth of what happened that morning.
I am a journalist. I'm only interested in what really happened. This is a story that deserves to be told. And FERGUSON shows the audience something the media won't: The Truth. You get to decide what you would do with that information.
 
 

 
"Verbatim drama, at its best, is aesthetically indistinguishable from high art. " - Michael Billington, Chief Drama Critic for The Guardian. Britain's longest serving drama critic.
 
 
The format of FERGUSON is based on the Verbatim Theatre movement centered around the Tricycle Theatre in London UK. They pioneered the idea of writing plays based on the exact testimony from public inquiries or court cases.
There have been a number of high profile Verbatim Dramas, particularly BLOODY SUNDAY: Scenes from the Saville Tribunal and GUANTANAMO: "Honor bound to defend freedom."
 

 

 
 
 
 
I believe lies imprison people, but the truth sets them free.
FERGUSON doesn't present an agenda. It presents the exact testimony and asks you to decide for yourself. No spin. No media filter. Just the evidence and you. In an era of 24 punditry disguised as news, FERGUSON brings the truth. 
Your contribution helps us bring this story to the stage and to the world.

 

 
We are a GUEST PRODUCTION at the Odyssey Theatre and are renting their theatre in Los Angeles, but the show won't go on without your help. When you make a contribution and claim a perk, you're helping guarantee that this story gets told. 
Right now we're planning to have four performances in LA, April 26-29, 2015. But eventually, we want to bring the show to more cities and we even want to have performances in Ferguson itself. Even if you're not local to Los Angeles, you can be a HUGE part of bringing this show to communities everywhere.
The performances will be:
Sunday, April 26 at 7 p.m. (World Premiere)Monday, April 27 at 8 p.m. (Second Night)Tuesday, April 28 at 8 p.m. (Third Night)Wednesday, April 29 at 8 p.m. (Final Night)
A recording of one of the performances will be on YouTube for FREE if we reach our funding goal. 


 

 
Every single dollar brings us closer to our goal, but so does every word. Please share this campaign with your close friends and family. Tell them how important it is to you personally that this story be told.
Tell people to visit FergusonThePlay.com. 
Thank you!

story:
A Cross-Country Vision

Chris LeVan and Nate Lawrence grew up just 20 miles apart between Concord, and Sterling, Massachusetts, yet didn't cross paths until their separate journeys in theatre and film brought them to Los Angeles.

After becoming friends and experiencing each other's creative style during the making of a short film, they decided to pursue a collaborative production of one of their favourite works: Sarah Ruhl's Melancholy Play.

And voíla!  A project was born - and with your help, it will be brilliant.

This campaign to fund Melancholy Play is going to make it possible to bring the storytelling process as a whole to life. 

Chris and Nate know how the art of live theatre can touch lives and shape the creative process and now it’s time to share Melancholy Play's magic with as many people as possible. 

Paula Vogel, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of How I Learned to Drive, describes the world of Sarah Ruhl perfectly.  Upon seeing a Ruhl production, Vogel says, 

"You see the world with fresh perceptions: the man or woman sitting across from you on the bus seems mysterious and magnetic.  Weeping feels delicious and laughing feels sexier than hell.  And just for the brief few hours, you imagine you can sing and dance.  And then you come to the end of the play—all good things do come to an end—and you sigh, and wait for the next fling with another of her plays.”


What We Need & What You Get

Your investments will help us raise:

* $600 for theatre rental

* $150 for insurance 

* $500 for rights

* $900 for actors' stipend

* $200 for cellist stipend

* $300 for crew members' stipend

* $200 for set pieces 

* $150 for rehearsal space

Total:  $3,000

We realise both your time and money are precious, so we're offering a range of perks that honour your investments!
From hand-written thank yous to an in-depth actors workshop, we have some incredible perks for each level of your generous donations.
If by chance our entire $3,000 isn't raised, any percentage that we do obtain will be divided up first and foremost between our incredible cast and crew.

Risks & Challenges

While this is the first full-scale production collaboration between Chris and Nate, and challenge is to be expected with newness, they are as passionate as they are experienced and educated in the art of storytelling. 

With continued planning and prioritization (and quite a squad of support!) Chris and Nate will deliver four quality, entertaining, meaningful, and memorable performances that honour Sarah Ruhl’s bold, sassy, and unique vision.


Other Ways to Support

We would love for you to purchase a regular ticket via our Eventbrite page here and share this campaign with friends you think could benefit from a bit of melancholy!

story:
We are PopUP Theatrics!

We create site specific, site-impacting, immersive theatrical pieces in international dynamic collaborations all over the world. 

In past years we have created shows in New York, Buenos Aires, Bucharest, Edinburgh, Madrid, Querretaro (Mexico) and more. We have brought together artists from over 80 countries. 

We have been honored with some awards...

- Best Ensemble New York Innovative Theatre Awards
- Audience Choice Award in Slovenia National Theatre Festival
- Jury Award at The Romanian Independent Theatre Festival

Humbled by great press...

"There are few opportunities to see New York City in such an imaginative and innovative fashion. Broken City is an opportunity that should not be missed."~Paulanne Simmons, Theater Pizzazz

"I applaud PopUp Theatrics for exploring performance via technology; for shifting the performer/audience paradigm by adjusting its scale, location, and form."~Catherine Mueller, New York Theatre Review 

"If theatre is already tridimensional, this brings the fourth dimension!"~Sergio C Fanjul, EL PAIS

"Without doubt, the New York Artists Ana Margineanu and Tamilla Woodard, that form Pop UP Theatrics, have created a show with the spirit to revolutionize theatre and with the potential to expand it." ~Fernanda Muslera, El Observador

And better than anything, loved by you - our audience!

 "It is one of the gutsiest, strangest, and most moving love letters to New York."~Mona Nicoara
"It was beautiful like a dream you regret waking up from."~E. L.
“I silently applauded you after every moment. For every performance, for every "voice"... You have to do it again, do it again, do it again, for more people to see it, and for those who saw it already to see it again... BRAVOOOO!!!"~Andreea Gramosteanu

Our season is already well underway. Company partners Ana Margineanu and Peca Stefan have just premiered the second edition of The Vanished Year in Romania. The first edition made it to Top 5 Best Romanian Shows of 2015!

Here at home in New York, we are preparing to do two new shows: 

Broken City: Wall Street and INSIDE. 

Broken City: Wall Street

Conceived by PopUP Theatrics partners Ana Margineanu, Tamilla Woodard and Peca Stefan, real life and theatre collide in our 'street immersive' that invites nine audience members per performance to navigate the broken trails of stories, following the characters who populate this neighborhood of Manhattan. Broken City: Wall Street is our love letter to this place and these people. 

Nowhere in the world sets a better stage than the streets of New York. After exploring the Lower East Side in 2014 and Harlem in 2015, we are now preparing to present the final part of our Broken City Trilogy, this time investigating Wall Street - the core of the American Dream. The stories will focus on the human transaction with time and achievement, not only in terms of success, but also exploring how we move ourselves through this world anchored to our past, in search of our future and imminently missing our present moments.

Additionally for this installment, we are collaborating with UK’s Sign Dance Collective, pioneers of the art form of Sign Dance Theatre. Led by the deaf and physically disabled artistic team of Isolte Avila and David Bower, this innovative company fuses sign language with dance, theatre and live music to create electrifying performances all over the world. Their work is unusual and poetic; it breaks rules, transforming physical disability into artistic wonder. 

Together, we aim to create a highly visual narrative adventure that allows both ticketed audience members and random spectators an opportunity to experience a neighborhood they thought they knew in a way that is fresh and full of surprises. 

INSIDE

Then, in the fall, we will finally present to New York audiences INSIDE.

A project first created in Madrid in 2013 and then in Bucharest in 2014, INSIDE is a performance intervention created for two audience members at a time that uncovers the hidden faces of well know places. INSIDE takes audiences deep inside the scenes to experience an iconic landmark as never before. Each performance offers spectators a heightened level of physical access to a well-known location. At the same time audiences experience an internal connection to the surrounding event as a voice “inside their head” give live private commentary to each audience member via an ear-piece.  Audiences travel in pairs, seeing the same events but hearing different versions of each story. Both editions had amazing press and the Bucharest one brought us the Jury Award at The Romanian Independent Theatre Festival. 

This time because of our venue collaborator, we are taking the concept and re-imagining it in a way that we are so excited to share with you! We have invited France Damian to join us from Berlin. Big announcements coming soon!

What We Need & What You Get!

We are presenting Broken City: Wall St in July and INSIDE in the late fall. PopUP Theatrics has a history of producing innovative concepts that are ambitious in scope with almost zero budget. Our efforts have not gone unnoticed and we do have some grant funding in place but it does not cover everything. That’s where you come in! 

We hope to raise $5000 through this campaign to cover the budget shortfalls in getting our international artists to New York and housing them. But it will make possible our plane tickets, accommodation for our three international artists and the hire of local support staff. We also need to buy costumes, props and other necessary items for the show.

Your $10 will buy a prop, $50 helps to cover our local artist stipends and $1000 helps with renting an apartment in New York City for our international artists.  

In return, we’ve created some fun ways to say thank you and for you to experience the shows even if you won’t be NYC to see them. Beginning in July we will be posting notes, photos and videos almost daily!  You’ll get to know the whole team of amazing international and local artists we’re working with.  You'll feel as if you're virtually right here with us. We are also going to thank you on Facebook and Twitter and our website...a lot!  

The funding from this campaign will go towards production costs for both Broken City: Wall Street and INSIDE. 

Please share the word!

Not everyone can be active financially, but everyone can be involved! So if you can't contribute now please consider making a bit of noise about our show and this campaign.  Like our campaign on IndieGogo and Facebook, post this link to your Facebook profile or twitter feed!  Tell ALL your friends and most importantly, come see us! Tickets for Broken City: Wall St are on sale now! To find out more about us and our company, please visit us at www.popuptheatrics.com 

*PopUP Theatrics is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of PopUP Theatrics must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Macbeth

Dances Patrelle is thrilled to celebrate its 26th season, with a revival of Franics Patrelle's critically acclaimed Macbeth, set to music by Tchaikovsky, at The Danny Kaye Playhouse, for five performances, September 15-18.

Continuing its commitment to dramatic storytelling while  nurturing young dancers, this production will give ballet students from top ballet schools in and around NYC the opportunity to dance alongside celebrated professionals from The Royal Ballet, New York City Ballet, Rebecca Kelly Ballet, Sense Dance and Connecticut Ballet.   

We Need Your Help

The cost of live theatre in New York City is daunting. Dances Patrelle has set an ambitious goal to present the highest possible caliber ballet. Ultimately, our goal is $90,000. 

Thus far we are 1/3 of the way there. And with your donation here, combined with tickets sales, we will make it happen! 

Your donation guarantees an exciting (and educational) experience for the dancers, and a performance that will thrill you to your seat and have you humming the  beautifully haunting music long after you leave the theatre. 

Your Money Goes Towards...

Your generous contributions will not only assist with the cost of the talent but also support the refurbishment of the sets, costumes, rehearsal studio space, marketing and rental of the theatre. 

No Money? No Problem!

Unable to commit financially? You can contribute in other ways, including posting this campaign on any social media platform you have as well as spreading the word about this exciting production. It takes a village to make some noise so start rattling!

story:
We're Back for our 3rd Amazing Year!

Brace yourself!  From May 5-29, 2016, Sci-Fest LA returns to the ACME Theatre in Hollywood with 10 new amazing short sci-fi plays!  Guaranteed to be mind-bending,  occasionally hilarious and sometimes just plain scary!  

This is the festival that KCRW declared, "Chilling," the LA Weekly called, "The first of its kind anywhere!" and the Hollywood Reporter christened, "An inspired notion!" Just last year, American Theatre Magazine praised the festival's "Top notch stagecraft!" -- Something we're especially proud of. 

This year's incredible line-up is by far the most technically challenging set of shows we've EVER attempted.  Your generous donations will help Sci-Fest LA not only maintain, but SURPASS the standard of excellence set by 2014 & 2015 festivals.  

What We Need & What You Get

Special effects for a festival like this aren't cheap.  All we want is to do justice to do justice to these incredible stories of alien abductions, distant war-torn galaxies, deadly pandemics, inter-dimensional travel, malevolent machines and demonic soul hunters.   Some of these projects were personally handed to us by literary icons Neil Gaiman and Clive Barker! 

In order to create these desolate planets, invading space ships, slithering aliens, and creepy creatures under the dock, we’ll need to give our extraordinary team of “A-List” designers all the things they need including:  SFX lighting, 3D projection mapping, a transformative stage set, all kinds of crazy props, special effects rigging, SFX costume creation, facial prosthetics mechanics, plus lots of slime, goo and other things to make you jump out of your seat!

In exchange for you generous support, Sci-Fest LA is delighted to offer a wide range of fun and amazing perks including luxury items like a gift certificate to Circa 55 in Beverly Hills to a whole range of gorgeous, new visually stunning books (“David Bowie: A Life in Pictures,” “The Art of Hammer"), plus autographed memorabilia and unique Sci-Fi art posters (many signed by Star Trek regulars) all created exclusively for Sci-Fest LA donors! In addition, we’re offering behind the scenes experiences, producer credits, deluxe ticket packages, and invitations to special events!  Please note that many of these items have a clearly posted additional charge for shipping.  We're sorry!  We've tried to keep these charges to a minimum, but padded envelopes and postage cost much-needed money and many of these items (like the hardcover books) are heavy.  Thank you for understanding.   

The Impact

In addition to putting on two wonderful, rotating evenings of fantastically unique entertainment, Sci-Fest LA also produces GREEN SCREEN (a series of readings of innovative new Sci-Fi, Fantasy and Horror TV & film projects).  We're are also very proud to sponsor THE TOMORROW PROJECT, a sci-fi short story contest for LA county high school students.  The winner and 4 runners-up receive a modest cash prize and get to hear their stories read aloud by well-known sci-fi performers at a special ceremony.  Because we also believe art should be an agent for change, one dollar from every ticket sold during the festival (plus all proceeds from the award ceremony) are donated to the winner’s high school science and English departments.  Like all good sci-fi, we want not only want to entertain, amaze and scare our audiences; but also inspire and move them to consider our collective future.     FYI - All five finalists for last year's Tomorrow Prize were girls!  See below.  

Risks & Challenges

Sci-Fest LA has successfully funded our two previous festivals, but every year is a roller coaster of challenges.  Like all "first-of-their kind" arts festivals, we have reached our crucial “Third Year.”  This is usually the “make or break” year when momentum and enthusiasm have built to a fever pitch and it’s now up to the creators to find a sturdy base of financial support if the festival is to continue on its mission to explore strange new worlds, to seek out new life and new civilizations!  We believe our festival has the potential to grow into LA’s premier annual sci-fi event.  We thank you for your support and deeply appreciate your participation in our extremely cool new festival. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate financially, but can donate goods or services that might be useful to a festival like ours, please contact us at Info@Sci-FestLA.com.  We would also be very grateful if you would help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. It's actually easy to make use of Indiegogo's convenient share tools!  Please feel free to subscribe to our mailing list at www.sci-festla.com or share our posts on Twitter and Facebook.  THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT.  We look forward to seeing you all at the 2016 edition of our festival running May 5-29 at the ACME Theatre in Hollywood!  Live long and prosper!

The 3rd Annual Los Angeles Science Fiction One-Act Play Festival

Returning (with your help!) May 5-29, 2016

Now in our third amazing year, Sci-Fest LA will transport you to distant planetary outposts, trap you in undiscovered dimensions, fling you far into the future and drop you in a creepy seaside village not found on any map.  Our 2016 line-up of mini-masterpieces are eerie, thought-provoking, moving, hilarious, and in some cases, just plain scary!  Stay in the loop, by joining our mailing list at Sci-FestLA.com

A MIDNIGHT CLEAR

by Michael J. Himstedt

A divorced man’s attempt to share Christmas with his estranged son is thwarted by terrifying, otherworldly forces. 

ARRIVAL

by Spencer Green 

Stranded for decades between dimensions, a desperately lonely astronaut suddenly has a surprise guest.

CERTAIN UNEXPLAINABLE EVENTS

by Cody Daigle

Three troubled teenagers have very different accounts of the night their friend disappeared. 

LOVE LIFE ALPHA

by Nathan Wellman 

A young couple find it tough to mend their damaged relationship under the constant, watchful eye of “Alpha.” 

PRAYERVILLE

by Janis Ian

Adapted by Lisa Beth Kovetz

A futuristic tale of love, honor and unwanted duty played out in a distant, war-torn galaxy.  Based on the short story by the iconic singer-composer of “At Seventeen.” 

RANDOMIZED SKIN

by Chuck Armstrong & Charlie Stockman

A trio of quirky aliens fiercely interrogate a captive astronaut, determined to get answers to their questions about humanity. 

SHOGGOTH’S OLD PECULIAR

by Neil Gaiman

Adapted by Michael Bernard

A naïve American student stumbles onto a creepy, uncharted seaside village that hides a horrible secret.  Literary legend Neil Gaiman’s chilling homage to the work of Lovecraft. 

WINGED CUPID, PAINTED BLIND

by Rob Hollocks

The love between two married scientists is put to the ultimate test when they are trapped in a deadly race against time.

THE YATTERING AND JACK

by Clive Barker; Adapted by Matt. Murray. 

Despite his best demonic efforts, a “Yattering” dispatched from Hell cannot seem to break the spirit of his designated victim.  Based on the classic short story by one of Sci-Fi and Fantasy’s grandmasters. 

ZEBULON’S CALLING

by John P. Dowgin

A seemingly chance encounter between two strangers unleashes unexpected calamity.

Literary legend, Neil Gaiman makes a surprise visit to Sci-Fest LA, May 2015

SCI-FEST LA: The Los Angeles Science Fiction One-Act Play Festival is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of SCI-FEST LA: The Los Angeles Science Fiction One-Act Play Festival must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Help us keep the cool, mind-bending, scary special effects coming!
story_txt:
We're Back for our 3rd Amazing Year! Brace yourself!  From May 5-29, 2016, Sci-Fest LA returns to the ACME Theatre in Hollywood with 10 new amazing short sci-fi plays!  Guaranteed to be mind-bending,  occasionally hilarious and sometimes just plain scary!   
This is the festival that KCRW declared, "Chilling," the LA Weekly called, "The first of its kind anywhere!" and the Hollywood Reporter christened, "An inspired notion!" Just last year, American Theatre Magazine praised the festival's "Top notch stagecraft!" -- Something we're especially proud of.  
This year's incredible line-up is by far the most technically challenging set of shows we've EVER attempted.  Your generous donations will help Sci-Fest LA not only maintain, but SURPASS the standard of excellence set by 2014 & 2015 festivals.   


What We Need & What You Get 
Special effects for a festival like this aren't cheap.  All
we want is to do justice to do justice to these incredible stories of alien abductions, distant war-torn galaxies, deadly
pandemics, inter-dimensional travel, malevolent machines and demonic soul
hunters.   Some of these projects were personally handed to us by literary icons Neil
Gaiman and Clive Barker!  
In order to create these desolate planets, invading space
ships, slithering aliens, and creepy creatures under the dock, we’ll need to give
our extraordinary team of “A-List” designers all the things they need
including:  SFX lighting, 3D projection mapping, a
transformative stage set, all kinds of crazy props, special effects rigging,
SFX costume creation, facial prosthetics mechanics, plus lots of slime, goo and
other things to make you jump out of your seat!

In exchange for you generous support, Sci-Fest LA is
delighted to offer a wide range of fun and amazing perks including luxury items
like a gift certificate to Circa 55 in Beverly Hills to a whole range of gorgeous,
new visually stunning books (“David Bowie: A Life in Pictures,” “The Art of Hammer"), plus autographed memorabilia and unique Sci-Fi art posters (many
signed by Star Trek regulars) all created exclusively for Sci-Fest LA
donors! In addition, we’re offering behind
the scenes experiences, producer credits, deluxe ticket packages, and
invitations to special events!  Please note that many of these items have a clearly posted additional charge for shipping.  We're sorry!  We've tried to keep these charges to a minimum, but padded envelopes and postage cost much-needed money and many of these items (like the hardcover books) are heavy.  Thank you for understanding.    The ImpactIn addition to putting on two wonderful, rotating evenings
of fantastically unique entertainment, Sci-Fest LA also produces GREEN SCREEN
(a series of readings of innovative new Sci-Fi, Fantasy and Horror TV & film projects).  We're are also very proud to sponsor THE
TOMORROW PROJECT, a sci-fi short story contest for LA county high school
students.  The winner and 4 runners-up
receive a modest cash prize and get to hear their stories read aloud by
well-known sci-fi performers at a special ceremony.  Because we also believe art should be an
agent for change, one dollar from every ticket sold during the festival (plus
all proceeds from the award ceremony) are donated to the winner’s high school
science and English departments.  Like
all good sci-fi, we want not only want to entertain, amaze and scare our
audiences; but also inspire and move them to consider our collective future.     FYI - All five finalists for last year's Tomorrow Prize were girls!  See below.  


Risks & Challenges 


Sci-Fest LA has successfully funded our two previous
festivals, but every year is a roller coaster of challenges.  Like all "first-of-their kind" arts festivals, we have reached our
crucial “Third Year.”  This is usually
the “make or break” year when momentum and enthusiasm have built to a fever
pitch and it’s now up to the creators to find a sturdy base of financial
support if the festival is to continue on its mission to explore strange new
worlds, to seek out new life and new civilizations!  We believe our festival has the potential to
grow into LA’s premier annual sci-fi event.  We
thank you for your support and deeply appreciate your participation in our
extremely cool new festival.  



    Other Ways You Can Help 

If you are unable to donate financially, but can donate
goods or services that might be useful to a festival like ours, please contact us at Info@Sci-FestLA.com.  We would also be very grateful if you would help
us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. It's actually easy to make use of 
Indiegogo's convenient share tools!  Please feel free
to subscribe to our mailing list at www.sci-festla.com
or share our posts on Twitter and Facebook. 
THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT.  We look forward to seeing you all at the 2016
edition of our festival running May 5-29 at the ACME Theatre in Hollywood!  Live long and prosper!




The 3rd Annual Los
Angeles Science Fiction One-Act Play Festival
Returning (with your help!) May 5-29, 2016
Now in our third
amazing year, Sci-Fest LA will transport you to distant planetary outposts, trap
you in undiscovered dimensions, fling you far into the future and drop you in a
creepy seaside village not found on any map. 
Our 2016 line-up of mini-masterpieces are eerie, thought-provoking, moving,
hilarious, and in some cases, just plain scary! 
Stay in the loop, by joining our mailing list at Sci-FestLA.com
A MIDNIGHT
CLEAR 
by
Michael J. Himstedt
A
divorced man’s attempt to share Christmas with his estranged son is thwarted by
terrifying, otherworldly forces. 
ARRIVAL 
by
Spencer Green  
Stranded
for decades between dimensions, a desperately lonely astronaut suddenly has a
surprise guest. 
CERTAIN
UNEXPLAINABLE EVENTS 
by
Cody Daigle 
Three
troubled teenagers have very different accounts of the night their friend
disappeared.  
LOVE LIFE
ALPHA 
by
Nathan Wellman  
A
young couple find it tough to mend their damaged relationship under the
constant, watchful eye of “Alpha.”  
PRAYERVILLE 
by
Janis Ian
Adapted
by Lisa Beth Kovetz
A
futuristic tale of love, honor and unwanted duty played out in a distant,
war-torn galaxy.  Based on the short
story by the iconic singer-composer of “At Seventeen.”  
RANDOMIZED
SKIN 
by
Chuck Armstrong & Charlie Stockman 
A
trio of quirky aliens fiercely interrogate a captive astronaut, determined to
get answers to their questions about humanity.  
SHOGGOTH’S OLD
PECULIAR 
by
Neil Gaiman
Adapted
by Michael Bernard 
A
naïve American student stumbles onto a creepy, uncharted seaside village that
hides a horrible secret.  Literary legend
Neil Gaiman’s chilling homage to the work of Lovecraft.  
WINGED CUPID,
PAINTED BLIND 
by
Rob Hollocks 
The
love between two married scientists is put to the ultimate test when they are
trapped in a deadly race against time. 
THE YATTERING
AND JACK 
by
Clive Barker; Adapted by Matt. Murray.  
Despite
his best demonic efforts, a “Yattering” dispatched from Hell cannot seem to
break the spirit of his designated victim. 
Based on the classic short story by one of Sci-Fi and Fantasy’s
grandmasters.  
ZEBULON’S
CALLING 
by
John P. Dowgin 
A
seemingly chance encounter between two strangers unleashes unexpected
calamity.





Literary legend, Neil Gaiman makes a surprise visit to Sci-Fest LA, May 2015



SCI-FEST LA: The Los Angeles Science Fiction One-Act Play Festival is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of SCI-FEST LA: The Los Angeles Science Fiction One-Act Play Festival must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Help us keep the cool, mind-bending, scary special effects coming!

story:
Hello! 

My name is Meghan Frederick and I am the director and founder of Meghan Frederick/Practice Project, a platform dedicated to the creation and performance of original dance works and the stewardship of supportive spaces for artistic exploration.

I'm thrilled to tell you about our 2016/17 project, SOFT BLUE, encompassing creative residencies, teaching events, and showings, in Maine and NYC, with a 35 minute premiere in New York City at Green Space, Feb 10th and 11th, 2017. SOFT BLUE is danced by Elisa Davis, Carlye Eckert, and Meghan Frederick and features an original score by Trevor Wilson.

I feel very fortunate to have grown up in the woods and waters of Downeast Maine. I feel profoundly connected to that state, and to a way of life that honors the beauty and importance of the natural world.

Having worked as a professional dance artist and educator in New York City since 2008, I also care deeply about dance practice. Over the last 8 years of working as a performer, choreographer and educator, I have found that dance has enormous potential to strengthen individuals and communities by offering radical re-imaginings of our possibilities as embodied beings.

I'm excited to engage two things that are very important to me - Maine and Dance- with this one project.  

Thank you to the major organizational support of Barn Arts Collective (BAC) (Tremont, ME) Denmark Arts Center (Denmark, ME), Green Space (Queens, New York), Marymount Manhattan (New York, NY), and the Catherine Johnson Foundation through BAC (Southwest Harbor, ME) for making this possible.

YOU can get in on the action by making a financial contribution now!

Your support will...

-Facilitate the creation and performance of original dance work in diverse communities: Urban and Rural, Large and Small, Young and Old- in Denmark, ME, Southwest Harbor, ME, Tremont, ME, Portland, ME, Lewiston, ME, and New York City

-Make possible experiential workshops for diverse populations; middle-schoolers in Southwest Harbor, ME, professional dancers in Portland, ME, young choreographers at Bates College.

-Strengthen connections between dance communities in New York City and Southern and Downeast, ME through shared dance practice.

OUR GOAL

Our Goal is to raise $6,000 to support space rental fees, artist fees, and travel expenses. We would be honored to receive your support.

Other ways to help

If you are interested in donating your time and energy, whether you live in Maine or New York City, please reach out and we will connect you to alternate ways to support this project.

AND OF COURSE

PLEASE SHARE! in the age of social media the ultimate support is the time it takes for you to share our project with your network. Tell your Grampy, tell your professor, tell your ex-girlfriend, help us by making some noise!

 

SOFT BLUE  conjures a space where the fragile lines between truth and fantasy are blurred and broken. With each moment counted and accounted for, three women practice performances of togetherness, misremember choreographies, and re/present images of femininity. Dancing through SOFT BLUE reveals the construction and collapse of physical and psychological realities, illuminating cracks through which possibilities for magic emerge. SOFT BLUE is performed by Meghan Frederick, Carlye Eckert, and Elisa Davis and features an original score by Trevor Wilson.

Project Schedule

SOFT BLUE  in DENMARK, ME, PORTLAND, ME and Bates College, LEWISTON, ME
MF/PP will be in residence at Denmark Arts Center in Denmark, Maine for one intense week of rehearsals culminating in a showing of our brand new work in progress. Meghan and dancers will be teaching an open class through Moving Target Portland, and will visit Bates College to teach a master class on improvisation and composition. Class Oct 30th, Showing Nov 4th

SOFT BLUE at OPEN PERFORMANCE
MF/PP will return from southern Maine and show a little something at Open Performance through Movement Research at Eden's Expressway. Nov 15th, 7pm sharp!

SOFT BLUE at BREW MOTION
We'll hit it again at a genius event dreamed up by Trina Mannino where craft beers, visual art, and dance come together. Check out dance work by Maya Orchin, Trina and myself and grab a drink! Nov 19th, details coming soon!

SOFT BLUE at M(Mix) Residency MARYMOUNT MANHATTAN COLLEGE  Creation of new movement material through a process-based residency with Marymount Manhattan students. Nov 28th- Dec 2nd

SOFT BLUE in TREMONT, ME
In late January MF/PP will be heading ALL the way up to Tremont, ME (my high school stomping grounds) for another creative residency. This time around we will be working with local middle-schoolers in an exploration of composition and improvisation in performance. 

SOFT BLUE at GREEN SPACE through Take Root
MF/PP will return to to NYC to mount the full production in a shared evening with Kathleen Kelly. We can't wait to put it all together. Feb 10th and 11th, details coming soon!

Meghanfrederick.com

 

Meghan Frederick/Practice Project is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Meghan Frederick/Practice Project must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
The Story:

Prince Tamino goes on a quest to rescue his true love Pamina, daughter of the mysterious Queen of the Night, accompanied by love-sick bird catcher Papageno, who also happens to desperately be finding a match. They travel together to the temple of the great wizard Sarastro and must decide whether to follow the ways of the dark or the light. All of this nonsense is told through the beautiful music of Mozart and the comedic interpretation of the singers and new English adaptation of the libretto by director Michealla Cipriani.

Our production of The Magic Flute will be taking place on December 1st and 3rd!

Our cast is made up of undergraduate students in the Voice and Opera program at Northwestern University. Our entire production team is also comprised solely of students who work on every aspect of the opera from props to direction. We are privileged to be working with our wonderful music director Jason Carlson, conductor Hannah Dixon-McConnell, and director Michaella Cipriani.

What We Need to Get the Show Up and Running!

  • Every dollar donated to this production will contribute to each aspect of performance from costumes, sets, lighting to our fabulous student orchestra.

  • As a completely student run production, every donation helps promote independent student opera at Northwestern!  A new and exciting frontier at the Bienen School of Music.

Other Ways You Can Help:

Even if you cannot donate we ask that you share this link with all of your friends and family to get us closer to our goal!  All publicity is good publicity!

And that's all there is to it!

Thank you!

~the cast and crew of The Magic Flute

story:
What's the Vibe here?

A post-apocalyptic, beach themed, multimedia experience..."DEAD BEACH!!!" explores the intersection where youth, pop culture, angst, and art are weapons in the futile battle against the march of time—all crammed into terse, energetic ear worms that are sure to raise the dead.  Part underground rock show, part dance off, part raucous beach party. Nobody will be able to resist the contagious movement! Everyone is welcome. Everyone should feel that they're part of the party here at "DEAD BEACH!!!"

The Relevance.

After the devastation felt throughout the world in the wake of COVID, we need art and community now more than ever.  I want to be able to provide an artistic empathetic experience to as many people as I can, and this is my way of achieving that to the best of my ability… to leave something that would continue to inspire young queer artists that challenges the existing precept of what theatre can be. "DEAD BEACH!!!" Is a version of the world I want to see. Humans coming together finding a sense of community, experiencing love and loss together, and learning to not stress about the past or worry about the future…but rather to live in the ellipsis of the present moment.

What's my deal?

Greetings Party People! I'm Jake Corcoran, a New York based choreographer, dancer, and musician.  Since graduating from The University of Northern Colorado in 2015, I have been both working professionally as a Dancer as well as refining the ways in which I can communicate a narrative through movement in my own works.

I’ve always been anxiously conscious of the 27 club. Not to say that I’ve felt artistically comparable to the likes of Jimi Hendrix, Amy Winehouse, or Kurt Cobain…but rather in the sense that if I were to be taken that soon, what art would I have created to then be left in this universe? How do I want my artistic legacy to be remembered? Wasting no time, I called up my band mates and best friends to start creating the music and dance of what would eventually become "DEAD BEACH!!!" The original intent (back in the summer of 2018) was: “What would a soundtrack to the end of the world sound like?” We always hear about the idea of a post-apocalypse; we believe that even after catastrophe there is some world that continues on. Little did we know just how potent this message would become in the years that followed and here we are.

Who's at the party?

The creative team and cast (from left to right) is Jake Corcoran, Bennet Barber, Bridger Trap, Kaylee Olson, Madeline McBroom, Ari Conte,  Caylie Rose Newcom, Connor Shwantes, Neville Braithwaite, Elvig Michael, Carissa Fiorillo, and Abby McBroom.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We're seeking $10,000.00 which will directly fund this filmed proof-of-concept. A sort of trial run that we will use to refine the show before taking it to New York and beyond in the coming years.

  • The budget will cover proper compensation for our dancers and creatives, travel to and from New York, production housing during filming, food, insurance, venue and equipment rental necessary for performing and recording.

  • We have 6 tiers of donation perks by which we invite you to join the party in whatever capacity you wish - whether it's diving in, wading, or chillin' poolside.

Risks & Challenges

  • We as artists have been unemployed for over a year and a half due to the COVID shut down, so this is the first chance many of us have had to be a part of a creative process, and we are psyched to be here with you at the beach!

  • We have been so fortunate to have so many already offer their time and talents to make this project possible to date - but we're now at the point where we need to secure the resources to prove the concept - for that, we need funding!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute at this time, that's OK!

  • Share this page on your social network to help get the word out!!!
  • Follow us on TikTok, Instagram, and Facebook @thedeadbeach !!!
