We have been so fortunate to have so many already offer their time and talents to make this project possible to date - but we're now at the point where we need to secure the resources to prove the concept - for that, we need funding!


Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute at this time, that's OK!

Share this page on your social network to help get the word out!!!
Follow us on TikTok, Instagram, and Facebook @thedeadbeach !!!

story:
Short Summary

A stairway to heaven beside the water, a surprise garden just off of Pine, a bar outside of Fishtown, and glimpses into the Fae Wilds. Found is a scavenger hunt audio adventure where Philadelphia residents will go on the search for pockets of magic throughout the city. When they find special QR codes in these magical locations, which they'll discover with the help of puzzles and clues released online, our audience members will get to hear special audio scenes of fairy life in Philadelphia.

It Gets Worse & Philly Fringe

Found is presented by It Gets Worse But Then... (IGWBT) Theatre Company, a collective effort between Philly playwrights Devan Callahan, Doriane Feinstein, Griffin Horn, and Devin Randall. Found is our project for the 2021 Philadelphia Fringe Festival. And while we are committed to creating the project, WE NEED YOUR HELP to fund it.

Help us celebrate the magic of Philadelphia and the magic of discovering art! Every donation toward our $1K goal will go directly towards compensating our voice actors, a sound editor, our producers, and any additional expenses such as printing stickers for the QR codes.

Join us in this unique, virtual, theatrical, hands-on experience! 

Learn more at:
Instagram - @IGWBTtheatreco

Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/IGWBTtheatreco

Found is presented by It Gets Worse But Then... (IGWBT) Theatre Company, a collective effort between Philly playwrights Devan Callahan, Doriane Feinstein, Griffin Horn, and Devin Randall. Found is our project for the 2021 Philadelphia Fringe Festival. And while we are committed to creating the project, WE NEED YOUR HELP to fund it.Help us celebrate the magic of Philadelphia and the magic of discovering art! Every donation toward our $1K goal will go directly towards compensating our voice actors, a sound editor, our producers, and any additional expenses such as printing stickers for the QR codes.Join us in this unique, virtual, theatrical, hands-on experience! Learn more at:Instagram - @IGWBTtheatreco
Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/IGWBTtheatreco

story:
Short Summary

We’re Allegro Dance Company, and we’ve been working hard on a new choreography we want to share with the world! Instead of just recording a live show, we want to push our creativity by turning this choreography into a dance film we can release for free to the public.

 

Art is increasingly being consumed over the internet, and we want to join this new, wide-reaching stream of talent. Making this film will allow us to reach a global audience while also using a new medium to sculpt the way our dance style is viewed.

 

Allegro Dance Company is a collaborative effort, drawing company members from a diverse group of local talent. Each dancer brings their own unique artistic flair, dance training, and organizational skills to co-create choreographies and full narrative shows. It is also a labor of love, as company members pay for their own costuming and studio rentals.

 

What We Need & What You Get:

We need $2,500 in part to pay a videographer for their equipment, time, and expertise. Hiring a fellow artist and paying fair prices is a big part of Allegro’s equity values- Artists supporting Artists!  Funds also go towards paying for our costuming, studio rentals, and other production costs; Allegro has spent thousands of dollars on these expenses as a company, and funds from this campaign will help offset those personal costs. 

We have a wide range of perks! We’re offering dance drills and dance conditioning videos, bookmarks, a T-shirt grab bag, and more. If you’re feeling extra generous, your donation to our campaign could even bring us to perform at your next Pacific Northwest event!

If we don’t reach our entire goal, we will use the money raised to pay for filming and wait until we’ve raised more funds to pay for editing costs. Funds raised will still go to the film, the release will just be delayed!

$2,500 is our goal, but if the world is kind and we’re able to raise over that, we’ll be able to make a second film later this year!

 

The Impact

 

What this will do for us:

So much access to creating or enjoying art is restricted by money, and while making a dance film puts the financial burden on us, it releases our audience from it.

As dance evolves, Allegro Dance Company evolves with it. Individually, we train in multiple dance genres and we are passionate about sharing our collective fusion!

This could be the start of many beautiful dance films to come!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, you can still help by:

Telling your friends by sharing this campaign! A signal boost absolutely helps us reach our goal!

Liking us on Facebook  and Instagram @AllegroPDX!

Commenting on our social media links when you see our campaign in your feed! Comments help our posts be seen.

Thank you so much for reading this and for your support!

story:
In A Nutshell

For over eighteen months we’ve been working on Butcher, one of the finest new Canadian plays to hit the scene in years, written by one of the county’s most exciting voices, Nicolas Billon.

Butcher deals with a huge question of justice - what kind of punishment really fits the crime.  The play is about the unraveling of an intriguing mystery of identity: Inspector Lamb is working the Christmas Eve shift when an old man named Josef is left on the station's doorstep – drugged, wearing a Santa cap and with a butcher's hook hanging around his neck.  A lawyer is called in to help figure things out as well as a translator eventually.  What ensues is no less than shocking and challenging in every way.  

Our theatre coop Prime Cuts was formed primarily to produce this play, which we have been invited to showcase at The Cultch in Vancouver, March 2018.    Our troupe is comprised of extremely accomplished theatre professionals who believe in this project and are committed to making the Vancouver run the finest production.

What We Need & What You Get

The perks we’re offering include everything from having a listing or advertising in our playbill, and social media to dinner with the cast and director.  We will promote the businesses and individuals through our marketing, translating into thousands of views.

The Impact

Nicolas Billon’s play Butcher comes at a time when we are struggling with pain and reconciliation, collectively and as individuals.  The abuse of power is prevalent in our global community and tears at the very fabric of Western society, Canada being no exception.  This play addresses issues from our national struggles to those of Me, Too.  Butcher is an expression of Canada’s finest, having been professionally produced in all major Canadian cities to date except Vancouver.   We are so fortunate to have being invited to perform this play to on the main stage of the Cultch, meaning that we have to provide a production that looks like it belongs there.   We just want to make sure our set masters the space and that we have everything we need to tell the story.

When you walk into the doors of the major Canadian book store chain, Indigo (formally Chapters), on Broadway and Granville, there is a huge message that says “The World Needs More Canada.”  Our answer is “Here you go!”  With your help, we can share this cutting edge Canadian play at its full potential.   It's entertaining and ethically challenging and will bring to our community a powerful theatrical experience to be proud of!

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us realize our goals.  We’d love your support to do so – it will make our production be exactly what it should be – from the set to the crew.   Please share this campaign with everyone you know on all the social media platforms you can! 

Thank you so very much
The Prime Cuts Crew

story:
Short Summary

The $1,500 is the last bit we need to buy the Mystic Circus a touring and local use van. This upcoming tour is not only the best tour we have ever put together, its also a rescue missing to bring 2 new clowns from the east coast to come live in az to be a part of the family. 

What We Need & What You Get

A little bit of help from everyone to make something great happen. It's super easy. Just myself have over 2,000 friends on facebook. If even only a dollar we get closer to the road. The Mystic Circus has never be so vulnerable while simultaneously on the verge of such greatness. Just the way we like it!

Other Ways You Can Help

Come out to any of our shows! Give us a big hug and let us do the thing we enjoy more than anything, making you smile!

story: The LCSNA is celebrating the 150th anniversary of Alice in Wonderland with many events, exhibitions, conferences, and collaborations. This unprecedented public offering culminates in Alice150 Week in New York, October 2 through 11. Among the many exciting theater events and museum exhibitions and films and more are a few things that specifically are both open to the public and are costing the LCSNA far more to put on than we normally spend on events and meetings. First is the Alice Live! exhibition at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. It will be free to the general public and will reach 100,000 people with great information and entertainment, and will do more than almost any aspect of Alice150 to bring everything Carrollians and Alice enthusiasts love about this extraordinary story to the most people possible. The second aspect of Alice150 that involves expenses well beyond our usual undertakings is the conference itself. There are two conference days at the Grolier Club focusing on translations, two at NYIT on many different topics, and one at NYU on Alice in popular culture, plus a reception on Saturday night. These conferences will be attended by people from dozens of countries and will be an explosion of ideas and energy around Alice. The space, the reception, and other conference logistics need funding to keep them open and inclusive. All of Alice150 is receiving wonderful media coverage, so effects are spreading far beyond the actual exhibitions and events. Alice150 Week is a gift from those who love Alice to many thousands of people and to the culture at large. Be someone who gives Alice to the world!

story:
Hello there, I'm Helena Webb a London based dancer, choreographer and workshop leader. I have been making dance work since 2009 but this will be my first solo project. 

I'm concerned with the glorification of wealth. And fame. And royal-ness. I'm worried that we are being taught that worshipping others is more important than seeing greatness in ourselves and the everyday lives we lead. I think a lot of people (myself included) are missing greatness, beauty and majesty everyday because current society encourages us to celebrate scale, spectacle and volume over reality. I want to empower myself and others to value the small things. This project will explore what the word majesty means to us now and endeavours to reclaim it from the crown-wearers.

As part of the project I will run four euphoric dance workshops that will explore how dance can be empowering and of benefit to everyone. The workshops will be free and I hope to work with a great range of people; children, performers, non performers and older people. . . 

Majesty will be supported by Greenwich Dance and Battersea Arts Centre but their generous contributions will not cover all of the costs which is why I need you! The money that you donate will be vital in keeping the workshops free and paying for rehearsal time for the solo show. Your donations will cover studio space, printing and circulation of flyers and artists fees.  

On the right there are a selection of majestic perks for you lovely people. Including a personalised majestic haiku and euphoric dance clip! 

Huge thanks for coming to have a look.

Have a majestic day!

story:
We are honoured to present 8 beautifull 15 year old dancers, that spend their days studying and dancing, living healthy and balanced lifes, ruled by good education and human values, and will be at the Annual Dance Awards in New York, in July 2015. Thanks to their dedication and passion for dance, they were awarded this possibility. The expenses for 10 days in July in New York are a hard reality on the lifes of their families in Portugal, so we parents, families and friends are preparing all kind of actions to make this trip possible. Any contribuition, small though it may be, will make this trip and experience possible. Thank you all!!!



Este ano, entre os dias 5 e 12 de Julho, em Nova York, será realizado o evento “2015 Annual Dance Awards”. Trata-se de um evento com o significado dos “Oscars” para o mundo da dança, envolvendo entidades da dança de todo o mundo.

Pela primeira vez Portugal estará representado nestes prémios e a honra caiu sobre a escola onde os nossos filhos aprendem a arte da Dança.

A Escola de Dança Ana Kohler (EDAK) existe desde 2005. Ao longo dos anos a EDAK conquistou o seu lugar na realidade cultural Portuguesa, graças à tenacidade, profissionalismo e ao amor pela dança da sua fundadora Ana Köhler e sua equipa de docentes. Hoje em dia a escola tem 300 alunos e um nível profissional muito alto. O seu sucesso chamou atenção não apenas em Portugal, mas igualmente no seio da comunidade internacional de Dança por fazer parte do Conselho Internacional de Dança (CID), estrutura que integra a UNESCO, no que respeita a esta arte.

Neste evento a EDAK vai participar com uma equipe dos seus melhores bailarinos, o que deverá ser um motivo de orgulho de toda a comunidade Portuguesa. Infelizmente, a viagem de 10 dias e a estadia em Nova York provou ser um obstáculo financeiro proibitivo para os nossos filhos.

Por isso nós, os pais deste conjunto de crianças, colocámos a possibilidade de reunir um conjunto de patrocinadores que nos auxiliassem na redução do custo desta deslocação e estadia.

Estamos a desenvolver os nossos esforços na obtenção de patrocinadores junto de empresas e grupos económicos que consideramos atentos à importância das atividades culturais e à dignificação do bom nome do país, e cujas áreas de atuação económica não colidam com uma vida ativa, saudável e orientada por princípios sadios.

story:
Directed by Stevie King and Robin Mackey, Sissy is a site-specific comedy that explores themes of alienation and queer sexuality inside a men's bathroom. After a successful debut at Florida State University, and positive feedback from audiences, the cast and crew of Sissy are taking their provocative show on tour this summer to the Orlando Fringe Festival along with remounting the production in Tallahassee, Florida.

In order to make this tour happen, the cast and crew of Sissy needs your help in reaching their goal of $1,200l! Each donation you contribute will help them cover expenses they can't afford, and provide them the resources to put on the best possible show for audiences. Every donation they receive through their Indiegogo campaign will go towards ...

  • Budget for costumes, props, and set pieces
  • Publicity and marketing ads to promote the show
  • Rent for space and performance fees 
  • Traveling expenses 

Any amount raised will help this show immensely! It is through your continual support that the cast and crew of Sissy are able to make this tour a reality.

You can follow Sissy's progress and any contributions you make by visiting Sissy's Indiegogo page, or visiting Sissy's main page at: www.sissytourusa.wix.com/sissy

And don't forget to come check out Sissy's tour in the following cities:

Tallahassee, FL:
April 22 - 25, shows will be at 7:30 pm and 10:00 pm. Performing in the third floor men's bathroom at the Fine Arts Building (FSU Campus). 

Orlando, FL (Orlando Fringe Festival):
May 13 - 17, 19 - 24, shows will be at 11:00 pm with a 4:00 pm matinee on May 25. Performing in the Lowndes Shakespeare Center's lower lobby men's bathroom.

For more info on Sissy and its tour, please email us at sissytourusa@gmail.com

story:
SIMPLE LIVES written and directed Bernadette Armstrong who is lives in Sherman Oaks, California. She earned her BA in Film and Television Production from San Francisco State University. Bernadette can’t remember a time when she wasn’t writing stories. As a kid her stories became plays performed in her backyard during summer vacation or printed in her neighborhood newspaper, The Glenn Drive Gazette. Since graduating from college she has written and directed several plays in Los Angeles, worked on small films and theater projects, and self-published Finding Luther on Amazon Kindle. Bernadette is currently researching film history for her next book, The Tragic Lives of Single Mothers in Film.

Synopsis:

On what starts out as a brief visit home, Kathleen who embraces the world at large, yet remains arm’s length from intimate connections, witnesses her Gran and Auntie’s normal lives splinter into new dimensions of aging. Her emotional barriers begin to fade even more after friendly interactions with Mr. Knight, the local radio announcer. Mr. Knight, a voice known to thousands, lives a solitary life between his sound booth and his wife’s hospital room. Kathleen, Gran and Auntie’s simple lives expand as they embrace their own troubles, and work to bring Mr. Knight out of his isolation.  Location: Holdrege, NE - Population: 5,600

The Cast: 

Anne Cooper as ANNA

Goreti Da Silva as ROSALIE

Elaine Mello as KATHLEEN

Dan Metcalfe as MR. KNIGHT

Christine Uhebe performs various roles

By making a donation, you’re supporting:

The crucial infrastructure needed to stage this new and relevant theatrical work that includes:

  • Rental fees for rehearsal and performance space
  • Performer fees
  • Promotional costs
  • Lighting and Sound fees
  • Materials for costumes, set and props

Support our $7,500 SIMPLE LIVES Campaign with a donation and receive a thank you gift:

  • $1,000   4 Tickets + 4 T-shirts
  • $500      2 Tickets + 2 T-shirts
  • $100       2 Tickets
  • $75          1 T-shirt

Other Ways You Can Help:

  • Come see SIMPLE LIVES on September 9, 10, 16, 17, 23, 24, 30, October 1, 7 or 8 at 8PM @ The Secret Rose Theatre located at 11246 Magnolia Blvd in North Hollywood.
  • Bring your friends and family
  • Spread the word about the show. Share this Indiegogo campaign link and help us get the word out. Thank you for your support!

Other Ways You Can Help:
Come see SIMPLE LIVES on September 9, 10, 16, 17, 23, 24, 30, October 1, 7 or 8 at 8PM @ The Secret Rose Theatre located at 11246 Magnolia Blvd in North Hollywood.

story:
It's the middle of the week. We both barely have time to meet for coffee; one of us is ten minutes late. Sometimes it rains and we get wet on the way there, but we go anyway.

We start with the weekly run down, how we overbooked and had to run from one thing to the next, how coffee keeps us alive, we’ll sleep when we're dead.   

Usually there is a new story, one that resulted in sleep deprivation but also fond memories. The kind you replay in your head when you're bored, and they make you blush. If there isn’t a new relationship, it’s because we have actively chosen to be alone, but secretly, maybe we're just telling ourselves that.  

There comes a point where a deep sigh is followed by the discussion of artistic creation and mediums. The coffee date feels like a performance art piece. No one is watching but it is somehow still important.

                                                      ///


We are Ella Cuda / Whitney Casal :

Two recent post-graduates, navigating the world as freelance artists, primarily through dance. For the first time we are setting out to produce a full length work, culminating as a show in late September in the 2016 Philadelphia Fringe Festival!

We strive to cultivate an artistic community, in a way that will perpetuate it to thrive. We love to share dance and aim to provide a unique experience for our audience.  


Why donate?

Some may currently be experiencing the mayhem of life at 23, an artist in this economy, or a woman in 2016. Through Coffee?  we aim to connect individuals on a comprehensive level, highlighting themes of personal growth, young adulthood, gender, relationships and self doubt. Coffee?  makes these topics accessible via storytelling (verbal and dance), and our own personal, collective experiences.  We hope that sharing our intimate moments of self reflection can create questions for our audiences about themes we feel too often get glossed over. 


By supporting this project you can help us achieve the following:

Cost of production includes application fees, cost of venue, marketing, photography, and printed materials. Plus, the piping hot, local coffee we'll have available to you at the performance. 


About the Artists

Whitney Casal (BFA Dance, University of the Arts 2015)

Whitney is a multidisciplinary artist who focuses in the mediums of dance and photography. Although originally from Spain, Whitney grew up in Seattle and moved to Philadelphia in 2011. Her multicultural background largely fuels her love for travel and passion for a worldview through the arts. In 2015, Whitney graduated from the University of the Arts, where she had the opportunity to work with and present works by choreographers Douglas Becker, Matthew Neenan, Doug Varone and Roni Koresh.

Whitney is now a faculty member at UArts, assisting choreographer Douglas Becker as rehearsal director. Whitney is also a Yoga Alliance certified instructor. Most recently, she had the pleasure of performing at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, where she presented Mark Haim’s "The Goldberg Variations." Earlier in the year she also danced in choreographic works by Asya Zlatina and ingercooper|dancers, in Philadelphia and New York.

A lover of Latin dance, live music and fine cheeses, you can often find Whitney in salsa heels or at the nearest Tria restaurant. She feels fortunate to have such a warm community in Philadelphia, across the nation and around the world.


Ella Cuda (BFA Dance, University of the Arts 2015)

Ella is a tea enthusiast, nature lover and devoted sister who creates art spanning many mediums. She often choreographs in her backyard in Bluffton, South Carolina where she was born and raised. She made the big leap to Philadelphia to attend the University of the Arts, where she had the privilege to work with choreographers Curt Haworth, Esther Baker Tarpaga, Jen McGinn and Sidra Bell. Other training includes the UArts Dance Study Cycles Intensive in Gaga technique with Douglas Letheren and the Bates Dance Festival Professional Training Program. In January 2015 Ella completed the Level One Certification of the Silvestre Technique Training at the Escola de Danca da UFBa in Salvador, Brazil. She is also a Yoga Alliance certified Vinyasa instructor as well as an Eat Breathe Thrive certified facilitator.  

Recently, Ella was seen in the Philadelphia Fringe Festival performance of Rude Beach as well as in the REVERBdance Gallery Series in New York City with ingercooper|dancers. Ella loves Philadelphia and the community of artists who contribute to making the city a vibrant, beautiful place to live. She believes that small actions can make a big impact, and would like to thank her family and friends for their support in this process.  


Other Ways To Participate

We would love for you to share this campaign, but most of all, come out and see our production!

Showtimes: Friday, September 23rd @ 7PM / Saturday, September 24th @ 7PM

Location: Mama's Wellness Joint, 1100 Pine St, Philadelphia, PA 19107

Tickets: $5 - available at www.fringearts.com

story:
The House of Setting Sun is an original piece of musical theater, described as a Southern Gothic Thriller Musical, that will premiere at The Midtown International Theatre Festival during the first week in August. The show is directed by Took Edalow, with book and lyrics by Thomas Blakeley, and music by Julie Jeon, Jane Lee, Pedro Curvello, Cesar Manjarrez, and Sean Yauk. In it, the last surviving member of a prominent Georgia family invites Madame Eudora, a sideshow fortuneteller, to his decaying southern plantation in an attempt to divine who murdered his long-dead parents.

Think A Streetcar Named Desire meets Sweeney Todd.

The festival provides performance and rehearsal space for each of its shows. Thus, we must supplement the performance costs and salaries for cast and crew through a series of fundraising efforts, including grants, sponsorships, and this crowdfunding campaign! In addition to helping bring a new work off the ground, there are also a number of perks that will come along with donating to our project!

Funding for this show will be entirely used for costs associated with the production listed below: 
Producer: $150
Musical Director(s): $200
Director: $240
Actors: $1500
Stage Manager: $100
Lighting Designer: $100
Costume/Set Designer: $90
Band: $120
Sets & Props/Costumes: $300

Can’t donate? That’s fine! Just spread the word around about the show, tell your friends!

Thanks!

~The Team

story:
About REJECT THEATRE PROJECT

We are seven Philadelphia-based emerging theatre artists dedicated to the production of one project per member (something we call a Passion Project). We each take 100% artistic control of our own project and offer each other mutual production support in order to make it all happen. It's a magical, collaborative experiment that will self-destruct after our 7th project! 

Director Christine Freije on SHREW

"I love Shakespeare. I have read and re-read his plays, and his words are an integral, essential part of the way I understand my experience, my emotions and myself.

And I have never seen a production of The Taming of the Shrew that didn’t piss me the fuck off.

The problematic aspects of the play have been well studied and well articulated by many. To view the work as a comedy often means a reader has to skim over the abuse and degradation that Katharina suffers at her husband’s hands. To view it as a tragedy, a reader runs the risk of seeing Kate as just a victim of her circumstances. Neither satisfies me, but both provoke.

Anger is useful for me as an artist. It’s behind my best and most energetic work. And right now I am angry that there are women who still are trapped in bad relationships, whose rebellious spirits are tamed and dampened by domineering partners, and who are taught that society has no place for their unruliness.

Shrew is my effort to contend with these issues by entering into creative dialogue with Shakespeare’s work. The piece will employ a combination of excerpts from the original play, devised work, music and found text. It will feature an ensemble cast led by powerful, talented, creative, and pissed off women wrestling with the questions Shakespeare’s play raises that still persist today.

It’s gonna get a little unruly."

Goals & donation-karma!

  • We need $3,000 to produce this show. This money will be put directly towards the venue, costumes, props, scenery, marketing and artist fees. Theatre is expensive! As artists, we are great at bartering, borrowing and DIY-ing to make things work, but with the funds from this campaign we will be able to bring SHREW to life!
  • PERKS: We have a bunch of unique perks to offer our lovely donors. Some of these include a portrait session, a feminist shrew embroidery, a custom crocheted hat, tickets to see the show, a custom drawing and special performances from the cast! These perks are our way of saying THANK YOU for supporting emerging theatre ladies and their art. 

WHY you should support SHREW

Reject Theatre Project has a very unique structure. We are all young, emerging artists trying to make work that can impact the community. We are developing, learning and constantly supporting each other. Here are a few reasons why The Rejects are proud to be producing Christine Freije's Passion Project :

  • Christine Freije is a brilliant, kind, creative, insightful and hysterical human being. Her work is incredible and you should support it. 
  • Reject Theatre Project is employing seven female theatre artists under 30.
  • SHREW deconstructs the text and themes of The Taming of the Shrew in an incredible way. This production is shedding light on the problematic aspects of Shakespeare's play, society's attitude towards women & many other feminist issues. 
  • Bravery. This piece is pushing boundaries. These artists are challenging themselves every day. You will not be disappointed. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • LIKE our Facebook page!
  • Share our campaign with another potential supporter.
  • Spread the word on social media. Facebook, Twitter & Instagram are great ways to get the word out. 
  • Work our box office! Email rejecttheatreproject@gmail.com

Thanks ya'll!

Love,
The Rejects
[Christine, Kelsey, Leigh, Elaina, Lesley, Eric & Haygen]

Reject Theatre Project is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Reject Theatre Project must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Who am I?

I'm a British Comedian who lives in New York.   I've been performing comedy around the globe for quite a few years now and have been lucky enough to have my jokes shortlisted in loads of competitions including DAVE TV's Top 10 Funniest Jokes of the Fringe, The SCOTSMAN's Top 50 Best Ever Jokes at the Edinburgh Fringe & the DAILY MAIL's 50 Funniest One-Liners Ever. Here's more about me: www.willmars.com

What do I want?

I moved to New York a year ago to work harder than ever on a brand new, totally clean hour of comedy that I'm really proud of.  I want the world to see it but I can only really do that one step at a time.  The first step is always the hardest and that's the one I need a little help with.

Step one is get the world to believe what you're saying by getting a respected industry review.

One of the most respected industry websites is CHORTLE.co.uk.  Editor, Steve Bennett and his review team are all industry respected people and if they like it they really can make a difference and help put your show on the map.  Steve reviewed a show of mine (www.jokethieves.com) back in 2013 and that went on to record a TV pilot with the BBC!  Fact is though, the buzz all started because of his review and endorsement so I know from experience it works.

The cold hard truth: CHORTLE review a lot of shows but they will GUARANTEE to come and review your show if you spend £250 or more in advertising on their site.  They're good people, so they won't lie.  If it's a bad show they still say it's bad.  You don't buy their opinion, just their time.  Their time will get you a review (and a star rating) that people will listen to.

Like clever people their advertising rates are tailored so that you really need to spend  more than £250 to get to the guaranteed review threshold and so taking that into account, plus the money Indiegogo and Paypal charge, I need people to be generous to around the tune of £375 in order to raise the money for the review.

Hang on... if it's only £375 then why are you asking for £500 and also, why don't you just pay for it yourself Will?

Indiegogo has a minimum fund raising limit of £500 so I kinda have to aim for that.  But I only need £375 so if I'm lucky enough to raise that then I'll be extremely happy so stop donating or I'll only go and spend it on another advert somewhere to try and get another review or if not I'll give it to charity (probably one involving dogs! (I'll let you know where anything extra gets spent though of course)).

As to why I don't just buy the ad spot myself, I just don't have that sort of money spare (I've attached an image of my current bank balance below to prove it).  As a comedian this is a good bank balance.  In my first 5 years of comedy I had much less than nothing.  I really want to stay in the realm of breaking even each year though and advertising money doesn't fit into my 'earn zero this year' dream.

What happens if I help you?

I get the money to place an advert and I get a respected reviewer from CHORTLE.co.uk to come and review my Edinburgh Fringe show (https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on/will-mars...).  If that review is good then I can use it to get other journalists to review the show. I can also use it to get more people to watch the show. The ball will be rolling and the world is my oyster.  FINALLY!!! YES!!! THANKS!!!

What if the review is awful?

It wont be the first time a comedian has gotten a bad review.  It wont be the first time I have either.  But if it turns out that I'm deluded and the work I've put in is just not good enough then I promise to give you a laugh from that.  I will record myself reading that review out and I'll post that plus my  reactions on-line for the world to see.  Everyone likes to see people suffering on TV snd the internet nowadays eh?  I'll happily be one more of them happy in the knowledge that you helped me take a shot at the big time!

What do I get if I donate?

You have a whole choice of rewards.  You can be happy with just a thank you.  You may want one of the jokes from my show dedicated to you in a custom meme (put out across Facebook and Twitter or wherever you want).  Maybe you have a speech coming up at work or at a wedding and you want some bespoke joke writing help?  You can even have the advertising spot that I use this money to buy.  I want the review remember, not the ad, that could be all yours for half of the actual cost of the advert, and you can use it for anything you like (within reason)!

Here's where YOUR advert could be (I'll buy whatever is left when I get the money but it will be something like these areas circled in RED):

What if I don't have any money?

Do you know people with some?  If you do then please help me spread the word about my campaign.  Every donation helps but every tweet and status update will help me reach those people too.  Thanks!

story:
This play developed out of one erotic scene between two anonymous characters.  

Over time I found I was really interested in these characters and wanted to know them more.  As a poet, essayist, and short story writer,  it was my first foray into playwriting, but these characters wanted to be dramatized.  I worked on it until I had a very drafty draft of the script which I submitted to The Queer Art Mentorship Program to work with Moe Angeles, who mentored me for a year.  After which, an excerpt was featured in the QAM showcase, and I then submitted it to Dixon Place where it was accepted as part of their Little Theater program.  I reached out to my friends in the theater community, and producer Eric Borlaug put me in touch with Director Jaki Bradley who took the text I’d spent a year and a half developing and brought it to life.

 

Helps to Hate You a Little: a Lovestory is a tragic farce that unfolds in and underneath New York City. It is Persephone but with more kink. It is Wuthering Heights without the death scene, and with a better soundtrack. It’s Bill and Ted’s Excellent Adventure, if Bill and Ted were two dykes in love and Ted had an unsuspecting boyfriend. Helps to Hate You a Little incorporates elements of BDSM, shapeshifting, the absurd, and mixtapes in order to interrogate questions of belonging and foreignness.

 

********

 

I learned that the power of the play is in the poetry of the words.

I was nervous that being stripped down for the workshop, it would feel incomplete, or empty, but we learned that this play doesn’t need a whole lot of frills.  Our reading at Dixon Place was a very bare bones production.  What we do need are good actors, a space for them to explore and challenge one another using the text, and time for them to play and make discoveries in the world that we’re creating.

 

We need your help in order to give actors ample opportunity to probe the dynamics of “taboo” sexualities. To wrestle with our fears about sex, love, punishment and power. This is what our production will focus on. Your support will go toward paying the talented artists who will breathe the life into the world of the play.  Just over 20% of our budget will go towards costumes/sets/etc., and the remaining 80% of our budget will go directly to paying the artists.

 

**********

 

The realities of producing in New York are that in order to keep tickets affordable while allowing for these types of explorations, we need your help.  

We need to raise just $4,000 to bring this show to life; by helping out with $25, $50, or $85 (or more, if you can!) you’re bringing us one step closer to this underworld of our creation.  You’re supporting not just a show, but new queer erotic storytelling and the development of queer women’s erotic voices.  

 

Underwrite this underworld and we’ll give you things.  If you can’t make a donation please share, ‘Like’, and tweet. Come! Cathect! Cathart!
story_txt:
This play developed out of one erotic scene between two anonymous characters.  
Over time I found I was really interested in these characters and wanted to know them more.  As a poet, essayist, and short story writer,  it was my first foray into playwriting, but these characters wanted to be dramatized.  I worked on it until I had a very drafty draft of the script which I submitted to The Queer Art Mentorship Program to work with Moe Angeles, who mentored me for a year.  After which, an excerpt was featured in the QAM showcase, and I then submitted it to Dixon Place where it was accepted as part of their Little Theater program.  I reached out to my friends in the theater community, and producer Eric Borlaug put me in touch with Director Jaki Bradley who took the text I’d spent a year and a half developing and brought it to life. Helps to Hate You a Little: a Lovestory is a tragic farce that unfolds in and underneath New York City. It is Persephone but with more kink. It is Wuthering Heights without the death scene, and with a better soundtrack. It’s Bill and Ted’s Excellent Adventure, if Bill and Ted were two dykes in love and Ted had an unsuspecting boyfriend. Helps to Hate You a Little incorporates elements of BDSM, shapeshifting, the absurd, and mixtapes in order to interrogate questions of belonging and foreignness. ********
 
I learned that the power of the play is in the poetry of the words.
I was nervous that being stripped down for the workshop, it would feel incomplete, or empty, but we learned that this play doesn’t need a whole lot of frills.  Our reading at Dixon Place was a very bare bones production.  What we do need are good actors, a space for them to explore and challenge one another using the text, and time for them to play and make discoveries in the world that we’re creating. We need your help in order to give actors ample opportunity to probe the dynamics of “taboo” sexualities. To wrestle with our fears about sex, love, punishment and power. This is what our production will focus on. Your support will go toward paying the talented artists who will breathe the life into the world of the play.  Just over 20% of our budget will go towards costumes/sets/etc., and the remaining 80% of our budget will go directly to paying the artists. ********** The realities of producing in New York are that in order to keep tickets affordable while allowing for these types of explorations, we need your help.  
We need to raise just $4,000 to bring this show to life; by helping out with $25, $50, or $85 (or more, if you can!) you’re bringing us one step closer to this underworld of our creation.  You’re supporting not just a show, but new queer erotic storytelling and the development of queer women’s erotic voices.   Underwrite this underworld and we’ll give you things.  If you can’t make a donation please share, ‘Like’, and tweet. Come! Cathect! Cathart!

story:
Dracula needs your help!

‘Dracula’ meets ’39 Steps’ meets ‘Black Adder’ in this hilarious take on a well-loved classic, by Danny Wainwright and Daniel Hallissey.

Let Them Call It Mischief make bold, imaginative and energetic theatre, and we're ready to  bring our retelling of Dracula to life at this year's Edinburgh Fringe. Following sell-out London runs of The Alchemist, The Final Revelation of Sherlock Holmes, and A Christmas Carol (to name but a few), we're hoping to delight Edinburgh audiences with our personal brand of mischief-making theatre. HOWEVER, we need your help...

Creating theatre is expensive - there are no two ways about it. We aim to raise funds to provide a fair wage for our cast, who have already given countless hours to this project out of the goodness of their hearts (and their desire to make mischief). We wouldn't have had a hope of staging this show without our actors and production team all working for no financial reward, but it has always been our aim to pay our team a fair wage, and this is where you come in.

Your financial support will display your dedication to unsubsidised theatre and to paying creatives a fair wage for their work. You will, essentially, be championing our actors in their efforts to bring you new and exciting theatre, and you will (of course) be rewarded with a wonderful selection of prizes for doing so!


A Christmas Carol at the Pleasance, Islington 2014 - 2015 Directed by Danny Wainwright, Choreography by Alyssa Noble, Design by Ele Slade. Lighting Design by Tom Kitney.

 

"That sounds great! What can I do to help?"

Here's the deal...

We're able to get our actors to and from Edinburgh, provide them with a place to stay, cover our production costs (venue hire, set, costume, etc.), and generally get the show up and running. What we aren't able to do (without your support) is pay our actors for their time and graft. All the money raised through this campaign will go directly to our actors in order to cover their expenses and pay them a fair wage for all their hard work.

We're aiming to raise £2,500, which will ensure that each of our actors is paid £500 for their efforts. Of course, the show must go on regardless of whether or not we reach our target (in fact, the show will already be running before this campaign ends), which is why we've chosen flexible funding, meaning that any money we *do* raise will go straight to our actors. Every little helps! Furthermore, this will give Edinburgh audience members that opportunity to support this campaign after actually seeing the show, thus ensuring that they are completely confident that their money is going to a good cause.

 

"Ok, so what do I get out of this?"

Prizes! Treats! Protection from the forces of darkness!

In addition to the warm and fuzzy feelings you'll get from giving so generously to a good cause (and the bragging rights you'll have for being an official patron of the Arts), we have some very special 'Dracula' swag to give away, including...

  • Postcards and posters signed by the cast
  • Tickets to see the show
  • Your very own copy of the script
  • Writing workshops
  • And much more!

 

The Impact

Meet the cast:

Your support will see to it that this motley crew get a fair wage for all their hard work - not just for the Edinburgh run, but also for the months of readings, workshops, and rehearsals to which they've already given their time. Donate enough and they might just take you out for drinks - they're nice like that.

A very special mention must also go to the uber-talented Abigail Parmenter, who played the role of Mina Harker for our London preview, and who will be reprising the role for a couple of the Edinburgh shows too. What a beaut!

Want to learn more about our talented actors? Here are some handy links for your browsing enjoyment...

Alyssa       Anthony       Rob       Graham       Sarah       Abigail

 

Risks & Challenges

We’ve got our cast! We've got our show! Our dates are confirmed and we've got our venue! Now we need you, our supporters, to enable us to pay our team a fair wage so that we can give our show the highest possible production value.

The Edinburgh Fringe is a highly competitive arena, but everyone involved in this project - from our director, to our producers, to our lighting designer, to the actors themselves - has a wealth of experience and talent, which we're confident will make this show stand out. Not convinced? Then why not take a moment to read some reviews from our past productions here and here.

"Larger than life and laugh out loud" Whatsonstage
 "...warm energetic and innovative...with comedy at its centre...boisterous hilarity" The Stage

The future of arts funding is changing. The patronage system is making a comeback through crowdfunding websites like Indiegogo, Kickstarter, and JustGiving. With your support we will ensure that we do justice to a project that is very close to our hearts.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Come and see the show!

We'd love to see your smiling/hungover faces in the audience at The Fringe.

We're on at the Pleasance Courtyard - Beside from August 3rd to 29th (performances daily at 3.30) - buy your tickets HERE!

Share this campaign on social media!

Times are tough in this post-referendum state of economic and social limbo - we understand that - so if you're unable to chuck a few quid our way then please do give us a share or a shout out on your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, messenger pidgeon, ANYTHING!

And thank you. Thank you for reading and thank you for your support.

 

Production Team:

Director and co-writer: Danny Wainwright

Co-writer: Daniel Hallissey

Choreographer: Alyssa Noble

Designer: Freyja Costelloe

Sound Designer: Phil Matejtschuk

Production Manager and Lighting Designer: Tom Kitney

Co- Producer: Stephanie Martin

Executive Producer: Hilary Puxley

story:
Who We Are

Tempest in a Teapot Productions is a young theater company comprised of artists inspired by a need to tell stories, especially from voices that are commonly quieted. Our work is deeply collaborative, and we aim to engage the audience in a way that is both challenging and enlightening; daring audiences to leave the theatre with a new perspective on the world around them. We believe in taking big risks and saying yes to opportunities, and this next production is no exception!


What is Valhalla About?

This play is a full-throttle, hilarious epic about the search for beauty, and the web it weaves with madness, love, and desire. We follow two parallel characters: King Ludwig II of Bavaria (nicknamed the ‘Mad King’ for his obsession with opera and constructing fairy tale castles), and James Avery, a radical teen growing up in 1940’s-era Texas. Through their shared obsession with finding true beauty, the two learn just how much is at stake when you finally get exactly what you've always wanted.

Why Valhalla?

The characters in this play are relentless and fearless in their pursuits of what they truly want, and this spirit connects with us at Tempest in a Teapot, as we sprint madly towards our first professional production. In addition, Valhalla discusses homosexuality not simply as the alternative to heterosexuality to draw a few laughs from the audience, but as its own concept and its connection to beauty, desire, and passion. Talking bravely about sexuality is another core value of Tempest in a Teapot’s work, and Valhalla is not shy about this topic.


Valhalla is a play for the artist in all of us; for anyone who has ever dreamed big, then blindly and courageously followed their passion. This is a play about rebels and the lengths they go to get what they want. Artists of all kinds can relate to the passion, drive, and strength of the characters in this play. Whether you’re someone who dares people to stand on the edge of life like James, an architect of dreams like Ludwig, or even the loneliest humpback in Bavaria looking for love, you know what it’s like to search for a beauty that speaks to you.

"If you can't give up everything, even your life itself, for what you truly believe in, well, then why bother?"                    

Where Does the Money Go? 

Our basic expenses for this play include buying the rights, renting a performance space, and purchasing a few costumes (no one seems to have a King’s regalia lying around their house…). Most importantly, part of the funds we raise will be used as stipends for the actors, because we strongly believe in compensating the work that artists do just as we would compensate a professional in any other job.         


Ways You Can Help!

Even if you can't help us financially, you can spread the word to all of your friends, and come see the show!
Valhalla will run April 29th at 8pm, May 2nd at 8pm , and the 3rd at 2pm. We will be performing in the Second Floor Studio at Asian Arts Initiative at 1219 Vine Street in Philadelphia, PA.
 Check out our Facebook event page, and follow us on Instagram (@TempestInATeapotCo) for updates on our process!
